}

}

data-testid="stFileUploaderDeleteBtn"><button kind="minimal" data-testid="stBaseButton-minimal" aria-label="" class="st-emotion-cache-8ccstr em9zgd06"><svg viewBox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true" class="st-emotion-cache-1hyd1ho e1icttdg0"><p>Submit</p></div></button></div></div><div class="stElementContainer element-container st-emotion-cache-kj6hex eu6p4el1" data-testid="stElementContainer" data-stale="false" width="auto"><div class="stMarkdown" data-testid="stMarkdown"><div data-testid="stMarkdownContainer" class="st-emotion-cache-1104ytp e1icttdg0"><p><strong>Processing file:</strong> Unit_3_Adult_Nursing_Complete.pdf</p></div></div></div><div class="stElementContainer element-container st-emotion-cache-kj6hex eu6p4el1" data-testid="stElementContainer" data-stale="false" width="auto"><div class="stMarkdown" data-testid="stMarkdown"><div data-testid="stMarkdownContainer" class="st-emotion-cache-1104ytp e1icttdg0"><p>UNIT THREE PART ONE - ADULT NURSING</p>
<p>This first part of the third unit of the first module covers the structure and function of the human body, followed by the pathophysiology of some body dysfunctions and, finally, focuses on the nursing care of adults with the aforementioned dysfunctions.</p>
<p>This part of unit three is composed of four sections:</p>
<ul>
<li>Section One: The Organisation of the Human Body, Dysfunctions and Management</li>
<li>Section Two: Support and Locomotion</li>
<li>Section Three: Communication and Coordination</li>
<li>Section Four: Digestive System</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Unit three part one of the general nursing module, describes the conditions and diseases of the adult that affect a number of the bodies systems.</p>
<p>Nursing of the adult requires an in depth knowledge of each condition. This units' role is to assist you in understanding and describing each condition of the systems, following the format of:</p>
<ul>
<li>Anatomy and physiology</li>
<li>Definition</li>
<li>Causes (where applicable)</li>
<li>Pathophysiology</li>
<li>Clinical features</li>
<li>Diagnosis and investigations</li>
<li>Management (using the nursing process)</li>
<li>Complications</li>
</ul>
<p>This unit will describe common conditions affecting the following systems:</p>
<ul>
<li>Musculoskeletal</li>
<li>Neurological</li>
<li>Ophthalmic</li>
<li>Otolaryngeal</li>
<li>Endocrine</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal</li>
</ul>
<p>Although there is no single book covering all materials in this unit, consider reading Anatomy and Physiology in Health by Wilson Kathleen and Anne Waugh.</p>
<p>Adult nursing is the care of those aged above 12 years and suffering from general medical and surgical conditions.</p>
<p>In order to function better as an adult nurse, you need to understand how the human body works.</p>
<p>You will start this unit by learning about the organisation of the internal environment of the body and disorders affecting it.</p>
<p>Later you will learn about the different functions of various parts of the human body. These include support and locomotion, communication and coordination, digestion, respiration, internal circulation and elimination.</p>
<p>You will then conclude the unit by learning about palliative care. This will make it easier for you to understand specific diseases and their management.</p>
<p>There is a very important concept, which is recommended for you to apply to the management of your patients.</p>
<p>This is the Integrated Management of Adolescent and Adult Illness (IMAI) which was introduced in unit two of this module but was not covered in detail.</p>
<p>IMAI is a health care strategy that addresses the overall health care of the patient. It focuses on the main clinical conditions that account for most deaths among adolescents and adults.</p>
<p>It integrates the prevention of illnesses and the care into a single health care package. If you use this approach, you will find it more rewarding and it will make your work easier. Now take a look at the rationale for using IMAI.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rationale-of-the-imai-approach">Rationale of the IMAI Approach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rationale-of-the-imai-approach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Each year many adults and adolescents die prematurely of simple and preventable illnesses. When people seek treatment, they may get treated for a single illness. However, health workers are beginning to realise the need for a more integrated approach. This is because, in many cases, it may not be easy to make a single diagnosis with limited resources. In any case, when patients present to you, they may have multiple complaints that do not point to just one diagnosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="benefits-of-the-imai-approach">Benefits of the IMAI Approach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#benefits-of-the-imai-approach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>IMAI extends the benefits of the integrated management of diseases to adolescents and adults who are a neglected group. Furthermore, the strategy combines preventive strategies even for the management of chronic illnesses.</p>
<p>Benefits of the IMAI approach include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Addressing the major adolescent and adult problems</li>
<li>Responding to demand</li>
<li>Focusing on chronic diseases and their treatment, for example HIV and AIDS</li>
<li>Balancing prevention and care</li>
<li>Addressing special needs of the special groups</li>
<li>Investing in care in the community</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Promoting savings and saving on costs</li>
<li>Improving equity</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interventions-of-the-imai-strategy">Interventions of the IMAI Strategy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interventions-of-the-imai-strategy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The IMAI has simplified guidelines in a flowing manner, which gives several possibilities and a large number of interventions. The interventions are based on key clinical symptoms. Every country must develop and adopt core interventions that are related to prevalent diseases in their communities. The interventions are centred on acute care, chronic care, HIV care, palliative care, tuberculosis and emergency treatment.</p>
<p>The main objective of outlining this concept in this introduction is to encourage you to think in an integrated manner in spite of the fact that we will be dealing with one disease at a time.</p>
<p>You will begin by learning about the organisation of the internal environment, diseases that may disrupt this organisation and their management</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="unit-objectives">Unit Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#unit-objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By the end of this unit you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the structure and function of the human body</li>
<li>Explain the pathophysiology of body dysfunctions</li>
<li>Apply the nursing process in the care of adults with various disorders</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-1-the-organisation-of-the-human-body-dysfunctions-and-management">SECTION 1: THE ORGANISATION OF THE HUMAN BODY, DYSFUNCTIONS AND MANAGEMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-the-organisation-of-the-human-body-dysfunctions-and-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>When referring to the internal environment of the human body, it is referring to the cells, and how the cells are organised at various levels. It is important to know how the cells work and what processes affect them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>By the end of this section you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Describe the cell and its functions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Describe cell multiplication</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Describe the transfer of substances across cell membranes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Describe tissues and their functions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Describe body fluids and electrolytes</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-and-function-of-cells-tissues-organs-and-systems">Structure and Function of Cells, Tissues, Organs and Systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-and-function-of-cells-tissues-organs-and-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-cell-structure-and-its-functions">The Cell Structure and its Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-cell-structure-and-its-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The human body is made up of cells, which form the basic units of tissues, organs and systems. Similar cells grouped together form tissues. Different tissues grouped together to perform a related function form organs. Several different organs grouped together to perform a related function make up a system. In the following pages you shall see how these levels are interrelated.</p>
<p>All living things are made up of cells. All cells in the body have a cell membrane, which forms the boundary of the cell. The cell is made of protoplasm, which can be divided into two. The cytoplasm is a gel-like substance in which many processes take place. The nucleus is responsible for cell coordination and cell division. It is made up of protein granules, and is surrounded by a membrane, which separates it from the cytoplasm.</p>
<p>The cell has two different nucleic acids:</p>
<ul>
<li>The ribonucleic acid (RNA) is found in the nucleus and in the cytoplasm.</li>
<li>The deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) is found exclusively in the chromosomes (in strands of chromatin) in the nucleus.</li>
</ul>
<p>Chromosomes are the units that are involved in the transfer of the genetic material during the process of reproduction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="mitochondria">Mitochondria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mitochondria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These are rod-shaped structures that are the factories for production of energy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="golgibody">Golgibody<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#golgibody" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These are folded tubes involved in protein and carbohydrate processing and transfer.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="endoplasmic-reticulum">Endoplasmic Reticulum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endoplasmic-reticulum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a network of tubes, which is responsible for the manufacture of enzymes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="lysosomes">Lysosomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lysosomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These are the structures that form the digestive system of the cell.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-1b56c1be.jpeg" alt="img-0.jpeg"></p>
<p>As mentioned before, all the processes outlined on the previous pages take place within the cytoplasm. Most cells will eventually wear out and die, one by one. The only cells that do not get replaced are those of the nervous system. Dead cells are replaced by other similar cells through multiplication. The processes of mitosis and meiosis are involved in cell division. Mitosis is the division of one cell into two similar diploid daughter cells, which are identical to the mother cell. Meiosis is the division of a cell to produce four haploid daughter cells with different characteristics, and are not identical to the mother cell. This occurs during the production of spermatozoa and ova. The normal transfer of a substance from cell to cell occurs across the cell membrane.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diffusion">Diffusion:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diffusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The process in which dissolved substances move across cells following a concentration gradient so that they balance on both sides of that gradient.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osmosis">Osmosis:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osmosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The process which involves the movement of solute materials from a region of higher concentration to that of lower concentration via a semi-permeable membrane.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="active-transport">Active Transport:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#active-transport" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Active transport is a process where energy is utilised to move substances in any direction.</p>
<p>It has already been mentioned that cells make up tissues. You shall now proceed to learn about the tissues in a human body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tissues">Tissues<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tissues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tissues are made up of large numbers of cells. There are four key types of tissues in the human body, each of which has a special function.</p>
<p>The four types of tissue are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Epithelial</li>
<li>Connective</li>
<li>Muscle</li>
<li>Nerve</li>
</ul>
<p>Each of these will now be covered in detail.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epithelial-tissues">Epithelial Tissues<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epithelial-tissues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Epithelial tissues cover and protect body parts. They also produce secretions.</p>
<p>The epithelium covers such areas as the stomach, nose, throat and many other areas. Depending on the area where epithelial cells are found and their function, their structure maybe different.</p>
<p>They can, therefore, be further divided into squamous epithelium, columnar epithelium, cuboidal epithelium, ciliated epithelium and transitional epithelium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="connective-tissue">Connective Tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#connective-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the tissue that supports body structures and is found in every part of the body.</p>
<p>This type of tissue may be loosely structured, densely structured or fatty. The different cells that will make up this type of tissue include</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>fibroblasts, macrophages, fat cells and mast cells.</p>
<p>The most densely structured connective tissue is bone. Another example is cartilage.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-25a08043.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="muscle-tissue">Muscle Tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscle-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the tissue that makes up the red part of flesh. It is capable of stretching and contracting. Muscle tissue can be skeletal (therefore voluntary or involuntary) or cardiac,</p>
<p>found exclusively in the heart or visceral muscle, which normally makes up the internal organs and walls of blood vessels.</p>
<p>There are over 500 groups of muscles in the human body.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-6bf31220.jpeg" alt="img-2.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nerve-tissues">Nerve Tissues<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nerve-tissues" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a type of tissue that is excitable and conducts impulses. It makes up the nerves.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>A Neuron</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-764e37de.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-tissue">Blood Tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a special type of connective tissue, which is composed of various cells. You will come across the various types of cells again in later sections and study them further. Many of these tissues will work together to perform a definite function. In this case, you will refer to them as an organ.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="organs-and-systems">Organs and Systems<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#organs-and-systems" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The next structural levels in the body are organs and systems. You have learnt that tissues make up organs. Organs are always associated with each other and, therefore, perform multiple functions. These groupings of organs are called systems. Once you understand the working of various systems, which will be covered later, it will definitely help you to become a better nurse. Some of the systems are the respiratory system, cardiovascular system and the digestive system. You will cover the systems and their functions in later sections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="homeostasis">Homeostasis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#homeostasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You have now seen that there are many systems performing various functions in the human body. The body must then constantly struggle to maintain equilibrium. This process is referred to as homeostasis. The body must sense changes in the internal environment and thereafter make appropriate adjustments. The process of sensing the changes is done by a feedback mechanism.</p>
<p>You will now look at some basic concepts to enable you to understand homeostasis better.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="body-fluids">Body Fluids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-fluids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You should understand some basic terms in chemistry, for example, compounds, mixtures, chemical changes and energy. Certain elements make up about 96% of the body. These are hydrogen, oxygen, carbon and nitrogen.</p>
<p>You are aware that water is made up of the elements hydrogen and oxygen. It makes up about 60% of the weight of an individual.</p>
<ul>
<li>It makes up part of all body fluids</li>
<li>It protects cells from outside pressure (a bumper)</li>
<li>It helps in the regulation of body temperature</li>
<li>It maintains intracellular pressure</li>
<li>It is involved in chemical reactions</li>
<li>It washes out wastes and is, therefore, a medium of excretion</li>
</ul>
<p>Water is an essential part of human existence; in fact all life as we know it depends on the presence of liquid water.</p>
<p>The fluid in the body can either be in the cell, in which case it is called intracellular fluid (ICF), or it can be found outside of the cell, in which case it is called extracellular fluid (ECF)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="electrolytes-and-ions">Electrolytes and Ions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#electrolytes-and-ions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Substances dissolve in body fluids to form ions. If these substances are able to conduct electricity in dissolved form they are then called electrolytes.</p>
<p>Some examples of electrolytes in the body are sodium, potassium, magnesium, bicarbonate and phosphate. These are distributed both in the intracellular and extracellular compartments. The charged particles in the</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 104 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>body are the ones we call ions. They are always denoted as Na+, K+, and so on.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="important-electrolytes-in-the-human-body-sodium">Important Electrolytes in the Human Body Sodium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#important-electrolytes-in-the-human-body-sodium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most abundant ion in the extracellular compartment. It is involved in the conduction of nerves and the contraction of muscles. It is also involved in the regulation of acid and base balance. The acid and base balance is maintained through the exchange of hydrogen (H+) ions with sodium (Na+) ions in the kidneys. Foods rich in sodium include processed foods, snacks, smoked foods and table salt.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="potassium">Potassium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#potassium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the most abundant ion in the intracellular compartment. It affects nerve conduction and muscle strength. Foods rich in potassium are ripe bananas, avocados, oranges, potatoes and dates.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="calcium">Calcium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#calcium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This makes compounds with other elements. The compounds so formed make bones and teeth hard. The ion is also involved in proper nerve and muscle functioning, and as a cofactor in the blood clotting mechanism. Foods that are rich in calcium are grains, legumes, and leafy vegetables.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="magnesium">Magnesium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#magnesium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Magnesium is a normal constituent of bones. It is also involved in energy metabolism. It is contained in such foods as cocoa, seafood, dried beans and peas.</p>
<p>The other electrolytes in the human body include chloride, bicarbonate, and phosphate ions. The chloride ion is involved in balancing sodium in the body and its main dietary source is salt. Bicarbonate is involved in balancing the body pH, while phosphate is involved in several processes. These include cellular metabolism, combining with calcium to form bone and forming the structure of genetic material.</p>
<p>The movement of electrolytes into and out of cells is through the processes of diffusion, osmosis and active transport. These have been mentioned before. The ions you learnt about may combine to form acids and bases when in the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acids-and-bases">Acids and Bases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acids-and-bases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>An acid is a substance that produces hydrogen ions when dissolved. Acids act as electrolytes in water. They neutralise bases to produce salt and water. Common acids are hydrochloric acid and carbonic acid.</p>
<p>A base is a substance that reacts with acid to form salt and water. Common bases are magnesium hydroxide and aluminium hydroxide. The balance between acids and bases must be maintained for the various processes in the body to take place optimally.</p>
<p>You can now go ahead and do some further reading on acid and base balance. Having looked briefly at the internal environment, you will now move on to learn about the body's defence mechanisms.</p>
<p>You will now move on to look at acids and bases in order to broaden your understanding of the internal environment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="body-defence-mechanisms">Body Defence Mechanisms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#body-defence-mechanisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The human body must constantly fight against aggressors. These aggressors mostly come in the form of micro-organisms, which are fungi, protozoa, bacteria and viruses. Some micro-organisms are not harmful and we call them non-pathogens, or commensals. Those that are harmful are called pathogens.</p>
<p>In a later section, you will discuss infections in further detail but right now let us look at the body's immune response.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="immune-response">Immune Response<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#immune-response" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the body encounters microbes, it produces antibodies against them. These antibodies will fight the micro-organisms the next time it is attacked. This is the principle employed in immunisation of individuals against diseases.</p>
<p>When you give a child a measles vaccine, or when you inject a pregnant woman with tetanus toxoid, you are preparing them to fight the diseases when they encounter them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acquired-immunity">Acquired Immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acquired-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acquisition of immunity may be natural or artificial. If an individual has encountered an antigen (foreign material), he produces his own antibodies. If the antibodies are produced as a result of a disease or sub-clinical infection in the individual, this is called 'active natural immunity'. The disease causing organism is serving as the foreign antigen.</p>
<p>Alternatively, antibodies may be formed as a result of an individual being given weakened or dead microbes (vaccines). This is referred to as 'active artificial immunity'.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>The individual may receive antibodies during intra-uterine life from the mother. This is called 'passive natural immunity'. Passive immunity does not last for long. This is why children must be vaccinated soon after birth. A person can receive antibodies directly by being injected with serum from an animal, or a person who has recovered from a particular disease. This is referred to as 'artificial passive immunity'.</p>
<p>The body also has non-specific defence mechanisms. These include the skin and mucus membranes, which act as barriers.</p>
<p>Other non-specific defence mechanisms include anti-microbial substances in body secretions, for example, hydrochloric acid in the stomach, lysozyme in tears and other body secretions, and saliva, which cleanse the mouth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="homeostatic-dysfunction">Homeostatic Dysfunction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#homeostatic-dysfunction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Now you will look at homeostatic dysfunction. This is the alteration in the balance of body fluids and electrolytes. Following this you will spend some time learning about infections, as infections bring about an immune response in the human body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fluid-and-electrolyte-imbalance">Fluid and Electrolyte Imbalance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluid-and-electrolyte-imbalance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fluid and electrolyte imbalances occur in most major illnesses. Some imbalances are caused by disease, while others are caused by treatment procedures and measures. They can be labelled as either deficits or excesses. Let's start with fluid volume deficit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fluid-volume-deficit">Fluid Volume Deficit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluid-volume-deficit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You learnt earlier that fluids within the body are contained in two areas; the extracellular compartment, which is outside the cell, and the intracellular compartment, which is inside the cell. Fluid deficit occurs when fluid loss from the body exceeds intake. Fluid deficit is a serious problem as water needs to move between the two compartments. Patients suffering with fluid deficit will present with dehydration.</p>
<p>Generally, the causes of deficits in volume are inadequate intake and increased loss. You will now learn about this in detail.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inadequate-fluid-intake">Inadequate Fluid Intake<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inadequate-fluid-intake" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This condition is caused by the inability to perceive thirst (thirst is a physiological process which makes the body desire fluids), or oral trauma, causing the inability to swallow. Withholding fluids for therapeutic reasons can also lead to inadequate intake.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="excessive-fluid-loss">Excessive Fluid Loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#excessive-fluid-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This can occur in the gastrointestinal tract through vomiting, diarrhoea, suction and drainage of fistulae. Fluid loss through urine can occur during treatment with diuretic drugs. Certain disorders like hyperglycaemia, salt wasting renal disease and insufficiency of the adrenal glands can also produce deficits.</p>
<p>Due to the effects of sodium on osmosis, salt changes in the body affect fluid volumes. Excess fluid losses can occur through the skin because of fever, exposure to hot environments, burns and diseases that remove the body's ability to regulate fluids.</p>
<p>Fluid losses also occur if fluids that are in compartments such as oedema, ascites and blisters, due to burns, are removed suddenly. As you are aware the signs and symptoms of volume deficits include acute weight loss, increased thirst, decreased urine output, and increased serum osmolarity. Patients can also have a decreased volume in the vascular compartment, which can lead to tachycardia, a weak and thready pulse, hypotension and shock.</p>
<p>A decrease of volume in the extra-cellular space will cause depressed fontanels in children, sunken eyes and soft eyeballs. Patients may also exhibit dry skin and mucous membranes, a decrease in saliva and tears, and general fatigue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="why-do-patients-with-dehydration-suffer-from-a-high-temperature">Why do patients with dehydration suffer from a high temperature?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#why-do-patients-with-dehydration-suffer-from-a-high-temperature" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>One of the functions of water in the body is to act as a coolant. When fluid (that is made up of a high percentage of water) is lost, the cooling mechanism is affected.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fluid-volume-excess">Fluid Volume Excess<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fluid-volume-excess" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fluid volume excess can be caused by high sodium and water intake. Sodium retention leads to retention of water. Increased sodium in the body may occur through excessive dietary intake. The intake can also be through drugs, remedies and solutions that contain sodium given intravenously in the hospital.</p>
<p>Inadequate renal losses can also lead to fluid volume excess. If a person has renal disease, increased corticosteroid levels, congestive heart failure and/or diseases of the liver, they may be unable to excrete sodium properly leading to its retention. This will affect the retention of water.</p>
<p>The main symptoms of fluid volume excess are acute weight gain and increased extra-cellular fluids. These would produce pitting oedema of</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>the extremities, puffy eyelids and pulmonary oedema.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-does-a-patient-with-pulmonary-oedema-present-clinically">How does a patient with pulmonary oedema present clinically?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-does-a-patient-with-pulmonary-oedema-present-clinically" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The patient will have shortness of breath, dyspnoea and a dry cough. The patient may have distinctive breath sounds that can be identified through the use of a stethoscope. These sounds are known as rales. The other manifestations of excess volume produced by increased intracellular fluid are full and pounding pulses, and distension of veins.</p>
<p>The symptoms of fluid volume excess are similar to those of sodium excess (also called hypernatraemia).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sodium-deficit">Sodium Deficit<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sodium-deficit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sodium deficit (hyponatraemia) can occur in several ways. These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Dilution by excess administration of fluids (dilution hyponatraemia)</li>
<li>Excessive thirst (polydypsia)</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal losses (e.g. vomiting, diarrhoea)</li>
<li>Skin losses (e.g. excessive perspiration, burns)</li>
<li>Anaemia</li>
<li>Kidney disease</li>
<li>Increased levels of anti-diuretic hormone</li>
</ul>
<p>There are several symptoms of sodium deficit. Laboratory values will show low levels of sodium and there may be increased water content in brain and nerve cells. This will result in headaches, depression, confusion, coma, convulsions and personality changes.</p>
<p>It may also bring about gastrointestinal disturbances, for example, nausea, abdominal cramps and diarrhoea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sodium-excess">Sodium Excess<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sodium-excess" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sodium excess (hypernatraemia) can be caused by excessive intake of sodium and decreased intravascular fluid. The decrease in intravascular fluid leads to a concentration of sodium in the plasma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="in-what-situations-may-there-be-increased-fluid-loss-and-decreased-intake">In what situations may there be increased fluid loss and decreased intake?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#in-what-situations-may-there-be-increased-fluid-loss-and-decreased-intake" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The use of drugs, diseases such as diabetes insipidus, diarrhoea, unconsciousness and inability to swallow due to oral trauma are examples of situations of when increased fluid loss and decreased fluid intake may occur.</p>
<p>There are several symptoms of sodium excess. Laboratory levels will show high values of sodium. This will result in thirst and dehydration, which can produce dry membranes, agitation, restlessness, elevated body temperature and decreased reflexes.</p>
<p>Having covered sodium and fluid imbalances, you will now discuss the management of adults with sodium and fluid imbalances.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-adults-with-sodium-and-fluid-imbalances">Care of Adults with Sodium and Fluid Imbalances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-adults-with-sodium-and-fluid-imbalances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="where-sodium-goes-water-goes-too-for-this-reason-fluid-imbalance-should-always-be-managed-when-thinking-about-sodium-imbalance">Where sodium goes, water goes, too". For this reason, fluid imbalance should always be managed when thinking about sodium imbalance.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#where-sodium-goes-water-goes-too-for-this-reason-fluid-imbalance-should-always-be-managed-when-thinking-about-sodium-imbalance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>In unit one, you learnt about the nursing process. This always begins with an assessment of patients, analysing data and coming up with nursing diagnoses, planning patient care, implementing the care and finally evaluating.</p>
<p>In the process of patient assessment, you should note their personal history and carry out a physical assessment. Some of the manifestations mentioned earlier will form part of the database.</p>
<p>The goal in the management of fluid excess and fluid deficit (over-hydration and dehydration) is the treatment of the underlying cause. Before this can be done, investigations of the electrolyte levels should be undertaken.</p>
<p>In primary fluid deficit, the losses must be prevented and fluid replacement provided. For a patient with fluid excess, fluid restriction is all that is required.</p>
<p>On the other hand, the goal of management of sodium deficit is to restore sodium without causing fluid excess. Diluting the sodium concentration and promoting the excretion of the sodium through urine is the management of sodium excess.</p>
<p>There are specific nursing interventions necessary for these goals to be achieved.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="monitoring-intake-and-output">Monitoring intake and output:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#monitoring-intake-and-output" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Twenty-four hour intake and output records should be maintained to include oral and intravenous fluids, vomitus and diarrhoea. You can usually estimate the amount of losses from the perspiration and from draining wounds</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="monitoring-weight">Monitoring weight:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#monitoring-weight" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Weights should be taken and recorded daily as they provide the best bedside measure of hydration status.</p>
<p>A rapid increase of 1 Kg is equivalent to 1000 mls fluid retained.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Skin Assessment:</p>
<p>Skin assessment and care are important aspects in the care of the adult with dehydration or over-hydration. The dehydration and oedema cause the skin to become dry. Therefore, moisturising creams or oils will increase moisture retention and stimulate circulation.</p>
<p>For patients with oedema, elevating extremities will promote venous return and thereby provide temporary relief.</p>
<p>Other nursing measures include monitoring infusion rates and ensuring that patients on naso-gastric suction are closely attended to.</p>
<p>Potassium Deficit (Hypokalaemia)</p>
<p>A decreased amount of potassium in plasma is caused by inadequate mineral intake (a diet that is deficient in potassium), excessive gastrointestinal losses (vomiting and diarrhoea), excessive renal losses or intracellular losses.</p>
<p>The person with hypokalemia clinically presents with low laboratory values of the electrolyte, muscle weakness and cramps, hypotension, and arrhythmia. Other manifestations are anorexia, vomiting, abdominal distension, shortness of breath, thirst and high urine output. In some cases there may be confusion and depression</p>
<p>Excessive dietary intake, renal failure and potassium retaining drugs often cause hyperkalaemia. Patients with renal failure may have difficulty excreting potassium through their kidneys.</p>
<p>Clinically, potassium excess manifests with increased laboratory values of potassium, muscle cramps, nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea. Hyperkalaemia can also result in cardiac arrest if not urgently managed.</p>
<p>Care of Adults with Potassium Imbalances</p>
<p>The goals of medical and nursing management of the patient with potassium imbalances are two-fold:</p>
<ul>
<li>Managing hypokalemia</li>
<li>Caring for those with hyperkalaemia</li>
</ul>
<p>Before starting the specific management, the patient should be investigated. This will form part of the assessment of the patient to provide data on which nursing interventions will be based.</p>
<p>Hypokalaemia, is managed by administering potassium chloride supplements and increasing dietary intake of potassium. Potassium chloride supplements may be given orally or intravenously. When potassium is given intravenously, it may cause pain in the skin area over the vein where it is being infused.</p>
<p>For a patient who is taking diuretic medications, an increase in dietary intake of potassium or oral potassium supplements should be advised.</p>
<p>Patients who are on digoxin medication need close monitoring of potassium levels. This is because digoxin leads to an increase in potassium levels.</p>
<p>The treatment of Hyperkalaemia includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Decreasing dietary sources of potassium.</li>
<li>Administering sodium bicarbonate intravenously.</li>
<li>Administering 10% calcium gluconate, 10-20mls I.V. over 10 minutes.</li>
<li>Infusing 50% glucose 50mls and insulin intravenously. During cellular metabolism, potassium enters the cell together with glucose. This will lead to a decrease in the extraracellular potassium.</li>
<li>Administering Calcium Resonium, 15-30 g orally (exchange resin, binds k+ in exchange for calcium).</li>
<li>Performing dialysis. Heamo-dialysis or peritoneal dialysis if the above-mentioned measures fail.</li>
</ul>
<p>You are now going to learn about imbalances of two other electrolytes. These are calcium and magnesium.</p>
<p>Calcium Imbalance</p>
<p>Calcium metabolism is dependent on three factors. They are vitamin D, and the hormones parathormone and calcitonin. These factors influence the use of calcium and are involved in the re-modelling of bone. (This explains why a child with a vitamin D deficiency suffers from rickets. You will come across further information on this in our unit on paediatric nursing.)</p>
<p>The primary goal in managing calcium imbalance is treating the cause. If a patient has a disorder affecting the utilisation of any of the factors that have been named, then they should be treated for that problem.</p>
<p>More specifically, hypocalcaemia is treated with oral or intravenous calcium supplements such as calcium lactate and calcium gluconate. Patients that have had thyroid surgery must be closely monitored for symptoms of hypocalcaemia. During surgery, the parathyroid glands may be affected leading to lack of production of the parathyroid hormone.</p>
<p>Hypercalcaemia is managed by promoting excretion of calcium in the urine. The best way to do this is through administration of loop diuretics.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 108 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>A good loop diuretic is furosemide e.g. lasix. The patient must also increase daily fluid intake to about four litres. This will decrease the possibility of renal stone formation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="magnesium-imbalances">Magnesium Imbalances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#magnesium-imbalances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Magnesium is the second most abundant intracellular action. The factors that influence calcium imbalance will also influence magnesium imbalance.</p>
<p>Hypomagnesaemia produces neuromuscular and central nervous system hyperirritability. Symptoms include insomnia, anxiety, and muscle cramps. Additionally, diets that are low in magnesium indicate a risk factor for hypotension, cardiac dysrhythmias, ischemic heart disease and sudden cardiac death. This will be mentioned again when you learn about disorders of the circulatory system and their management.</p>
<p>A patient with slight hypomagnesaemia can be treated with magnesium supplements. The patient also needs to increase their dietary intake of foods high in magnesium. These foods include green vegetables, nuts, bananas and oranges. If the hypomagnesaemia is severe, then IV or IM magnesium is given. This drug is mainly used in the management of hypotensive disease in pregnancy. However, it may also be used in treating hypomagnesaemia.</p>
<p>The management of hypermagnesaemia should focus on prevention. This, therefore, means that people with renal failure should not take medication containing magnesium. It may lead to the accumulation of the electrolyte in the plasma.</p>
<p>The emergency management of hypermagnesemia should focus on giving IV calcium chloride or calcium gluconate to physiologically oppose the effects of the magnesium on the cardiac muscle. Promoting urinary excretion with fluids will also decrease serum magnesium. If a patient has renal failure, they may require renal dialysis.</p>
<p>This information should assist you in giving better care to a patient with an electrolyte imbalance. You will now study the constituents of plasma as well as plasma proteins in an effort to better understand plasma protein imbalances.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plasma-protein-imbalance">Plasma Protein Imbalance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasma-protein-imbalance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By now you may have learnt about the importance of plasma proteins in maintaining oncotic pressure. This is the pressure that maintains the extracellular and intracellular fluid balance. Examples of plasma proteins include albumin, antibodies and lipoproteins.</p>
<p>Hypoproteinaemia is a decrease in the amount of plasma proteins. It occurs through anorexia, malnutrition, starvation and consuming poorly balanced vegetarian diets. It may also occur through malabsorption, inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract and increased breakdown of protein. Poor absorption can occur with diarrhoea. Diseases such as HIV/AIDS contribute to increased breakdown of proteins in the body.</p>
<p>Hyperproteinaemia is rare but occurs through dehydration resulting in haemo-concentration of the available proteins in the body.</p>
<p>The management of plasma protein deficits includes providing a high carbohydrate and high protein diet. A high carbohydrate diet is essential to prevent body protein breakdown as a source of energy. Deficits can be treated by use of dietary protein supplements.</p>
<p>Enteral nutrition or total parenteral nutrition can also be used to deal with hypoproteinaemia, if dietary needs cannot be met orally.</p>
<p>The former is where a patient is fixed with a naso-gastric tube for giving commercially prepared concentrated proteins, while the latter involves using an IV line to infuse proteins that have been commercially prepared.</p>
<p>You will now move your attention to acid and base balance before you proceed with the rest of your unit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acid-base-imbalances">Acid-Base Imbalances<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acid-base-imbalances" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You will now cover some problems that you are likely to encounter in your daily practice that are related to acid-base balance. These include respiratory acidosis, metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis and metabolic alkalosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-acidosis">Respiratory Acidosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-acidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an excess of carbonic acid. The body pH in this case is below 7.5. Common causes of respiratory acidosis are inadequate ventilation, respiratory obstruction such as those that occur in asthma and respiratory tract tumours, impaired gaseous exchange and spinal cord injury at the cervical level. The acidosis clinically presents with cyanosis, tachycardia and disorientation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="metabolic-acidosis">Metabolic Acidosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-acidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a deficit of the bicarbonate ion. It may also be due to an excess of other acids in the body. The pH is normally less than 7.5, and common causes are starvation leading to increased ketones due to lipolysis. The signs and symptoms include headache, weakness, and deep laboured breathing.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
