Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="respiratory-alkalosis">Respiratory Alkalosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-alkalosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In this abnormality, there is carbonic acid deficit, mostly due to hyperventilation. The pH will be found to be above 7.5 and it presents with deep rapid breathing, tingling sensations, and tinnitus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="what-are-the-common-causes-of-hyperventilation">What are the common causes of hyperventilation?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-are-the-common-causes-of-hyperventilation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Anxiety</li>
<li>Crying / Distress</li>
<li>Grief</li>
<li>Stress</li>
<li>Hysteria</li>
<li>Panic Attack</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="metabolic-alkalosis">Metabolic Alkalosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#metabolic-alkalosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An excess of bicarbonate ion and a pH level above 7.5. characterises this abnormality. The contributory causes include H+ losses from the GIT through vomiting and gastric lavage. Over enthusiastic treatment with sodium bicarbonate may also cause it. Signs include tetany, tingling, tremors and dizziness.</p>
<p>The general management of acid and base imbalance involves three main actions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Determine the cause of the imbalance</li>
<li>Address the cause</li>
<li>Administer fluids</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infections">Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Human beings are always interacting with micro-organisms. Some of them are commensals, while others attack us and bring about disease (pathogens). However, we employ defence mechanisms to minimise the danger from the latter, you learnt this earlier in the section.</p>
<p>The various agents of infectious diseases are viruses, bacteria, rickettsiae, chlamydia, fungi and parasites.</p>
<p>You will now look at each of these agents and begin with viruses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viruses">Viruses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viruses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Viruses are small intracellular organisms. They can be classified as either DNA or RNA viruses depending on the nucleic material they contain. Each virus contains only one type of nucleic material.</p>
<p>Viruses do not replicate outside a living cell. They are sometimes enveloped in lipoprotein envelopes, which are from the membrane of a host cell.</p>
<p>Viruses must enter a host cell and use its mechanisms to multiply. This makes it difficult for the cell to recognise and fight them.</p>
<p>Viruses are grouped according to their characteristics and the various diseases they cause. Some examples of groups of viruses include the herpes virus group, which includes herpes zoster, chicken pox viruses, and cytomegalovirus. The other group is the retrovirus group, which include the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV).</p>
<p>Viruses are classified according to various characteristics.</p>
<p>These are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Type of viral genome</li>
<li>Mechanism of replication</li>
<li>Mode of transmission</li>
<li>Type of disease produced</li>
</ul>
<p>A good example is HIV. It is called a retrovirus because it can produce DNA from RNA instead of the usual reverse. In this unit you will learn about infections affecting various functions in the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bacteria">Bacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are autonomously replicating unicellular organisms. Unlike viruses, bacteria contain both DNA and RNA. The structure and synthesis of the cell wall determine whether the microscopic shape of the bacterium is spherical (cocci), helical (spiral) or elongated (bacilli).</p>
<p>When the cocci divide in chains, they are referred to as streptococci. If they divide into pairs they are called diplococci and if they form clusters they are known as staphylococci.</p>
<p>Bacteria may be motile as a result of flagella. Other bacteria produce hair like structures called pili or fimbriae. These enable them to adhere to other bacteria or membranes in the body.</p>
<p>Some bacteria require oxygen for their growth. They are referred to as aerobes. These bacteria are found in parts of the body where oxygen is abundant. Those that cannot survive in an oxygenated environment are called anaerobes. Those that can live in either of these circumstances are referred to as facultative anaerobes.</p>
<p>Another way of classifying bacteria is according to their appearance and staining properties.</p>
<p>They are called gram positive if they stain red by sufrine dye (gram stain) or gram negative if they do not.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 111 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="spirochaetes">Spirochaetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spirochaetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are a category of bacteria, which will be discussed separately because of their morphology and mobility. They are gram-negative rods. The spirochaetes move in a corkscrew fashion. They are facultative anaerobes. They are sub-classified into three groups:</p>
<ul>
<li>Leptospira</li>
<li>Borrelia</li>
<li>Treponema</li>
</ul>
<p>You may remember the organisms that cause syphilis, treponema pallidum. Borrelia cause relapsing fever and a good example of this group is borrelia recurrentis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mycoplasma">Mycoplasma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mycoplasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are micro-organisms capable of independent replication. They are smaller than bacteria, and do not have the same kind of cell wall as bacteria. They, therefore, have varied morphology. Some of these mycoplasma are commensals in the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rickettsiae-and-chlamydia">Rickettsiae and Chlamydia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rickettsiae-and-chlamydia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are micro-organisms that have both characteristics of bacteria and viruses. They are intra-cellular but contain both DNA and RNA. The rickettsiae produce epidemic typhus, while chlamydia produces the infection chlamydia trachomatis in the eyes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fungi">Fungi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fungi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Fungi are free-living saprophytes. Some of them are normal flora on the human body. Despite being normal flora, some fungi have the ability to cause serious illnesses. They are classified into two groups: yeasts and moulds. Yeasts are single celled organisms that reproduce by budding. Moulds produce long hollow branching filaments.</p>
<p>Most fungi are capable of both sexual and asexual reproduction. Asexual reproduction produces spores, which are very resistant. This is the reason why you must practice good infection prevention practices. Some of the diseases caused by fungi are candidiasis, superficial mycoses and systemic mycoses.</p>
<p>Now you will look at the last group of infectious agents, the parasites.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="parasites">Parasites<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parasites" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This term is used to refer to micro-organisms of the animal kingdom, which cause diseases in other animals. This group includes protozoa (such as those that cause malaria), helminths and arthropods.</p>
<p>The helminths are mobile parasites, while arthropods are vectors of diseases, for example, ticks. Others are ecto-parasites, for example, lice and mites that cause scabies. Ecto-parasites live on the outer body surface of their host.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="malaria">Malaria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#malaria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You will now look at a parasitic disease that presents a great challenge to health care services in our country. This is malaria.</p>
<p>Malaria is a parasite disease caused by Plasmodium. Plasmodium falciparum is the commonest species of the parasite in Kenya. The infection is usually transmitted through the bite of a female anopheles mosquito. It causes much death, especially among children and pregnant women. Its clinical features include fever, joint pains, chills, mental confusion, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, nausea and vomiting.</p>
<p>The clinical presentation of malaria may be uncomplicated or severe. Uncomplicated malaria has all the clinical signs mentioned above, with none of the complications that will now be outlined.</p>
<p>Severe malaria presents with prostration, unconsciousness and/or respiratory distress. Additional complications include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cerebral malaria resulting in coma</li>
<li>Convulsions</li>
<li>Severe anaemia with Hb less than 5mg/dl</li>
<li>Renal failure</li>
<li>Hypoglycaemia</li>
<li>Fluid and electrolyte imbalance</li>
<li>Pulmonary oedema and hypovolemic shock</li>
</ul>
<p>In Kenya, due to the lack of effective and adequate health care systems, you may have to deal with treatment failure and recrudescence (recurrence) of clinical symptoms. There are areas in Kenya with endemic malaria. These areas include Kitui, TaitaTaveta and Tana River districts.</p>
<p>Other areas exhibit unstable malaria, which occurs sometimes during epidemics in areas of low malaria risk. The epidemic areas are the western highland regions of Kisii and Kericho, extending in a belt to parts of Western Kenya.</p>
<p>The treatment of uncomplicated malaria should involve a combination of artemisinin based drugs, such as Coartem, which is a combination of artemether and lumefantrine. If this is unavailable, other artemisinin based drugs may be used. For any patient with malaria, supportive management for the</p>
<p>anaemia, fever, nausea, diarrhoea and other symptoms that inevitably arise, should be undertaken.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-adults-with-infections">Care of Adults with Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-adults-with-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>From experience, you are aware that developing countries suffer high morbidity and mortality related to infectious diseases. It is, therefore, necessary to learn about the management of adults with infections.</p>
<p>From unit one, you would have learnt that assessment is done as part of the nursing process to obtain information necessary to plan the care. Based on the nursing diagnoses made, several actions are necessary</p>
<p>The care for an adult with infection will be done in various phases. There is the acute intervention phase during which you should observe vital signs, for example, fever, pulse rate, respiration and blood pressure.</p>
<p>Antipyretic medication is used to control fever. Fever must be controlled to allow the body to fight infections more easily.</p>
<p>Antipyretic drugs include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Acetylsalicylic acid</li>
<li>Acetaminophen</li>
</ul>
<p>The use of anti-microbial drugs, for example, antibiotics, anti-protozoa drugs, anti-viral drugs and anti-fungal drugs is important to control viruses, protozoa bacteria and fungi. These medications may be given orally, parenterally, topically or by any other route that is suitable.</p>
<p>At the same time, it is important to consider the patient's comfort, rest, nutrition, fluid and electrolyte balance and any other accompanying symptoms. Always remember to evaluate care administered to ensure you meet your objectives.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infection-prevention-and-control">Infection Prevention and Control<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infection-prevention-and-control" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is necessary to follow aseptic procedures in keeping the ward as free from microbes as possible. Infection prevention precautions are required for this purpose. The precautions are category specific, disease specific, universal precautions and body substance isolation.</p>
<p>These are the precautions you follow when washing hands, decontaminating instruments, undertaking high level disinfection and sterilization. Barrier nursing, isolation and reverse barrier nursing of patients are all intended to minimise infections and their spread.</p>
<p>You have covered these precautions in unit one and you will come across the concepts again in the units on Reproductive Health and Communicable Diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-an-adult-with-an-immune-deficiency">Care of an Adult with an Immune Deficiency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-an-adult-with-an-immune-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You have learnt that when the immune system does not adequately protect the body, an immune deficiency state exists. There are many immunodeficiency states and several measures specific to each disease are available that will be used in the management of these states.</p>
<p>You will, however, concern yourself with one syndrome that is a major problem in sub-Saharan Africa generally, and Kenya in particular. This is the Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hiv-and-aids">HIV and AIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hiv-and-aids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The management of a HIV-infected patient focuses on:</p>
<ul>
<li>Monitoring HIV disease progression and immune function</li>
<li>Initiating and monitoring antiretroviral therapy</li>
<li>Detecting and treating opportunistic infections</li>
<li>Managing symptoms and preventing complications</li>
</ul>
<p>Ongoing patient assessment and patient education will help you to accomplish these functions.</p>
<p>However, the best way of managing HIV/AIDS is prevention. This starts with being aware of one's HIV status, remaining faithful to one's sexual partner and/or the use of condoms during sexual intercourse. Perhaps you have heard of the ABCD of HIV/AIDS prevention. It generally includes all the information that you will give your patients concerning HIV/AIDS. In addition, good nutrition for adults and children already infected will enable them to lead better quality lives.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pharmacologic-management-of-hiv-aids">Pharmacologic Management of HIV/AIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharmacologic-management-of-hiv-aids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Antiretroviral drugs are given to patients so that they may slow down the multiplication of the virus. However, they do not eliminate it. Nevirapine, Azidothymidine (AZT) and other drugs are distributed at various centres in the country. These drugs are expensive and may be beyond the reach of many patients. It is your responsibility to give patients all the information required and let them make informed decisions.</p>
<p>Opportunistic infections and other manifestations of HIV respond well to treatment.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Pneumonia requires the use of appropriate antibiotics. The antibiotics that may be used include the cephalosporins, aminoglycosides such as kanamycin.</p>
<p>Diarrhoea requires correction of dehydration and use of drugs, for example, cotrimoxazole (Septrin) and metronidazole (Flagyl).</p>
<p>Oropharyngeal candidiasis requires the use of anti-fungal agents such as nystatin oral drops, miconazole oral gel or Ketoconazole tablets to control candida.</p>
<p>Tuberculosis needs close follow-up and use of anti-tuberculous drugs. This is because of high rates of relapse among HIV-infected patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hiv-and-aids">HIV and AIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hiv-and-aids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>HIV testing and patient education is an important aspect of the management and prevention of AIDS. Voluntary Counselling and Testing (VCT) services are now available in Kenya and should be promoted as part of the effort to control the spread of the infection.</p>
<p>Patient education should cover the topics of HIV transmission, how to avoid getting infected and how to live healthier lives even with HIV infection.</p>
<p>This information on HIV/AIDS may not be enough but will be a basis for further reading. You should spend some time finding out more about this.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-2-support-and-locomotion">SECTION 2: SUPPORT AND LOCOMOTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-2-support-and-locomotion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>You are now ready to continue with section two. In this section you will learn the structures involved in enabling support and locomotion of the body. These include the muscles, bones, ligaments, and joints. Before you start, here are the objectives to achieve by the end of this section.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>By the end of this section you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the bony framework of the body and its functions</li>
<li>Describe the process of bone healing</li>
<li>Describe common orthopaedic conditions</li>
<li>Describe the structure of the major muscles and their functions</li>
<li>Describe the structure, type and functions of the major joints</li>
<li>Utilise the nursing process in the management of adults with bone, muscle and joint problems</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="bones-and-their-functions">Bones and their Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bones-and-their-functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>You have already learnt that bone is a type of connective tissue. It is made up of water, living cells, calcium and phosphorus as its main components. The cells making up the bone are osteoblasts and osteoclasts. The latter are involved in the shaping of the bone through bone re-absorption.</p>
<p>The image (right) shows the macroscopic structure of a bone. In the human body, there are several types of bones mainly based on their shapes.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-2760c677.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bones">Bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The bone is the hardest tissue in the body and when fully developed comprises of:</p>
<p>Water 20%</p>
<ul>
<li>Organic material 30% to 40%</li>
<li>Inorganic materials 40% to 50%</li>
</ul>
<p>Inorganic material mainly constitutes of mineral salts especially calcium and phosphates. Organic materials comprise of bone cells.</p>
<p>There are two types of bone tissue - compact and cancellous. Bones are almost completely covered by periosteum which is a vascular fibrous membrane. Periosteum gives attachment to muscles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-bones">Types of Bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Bones are classified as long, short, irregular, flat or sesamoid, long bones eg. femur, humerus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="development-of-bone">Development of Bone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#development-of-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the process of bone formation that begins before birth and is not completed until age 25 years. Long, short and irregular bones develop from cartilage models.</p>
<p>A primary centre of ossification results from deposits of both organic and inorganic bone elements. This further develops allowing for a clear demarcation of the diaphysis. A two degree centre of ossification develops from the epiphysis. An epiphyseal cartilage demarcates the diaphysis from the epiphysis.</p>
<p>Osteoblasts and osteoclasts are involved in bone development. Osteoblasts are present at the centres of ossification of immature bone, at</p>
<p>ends of diaphysis and epiphyseal cartilage. They are involved in bone building.</p>
<p>Osteoclasts are responsible for bone resorption. They maintain and shape the bone.</p>
<p>It is advised that you do some further reading later, on the development of bone and various bone cells. You will now learn about the bony skeleton.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-skeleton">The Skeleton<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-skeleton" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The human skeleton is divided into two main parts: the axial skeleton and the appendicular skeleton. The axial skeleton refers to the central, while appendicular refers to the attachments.</p>
<p>The axial skeleton is made up of the skull, the vertebral column, the ribs and the sternum. The appendicular skeleton consists of the shoulder girdle, upper limbs, pelvic girdle and lower limbs. The total number of bones in the human body is at least 206. Study the diagram of the human skeleton.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-bones">Functions of Bones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-bones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The bones perform several functions. They:</p>
<ul>
<li>Provide the basic framework of the body</li>
<li>Provide points of attachments to muscles and tendons</li>
<li>Form a reservoir for calcium</li>
<li>Permit movement of the body as a whole by forming joints</li>
<li>Form boundaries of many cavities, which provides protection to organs within</li>
<li>Contain red bone marrow, which is involved in the production of blood cells</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>You will need to find time to study in detail the various bones.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-3f9249ea.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="joints">Joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are points in the body at which bones attach to each other. These are called joints. They form the points at which many movements can be made and positions changed.</p>
<p>Generally, there are three main types of joints:</p>
<ul>
<li>Fibrous joints, which are fixed and immovable joints. Examples include the joints between various skull bones (or sutures).</li>
<li>Cartilaginous joints, which are slightly movable and enable you to bend. They have cartilage between two bones. Good examples are joints between the vertebral bones.</li>
<li>Synovial (diarthrosis) joints, which are freely movable. They are further subdivided into ball and socket joints, hinge joints, gliding joints, pivot and saddle joints</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 115 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="movements-of-joints">Movements of Joints<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#movements-of-joints" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The various movements made at the joints include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Flexion: bending forward and backward. The knee joint is a good example of this.</li>
<li>Extension: straightening or bending backwards.</li>
<li>Abduction: movement away from the midline. The best example of this is moving your arm or leg away from your body laterally.</li>
<li>Eversion: turning the sole of the foot outwards.</li>
<li>Inversion: turning the sole of foot inwards.</li>
<li>Supination: turning the palm up.</li>
<li>Pronation: turning the palm downwards.</li>
<li>Rotation: movement around the long axis. You may use either the lower limb or the upper limb.</li>
<li>Circumduction: a combination of adduction, flexion and extension.</li>
<li>Adduction: movement towards the middle of body.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="muscles-and-ligaments">Muscles and Ligaments<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#muscles-and-ligaments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You previously learnt that muscle tissues belong to either of three groups. These are visceral, cardiac and skeletal.</p>
<p>Cardiac muscle is exclusively found in the heart.</p>
<p>Skeletal muscle is what makes up most of the structures in your body. It is called striated or</p>
<p>voluntary because its contraction can be controlled at will.</p>
<p>Visceral muscle makes up the intestines and the hollow organs. It is not striated and is involuntary.</p>
<p>Muscles can contract and are extensible and elastic. They are also irritable, which explains why nerve impulses can excite them. These properties enable them to stretch and return to normal, become thicker and respond to a stimulus. Individual muscles have various names.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-muscles">Functions of Muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Muscles are influenced by nerve impulse, hormones and, for cardiac muscle, impulses generated in the heart muscle. Muscle contraction causes movement of various parts in the body. Energy for contraction is obtained from metabolism. This energy is in the form of Adenosine Triphosphate (ATP).</p>
<p>The nerves and special messengers, that is, the hormones, do an important job. The functions of the muscles can, therefore, be listed as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Contracting, hence, performing work</li>
<li>Protecting internal structures</li>
<li>Producing movement in conjunction with muscles, bones and joints</li>
</ul>
<p>You will now start learning about the disorders of the various structures in more detail.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-bones-and-their-management">Disorders of Bones and their Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-bones-and-their-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Disorders of the bones range from those that occur as a result of altered growth and development, to those due to disordered metabolism, neoplasm, injuries and their complications.</p>
<p>The disorders occurring during growth and development include femoral ante-version where there is internal torsion or rotation of the femur and toeing-out of the foot with the foot flat and toes spread out. Many of the conditions resolve by themselves while a few may need surgery. However, these are generally rare conditions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scoliosis">Scoliosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scoliosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Scoliosis, which is lateral deviation of the spinal column. This condition can occur without any cause or may be caused by certain diseases. For instance, disturbances in vertebral development and neuromuscular disorders such as poliomyelitis can lead to scoliosis.</p>
<p>The manifestations of scoliosis include uneven shoulders and a prominent scapula, asymmetry of the flanks and asymmetry of the thoracic cage. The patient may also have rip humps.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="kyphosis">Kyphosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kyphosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Kyphosis is an exaggeration in the curvature of the thoracic spine. This may lead to a change in the volume of the thoracic space. It will, therefore, affect the functional lung capacities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="poliomyelitis">Poliomyelitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#poliomyelitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Poliomyelitis is another debilitating disease which, though a disease of the nervous system, may affect the muscular-skeletal system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lumbar-lordosis">Lumbar Lordosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lumbar-lordosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lumbar lordosis is an exaggeration in the curvature of the lumbar spine. This normally occurs during growth and development.</p>
<p>You will now learn about some of the disorders of bone metabolism, which include osteoporosis, osteomalacia and rickets.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osteoporosis">Osteoporosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteoporosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a disorder in which the rate of bone reshaping (resorption) is greater than the rate of formation. This results in a loss of organic matrix and mineral content. The bone then becomes brittle, fragile and fractures easily. This is a condition that is common among the elderly. It can also be seen in post-menopausal women, people with Cushing's syndrome and those who are on steroid treatment.</p>
<p>The manifestations of osteoporosis are pain and spontaneous fractures. In some cases, wedging and collapse of vertebrae causes loss of height. It may also lead to kyphosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="osteomalacia-and-rickets">Osteomalacia and Rickets<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteomalacia-and-rickets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These terms refer to the same process occurring at different ages. In both cases, there is a deficiency of vitamin D. If the deficiency occurs before fusion of the epiphyseal plates then the bones get deformed, but if fusion has already occurred, then the bones will bend easily. Rickets therefore occurs in children and osteomalacia in adults.</p>
<p>Both conditions are caused by mal-absorption syndromes, lack of exposure to sunlight and excess secretion of vitamin D. You can now reflect upon the effects of poor nutrition to bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-adult-with-osteoporosis-osteomalacia-and-rickets">Care of the Adult with Osteoporosis, Osteomalacia and Rickets<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-with-osteoporosis-osteomalacia-and-rickets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The prevention of osteoporosis focuses on adequate calcium intake and calcium supplementation. Some foods high in calcium content are whole and skim milk, spinach, cheese, dark green vegetables, and sardines. You may remember that we mentioned some of these earlier.</p>
<p>Oestrogen replacement therapy after menopause is used to prevent osteoporosis among post-menopausal women. Another useful management technique is calcitonin treatment, which acts by blocking the effects of the parathyroid hormone on bone resorption. The drug etidionate disodium also inhibits bone resorption. It is important to tell patients that weight bearing exercises are also useful in prevention of osteoporosis. Although loss of bone cannot be reversed totally, the use of oestrogen, exercise and calcium can prevent further loss.</p>
<p>You should strive to keep patients with osteoporosis ambulated to prevent further loss of bone substance as a result of immobility.</p>
<p>You should also ensure that we institute measures to avoid pathological fractures in patients with osteoporosis. Always include health education on the prevention of home accidents in your management. Those at risk should avoid walking on slippery floors, and should wear shoes with a firm sole.</p>
<p>The management of osteomalacia is directed towards correcting the underlying cause. Remember you learnt that this disorder is associated with vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D</p>
<p>should be supplemented and the patient will generally improve. Calcium and phosphorous intake may also be supplemented after proper investigation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bone-tumours">Bone Tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bone tumours constitute about 1% of all malignancies in the adult population. Sometimes tumours in the bones metastasise and cause complications in other organs. Bone tumours include osteomas, chondromas, fibromas, chondrosarcoma, osteosarcoma and multiple myeloma. The conditions associated with bone tumours are infections, pathological fractures and anaemia among others.</p>
<p>Generally the manifestations of bone cancer include bone pain that lasts over a week and unexplained swelling over a particular bone. Other manifestations include warm skin over the affected bones and prominent veins. Perhaps you have seen clients with bone cancer.</p>
<p>Bone tumours are rare in adults but if present, they rapidly metastasize and cause bone destruction. In addition, they lead to organ involvement. An example is multiple myeloma. This will involve the bone marrow and lead to anaemia. Chemotherapy is, therefore, used to suppress plasma cell growth in the bone marrow. Steroids are also given to these patients. However, both these management methods increase the patient's susceptibility to infection. Therefore, you need to practise good infection prevention and control. In osteoclastoma and sarcoma, chemotherapy, surgery and radiation may improve survival rates.</p>
<p>After assessment of a cancer patient, focus on achieving the following goals.</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensuring satisfactory pain relief</li>
<li>Enabling the patient to maintain preferred activities</li>
<li>Encouraging the patient to accept body image changes resulting from chemotherapy radiation and surgery</li>
<li>Decreasing the possibility of injury</li>
<li>Educating the patient on disease progression and prognosis</li>
</ul>
<p>You should also pay attention to pathological fractures, spinal cord compression and limb amputation. Pain relief is achieved by the use of strong analgesics. Counselling and patient education will enable the patient to choose the kind of activities to engage in. It will also assist patients to avoid injury.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bone-infections">Bone Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infections also affect the bones. Some infections are brought about by surgery to the</p>
<p>bone, while others are spread through fractures, abscesses and blood borne micro-organisms. One of these bone infections is called osteomyelitis.</p>
<p>In osteomyelitis, certain micro-organisms, mainly staphylococci, affect bone tissue. The infection can be either by direct or indirect invasion. The infection leads to pain on the affected area, abscess formation, fever and necrosis of the bone tissue. In your practice you may have seen that orthopaedic patients can complicate with osteomyelitis.</p>
<p>Vigorous antibiotic therapy is the treatment of choice for acute osteomyelitis. Some immobilisation of the affected part is necessary. The development of sepsis is common if metastasis of bacteria moves to other sites. Pathologic fractures may also occur due to weakened bone. Deformities of the affected extremities should not be overlooked. In such cases, preventive measures such as proper alignment and immobilisation are necessary.</p>
<p>Osteomyelitis can be chronic or acute. Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis includes surgical removal of the poorly vascularised tissue and dead bone. It also involves irrigating the area with antibiotics.</p>
<p>Generally the goals that we must strive to achieve in the management are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Pain and fever control</li>
<li>Preventing the transmission of the infection to other areas of the body</li>
<li>Decreased complications of bone fractures and deformities</li>
<li>Maintenance of a positive outlook and cooperation with the treatment plan</li>
</ul>
<p>Specific nursing activities include close monitoring of the patient, promotion of drainage, use of fluids, immobilisation, good nutrition to the patient, use of antibiotics, use of assistive devices such as crutches, minimising infection and patient education.</p>
<p>You will now learn about fractures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fractures">Fractures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fractures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A fracture is any break in the continuity of bone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-fractures">Classification of Fractures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-fractures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>They are classified according to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Location</li>
<li>Type</li>
<li>Direction or pattern of fracture line</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="location">Location<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#location" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Long bones can be described as having 3 parts; proximal, midshaft and distal. A fracture of the long bone is described in relation to its position in the bone.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 120 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-fracture">Types of Fracture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-fracture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is in relation to its communication to the environment, degree of break in continuity of the bone, character of fracture. For example an open fracture communicates with the environment because it penetrates the skin, while a closed fracture does not penetrate the skin. We also talk of the degree of break, e.g. green stick, partial or complete and character of fracture which is described as comminuted, impacted, segmental, etc. The pattern of fracture line can be described as transverse, spiral, oblique, etc.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bone-healing-process">Bone Healing Process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-healing-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>After a fracture, bone healing follows a number of stages:</p>
<ul>
<li>A haematoma forms between surrounding soft tissues.</li>
<li>Inflammatory process sets in with accumulation of macrophages. This takes about five days. The macrophages, phagocytose the haematoma. Growth of granulation tissue begins.</li>
<li>The osteoblasts secrete non-lamellar osteoid. Calcium is also absorbed which aids in hardening of bone to form callus.</li>
<li>Osteoclasts become active removing excess callus and opening up a medullary canal in callus. This may take up to one month.</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors enhancing bone healing:</p>
<ul>
<li>Adequate nutrition</li>
<li>Adequate blood supply</li>
<li>Absence of infection</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bone-healing-process">Bone Healing Process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-healing-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Factors hindering bone healing:</p>
<ul>
<li>Presence of infective organisms e.g. streptococci</li>
<li>Fat embolism in medullary canal</li>
<li>Excessive bone tissue fragments</li>
<li>Deficient blood supply</li>
<li>Continued mobility (lack of proper reduction and immobilisation)</li>
<li>Age - old age due to slowing</li>
<li>Nature of injury</li>
<li>Type of bone lost</li>
<li>Degree of immobilisation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-features">Clinical features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Pain at site of injury</li>
<li>Swelling due to haematoma formation</li>
<li>Loss of function due to pain and deformity</li>
<li>Deformity depending on force and muscle tissue surrounding muscles e.g. angulation, shortening of extremity</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is made from the history e.g. fall or trauma in road traffic accidents. An x-ray examination confirms diagnosis.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-c51aa655.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg"></p>
<p>A fracture dislocation break complicated by the joint.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-b5417dfb.jpeg" alt="img-10.jpeg"></p>
<p>An impacted fracture where the bone is broken and wedged into another break.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-11adf842.jpeg" alt="img-11.jpeg"></p>
<p>A green stick fracture where the bone is broken and bent out but securely hinged at one side.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-3ac48765.jpeg" alt="img-12.jpeg"></p>
<p>A closed fracture where there is no open wound.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-86dd4683.jpeg" alt="img-13.jpeg"></p>
<p>Bishops Computers

Bishops Computers</p>
<p>An open fracture where a wound in the skin communicates with the fracture.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-6bbff2af.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg"></p>
<p>An extracapsular fracture - the bone is broken outside of the joint.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-97edb7cf.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg"></p>
<p>An intracapsular fracture - the bone is broken inside the joint.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-07e2dcd9.jpeg" alt="img-16.jpeg"></p>
<p>Comminuted fracture where the bone has splintered into fragments</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-09de8f6d.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg"></p>
<p>A longitudinal fracture where the break runs parallel with the bone.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-ddd90380.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg"></p>
<p>A transverse fracture - the break runs across the bone.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-e248f175.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg"></p>
<p>An oblique fracture occurs when the break runs in a slanting direction across the bone.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-7755da63.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg"></p>
