<p>A spiral fracture is where the break coils around the bone.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-cf6afffb.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg"></p>
<p>A pathologic fracture occurs when the break is at the site of bone disease</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-49fdaef1.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg"></p>
<p>A depressed fracture occurs when a piece of the skull is broken off and driven inwards.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle-management-of-fractures">Principle Management of Fractures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-management-of-fractures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The emergency management of a fracture involves:</p>
<ul>
<li>Assessing the airway, breathing and circulation</li>
<li>Assessing any bleeding sites and controlling bleeding</li>
<li>Treatment of any life threatening injury</li>
<li>Immobilisation by use of splints</li>
<li>Applying cold compresses</li>
<li>Elevating the extremity</li>
<li>Minimising mobility</li>
<li>Monitoring the patient closely</li>
</ul>
<p>The principle management of fractures falls along 3 lines:</p>
<p>a) Fracture reduction
b) Immobilisation
c) Rehabilitation (restoration of function)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a-reduction">a) Reduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-reduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The aim is to replace the bone fragments to as near as normal anatomical position as possible.</p>
<p>Methods used are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Open reduction. This is a surgical method of bringing the fractured parts together.</li>
<li>Closed reduction. Here manipulation is used without viewing the fractures. An x-ray must be taken immediately after.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-immobilisation">b) Immobilisation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-immobilisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The aim is to prevent movement of injured parts already reduced by the above methods. It is accomplished through the use of:</p>
<ul>
<li>External devices e.g. splints, plaster casts, external fixation devices or traction.</li>
<li>Internal devices inserted during open reduction e.g. screws, nails, plates.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="traction">Traction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#traction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Traction involves a steady pull on a body part. This is a method of reduction and immobilisation used to maintain fractures apart but allowing sufficient contact for healing.</p>
<p>Traction may be either skin or skeletal. In skin traction the pull is transmitted to the skin on the fractured bone. In skeletal traction, the force is directly applied to the bone by use of pulls. In both, weights are used to maintain traction and the traction force must be maintained throughout the initial healing stage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indications">Indications:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>To reduce a fracture</li>
<li>Maintain alignment</li>
<li>Overcome muscle spasm</li>
<li>Correct deformities</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specific-care-for-patient-on-traction">Specific Care for Patient on Traction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-care-for-patient-on-traction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The care is similar to that of a patient on a cast and internal fixation. In addition, you should maintain continuous traction and avoid adding weight to the traction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="skin-care">Skin Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skin-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nurse the patient on sheepskin to avoid pressure sore formation and gluteus. Keep the skin clean around pin sites in skeletal traction to avoid infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plaster-casts">Plaster Casts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plaster-casts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a common external fixation device which is applied over skin.</p>
<p>The skin should be intact, clean and well</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>padded before a cast is applied to avoid risks of infection. Casts are molded over the affected body part after closed reduction has been done</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specific-care-for-a-person-in-a-cast">Specific Care for a Person in a Cast<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-care-for-a-person-in-a-cast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This should fall into a number of categories.</p>
<ol>
<li>Patient Education</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Before the application explain the procedure to the patient and the extent of the immobilisation.</li>
<li>After cast application explain the care of cast to the patient and when it will be removed.</li>
<li>Instruct patient not to insert sharp objects in to the cast to avoid injury in the skin.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Skin Care</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Inspect skin around the cast edges for redness or irritation.</li>
<li>After cast removal, skin should be washed thoroughly and oiled.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Mobilisation</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Weight bearing is at the discretion of the physician. The patient can ambulate on crutches.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="4">
<li>Positioning</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>After cast application, position limb elevated on a pillow to decrease oedema.</li>
<li>Observe limb for colour changes and sensation. If the patient experiences tingling sensations, the cast is too tight and should be removed.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="internal-fixation">Internal fixation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#internal-fixation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It has the advantage of allowing direct visualisation of fracture of the surrounding tissues. Its main disadvantage is that anaesthesia is required and there is the risk of infection if strict surgical asepsis is not maintained. Devices used for internal fixation include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Plates and nails</li>
<li>Intramedullary rods</li>
<li>Screws</li>
<li>Pins</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specific-care-for-a-person-with-an-internal-fixation-device">Specific Care for a Person with an Internal Fixation Device<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specific-care-for-a-person-with-an-internal-fixation-device" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Patient Education</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Explain the surgical procedure and general care expected post-operatively to the patient.</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Promoting Mobility</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Instruct and assist the patient on turning and transfer.</li>
<li>Assist the patient to use an appropriate ambulatory aid if the fracture is of a lower extremity.</li>
<li>Maintenance of immobilisation depends on whether traction or cast has been used.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-fixators">External Fixators<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-fixators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>External fixators are also used but applied under anaesthesia. They are indicated where there is extensive soft tissue and bone injury where an internal device may not be used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-fractures">Complications of Fractures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-fractures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Fat embolism</li>
<li>Deep vein thrombosis</li>
<li>Impaired fracture healing e.g. malunion, non union infection</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-joints-and-their-management">Disorders of Joints and their Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-joints-and-their-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="arthritis">Arthritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arthritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Arthritis is a descriptive term applied to more than 100 rheumatic diseases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="rheumatoid-arthritis">Rheumatoid Arthritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rheumatoid-arthritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Rheumatoid Arthritis is a systemic inflammatory diseases affecting synovial joints.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The disease begins in the synovial membrane within the joint. This leads to an inflammatory process. The inflammatory process is triggered by an unknown event that damages or irritates the joint tissues. Continued inflammation leads to thickening of the synovium especially where it joins the articular cartilage. At this point, fibrin develops into a granulation tissue known as pannus. This leads to adhesions between joint surfaces and fibrous or bony ankylosis. Pain occurs as a result of cartilage degeneration due to erosion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Early Signs</th><th>Late Signs</th><th>Other Signs</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Fatigue</td><td>Pallor</td><td>Increasing pain</td></tr><tr><td>Weight loss</td><td>Anaemia</td><td>Paraesthesia</td></tr><tr><td>Pain at rest and with movement</td><td>Joint deformities</td><td>Dislocation</td></tr><tr><td>Morning stiffness</td><td>Contractures</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Rheumatoid arthritis may also affect other body systems e.g. the heart.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 125 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is made from the history and presence of :</p>
<ul>
<li>Anaemia</li>
<li>Narrowing of the joint spaces seen on x-ray</li>
<li>Mild leukocytosis</li>
<li>Rheumatoid factor</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Early Signs</th><th>Late Signs</th><th>Other Signs</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Fatigue</td><td>Pallor</td><td>Increasing pain</td></tr><tr><td>Weight loss</td><td>Anaemia</td><td>Paraesthesia</td></tr><tr><td>Pain at rest and with movement</td><td>Joint deformities</td><td>Dislocation</td></tr><tr><td>Morning stiffness</td><td>Contractures</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Rheumatoid arthritis may also affect other body systems e.g. the heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is made from the history and presence of :</p>
<ul>
<li>Anaemia</li>
<li>Narrowing of the joint spaces seen on x-ray</li>
<li>Mild leukocytosis</li>
<li>Rheumatoid factor</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="assessment">Assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Inspection and palpation of the same joints on both sides of the body for asymmetry, skin color, size, shape, tenderness, swelling</li>
<li>Limitation of active joint movement</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-diagnosis">Nursing Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pain related to swelling of joint</li>
<li>Self-care deficit related to loss of muscle strength</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expected-outcomes">Expected Outcomes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expected-outcomes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Patient verbalises decreased pain</li>
<li>States factors that lead to fatigue and how to avoid them</li>
<li>Reports adequate sleep and rest</li>
<li>Demonstrates improved ability to perform self-care activities and participates to the fullest extent</li>
</ul>
<p>Rheumatoid Arthritis - Interventions</p>
<p>Think about how you might evaluate the following care?</p>
<p>These should include those that promote:</p>
<ol>
<li>Comfort</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Proper positioning of limb</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Administering of medications e.g. indocid 50-75mg tds naprosyn 100mg bd</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Providing heat or cold treatments on the affected joints according to what the patient says works best</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Encouraging the use of resting splints</p>
</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Independence</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Assist in activities of daily living as needed</li>
<li>Encourage use of supportive devices e.g. trapeze to move up the bed</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Reducing fatigue by for example, providing frequent rest periods. Instruct patient on how to conserve energy.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mobility and prevention of injury by:</p>
</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Assessing all joints for signs of inflammation and deformity</li>
<li>Avoiding positions that can lead to formation of contractures</li>
<li>Encouraging patient to wear shoes and not slippers for ambulation</li>
</ul>
<ol start="5">
<li>Patient education should include care in all the areas described above.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="degenerative-joint-disease-osteoarthritis">Degenerative Joint Disease (Osteoarthritis)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#degenerative-joint-disease-osteoarthritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A condition affecting one or more joints characterised by degeneration of joint tissue or a non-inflammatory condition of the joint characterised by degeneration of joint tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The onset is slow with erosion of articular cartilage, thickening of subchondral bone and formation of osteophytes or bone spurs. Normal articular cartilage is white, translucent and smooth in osteoarthritis. The area of the cartilage becomes soft and the surface becomes rough and cracks. Eventually the cartilage is destroyed and the underlying bone goes through a remodeling process. Osteophytes or bone spurs appear at the joint margin at the sites of attachment. These may break off and appear in the joints as joint mice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pain in affected joint (deep aching) which increases with weather changes or increased activity</li>
<li>Muscle spasms</li>
<li>Shortening ligaments</li>
<li>Joint deformity</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Based on evaluation and history</li>
<li>X-ray films show narrowing of joint space</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 126 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="post-operative-management">Post-operative Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-operative-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This includes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Proper positioning of the patient in bed to avoid hip dislocation. A wedge pillow maybe used between the limbs.</li>
<li>Vital signs observation which should be done four hourly to assess the patient's progress. Oxygen may be administered for the first six hours to improve perfusion. Other observations are of the incision site for bleeding and drainage if drain is in situ. If the drainage is minimal the drains should be removed 48 to 72 hours post operatively.</li>
<li>Pain management control should be maintained throughout the recovery period e.g. pethidine 75mgIV eight hourly and as needed followed by oral diclofenac100mg bd for 14-21 days.</li>
<li>Ambulation. The patient starts on passive exercises as soon as the pain is controlled. They should ambulate as soon as is possible to avoid complications e.g deep various thrombosis.</li>
<li>Nutrition. Depending on the type of anaesthesia used and patients condition they may be allowed to take oral sips six hours after surgery. If they had intravenous infusions running, these should be allowed to go through and the input and output chart should be maintained to monitor fluids. The patient should be allowed to feed on a well balanced diet soon after they can tolerate fluids.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="post-operative-management">Post-operative Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-operative-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This includes:</p>
<ol>
<li>Proper positioning of the patient in bed to avoid hip dislocation. A wedge pillow maybe used between the limbs.</li>
<li>Vital signs observation which should be done four hourly to assess the patient's progress. Oxygen may be administered for the first six hours to improve perfusion. Other observations are of the incision site for bleeding and drainage if drain is in situ. If the drainage is minimal the drains should be removed 48 to 72 hours post operatively.</li>
<li>Pain management control should be maintained throughout the recovery period e.g. pethidine 75mgIV eight hourly and as needed followed by oral diclofenac100mg bd for 14-21 days.</li>
<li>Ambulation. The patient starts on passive exercises as soon as the pain is controlled. They should ambulate as soon as is possible to avoid complications e.g deep various thrombosis.</li>
<li>Nutrition. Depending on the type of anaesthesia used and patients condition they may be allowed to take oral sips six hours after surgery. If they had intravenous infusions running, these should be allowed to go through and the input and output chart should be maintained to monitor fluids. The patient should be allowed to feed on a well balanced diet soon after they can tolerate fluids.</li>
</ol>
<p>You should have considered the following other cares:</p>
<ul>
<li>Elimination needs</li>
<li>Hygiene needs</li>
<li>Health message</li>
</ul>
<p>The health messages given should include among others that the patient should avoid squatting on a low toilet seat or to picking something from the floor to avoid dislocation of prosthesis.</p>
<p>Situations that might lead to dislocation include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Disorders affecting bones</li>
<li>Metabolic bone diseases</li>
<li>These affect the normal haemostatic functioning of bone e.g Paget's disease and osteoporosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="osteoporosis">Osteoporosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#osteoporosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Osteoporosis is a metabolic condition of the bone resulting in low bone mass.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="causes-include">Causes include<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Diabetes</li>
<li>Rheumatoid arthritis</li>
<li>Leukemia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In the normal bone forming process, bone remodelling occurs at the same pace as bone resorption. In osteoporosis, there is rapid bone loss. This leads to thinning of the lamellar with deformity and later collapse. The bone may easily fracture.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>History and clinical features</li>
<li>X-ray</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Acute onset back pain in low thoracic region cause vertebral fracture</li>
<li>Kyphosis (postural changes)</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 127 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prevention of the condition is through early administration of calcium supplements to encourage bone strengthening. Others include vitamin D, Fluoride. Give health messages about dangers of smoking and need to avoid it. Women approaching menopause may require assessment for suitability of hormone replacement therapy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-adult-with-joint-disorders">Care of the Adult with Joint Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-with-joint-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Patients with osteoarthritis have degeneration of articular cartilage in the joints. Management involves relief of discomfort and protection of the joints from undue strain. The relief of pain can be achieved by resting the involved joints, advising the patient to avoid activities that precipitate pain, use of heat, analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs, for example, steroids. The use of correct body mechanics, assistive devices and the avoidance of heavy weight bearing is also helpful. The joints should be restored to their maximal extent through the use of progressive range of motion exercises, avoiding flexion deformities and the utilisation of corrective and graded exercises.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amputation">Amputation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amputation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amputation is often necessary as a result of:</p>
<ul>
<li>Progressive peripheral vascular disease</li>
<li>Severe crash injuries</li>
<li>Severe burns</li>
<li>Severe congenital deformities or malignant tumours</li>
</ul>
<p>The amputation is performed at the point furthest from the torso that will heal well. The ankles, slightly below knee, and slightly above knee are some of the common points of amputation. Pre-operatively, you assist the patient to undergo investigations and support them psychologically. Always give good nutrition, correct Hb, teach the patient how to use assistive devices such as crutches and involve them in exercise programmes.</p>
<p>Post-operatively, the patient requires good wound drainage as well as proper wound dressing and antibiotics to decrease sepsis. Immediately after surgery, the patient should also be closely monitored for haemorrhages, vital signs fluctuations and wound drainage. Physiotherapy is utilised to prevent the development of contractures. Pain management is an important aspect. Phantom pain often occurs as a result of the missing limb and psychotherapy is recommended.</p>
<p>We talk of phantom pain when a patient reports pain in an area distal to a point of amputation. For example, a patient may report pain on missing toes.</p>
<p>Care of the skin at the stump area, muscle strengthening and balancing exercise, in addition to education on use of prostheses are all important aspects in the care of the patient with amputation. Always remember that rehabilitation of the patient with amputation is an important consideration of nursing. The graphic below illustrates the common points of amputation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gout">Gout<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gout" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When there is accumulation of products of purine metabolism, especially uric acid in the body, they may crystallise in the joints causing joint inflammation and destruction. The first symptoms of gout are typically joint pain that starts with distal joints and swelling. The disease is aggravated by infections, cold weather and consumption of meals rich in purines.</p>
<p>The management of gout is mainly preventive. Once an individual starts presenting with symptoms, they need to be advised on how to avoid acute gout attacks. Anti-gout medication comes in two forms. The first is pain-controlling medication such as indocid, diclofenac and aspirin at a high dose. The second is medication that acts to decrease the production of uric acid e.g. allopurinol. The patient must be advised to avoid over indulgence on roast meat, organ meat (such as liver), baked chicken and sardines, as these are high in purines. They should also drink lots of fluids to facilitate the secretion of uric acid through the kidneys.</p>
<p>The next topic you will learn concerns disorders of muscle and ligaments and their management.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-skeletal-muscles-and-their-management">Disorders of the Skeletal Muscles and their Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-skeletal-muscles-and-their-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Skeletal muscles make up about half of the mean body weight of individuals. They have various characteristics as you have studied earlier. They undertake the function of causing movement of various body parts. If muscles are not put to use for reasons such as pain, lack of exercise or disease, they may atrophy. Atrophy is a decrease in the number and size of muscle fibres. This is one of the reasons that physical therapists continually work with bedridden patients, in an effort to prevent disuse atrophy.</p>
<p>Muscles can get inflamed. This is called myositis. When bone forms within the muscle due to infiltration of bone cells, the condition is referred to as ossifying myositis. This is normally due to repeated injury accompanied by a haemorrhage into a muscle compartment.</p>
<p>Inflammation of muscles can be brought about by parasites and infections, for example, the larvae of the Trichinella spiralis, commonly found in muscles that are rich in a substance called cytochrome. These are muscles that work hard to produce energy. Autoimmune responses can also result in muscle inflammation.</p>
<p>The manifestations of inflammation of muscle include pain, swelling, easy fatigability and sometimes paralysis.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-221d48de.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neoplasms-of-muscles">Neoplasms of Muscles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neoplasms-of-muscles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are over 500 muscles in the human body. Conditions affecting the muscles are rare. Primary tumours of muscles can either be malignant or benign. These are mainly rhabdomyomas and rhabdomyosarcomas. Secondary tumours are a result of metastases from other organs of the body. These are very rare. The manifestations of secondary muscle tumours are pressure symptoms, decreased blood supply to the affected area, pain and infection. Keep in mind that there are general symptoms of neoplasms for almost all tumours and they include anaemia, nausea and anorexia.</p>
<p>Before concluding on the disorders of bones and skeletal muscles we should not forget to mention that muscles can be over-stimulated and go into spasms, which are often extremely painful and may render the use of the involved limb difficult. This could be a result of neurological disease and can lead to lower back pain, and muscle pull.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-adults-with-muscle-and-ligament-disorders">Care of Adults with Muscle and Ligament Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-adults-with-muscle-and-ligament-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You have learnt about several soft tissue injuries, including sprains, strains, dislocations and subluxation. These are abnormalities affecting the articular points. The main goals of management of sprains and strains are to return the limb to normal function and to ensure satisfactory pain relief and comfort.</p>
<p>You must, therefore, undertake the following actions while managing patients with these problems:</p>
<ul>
<li>Assess for neurological and circulatory status</li>
<li>Elevate the involved limb</li>
<li>Apply a compression bandage, except in cases of dislocation</li>
<li>Immobilise the affected limb</li>
<li>Eliminate weight bearing on the affected extremity</li>
<li>Administer analgesics to control the pain</li>
</ul>
<p>Specialised techniques may also be employed by physiotherapists to assist the patient in achieving the two goals that have just been listed.</p>
<p>Focusing on pain relief, realignment of articular surfaces and promoting joint function will treat dislocation and sub-luxation. Anti-inflammatory drugs, immobilization, and regulated rehabilitation are also utilised in the management of sub-luxation and dislocation. Muscle spasms are managed by a combination of drugs, physical therapy or both.</p>
<p>One example is Valium, which has some muscle relaxant activity and is commonly employed in our setup.</p>
<p>Tumours involving muscles can be treated with radiation, chemotherapy, surgery or a combination of these. These are treatment methods that are generally employed in the management of all cancers.</p>
<p>Now you will learn about back pain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="low-back-pain">Low Back Pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#low-back-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Low back pain is a major musculoskeletal disorder that is commonly encountered. It is caused by several factors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-lower-back-pain">Causes of Lower Back Pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-lower-back-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Here are some causes of lower back pain:</p>
<ul>
<li>Lumbo-sacral strain</li>
<li>Unstable ligaments</li>
<li>Weak muscles</li>
<li>Osteoarthritis of the spine</li>
<li>Inter-vertebral disc problems</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Osteoporosis in the elderly patients</li>
</ul>
<p>You should take down a good personal history and perform a thorough physical examination.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatment-of-lower-back-pain">Treatment of Lower Back Pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-lower-back-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Here are some treatments used for lower back pain:</p>
<ul>
<li>Rest the patient on a firm mattress, in the modified supine position with slight flexion so as to relieve the pain</li>
<li>Heat and appropriate medication for pain relief are important for the patient with back pain</li>
<li>To promote additional lumbar flexion, pelvic traction may be prescribed</li>
<li>Drug therapy</li>
<li>Exercise programmes</li>
<li>Encourage proper body mechanics and posture especially during strenuous exercise</li>
<li>Initiate physical therapy sessions</li>
</ul>
<p>Drugs are used for muscle relaxation, whereas electrical nerve stimulation and use of wide leather belts promote comfort.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-3-communication-and-coordination">SECTION 3: COMMUNICATION AND COORDINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-3-communication-and-coordination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Body systems do not work in isolation - their functions are interrelated and integrated. The coordination of all these functions is left to the nervous and the endocrine systems.</p>
<p>The endocrine system works through the use of special messengers, known as hormones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<ul>

<p>Describe the disorders of the nervous system and their management</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neurons">Neurons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neurons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-nervous-system-the-structure">The Nervous System - The Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-nervous-system-the-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The nervous system is divided into two parts: the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system.</p>
<p>The central nervous system consists of the brain and spinal cord while the peripheral nervous system consists of the cranial nerves, spinal nerves and autonomic nervous system.</p>
<p>The neurons are the functional cells of the nervous system.</p>
<p>A neuron consists of a nerve cell/body, an axon and a dendrite. When they are grouped together outside the central nervous system, they are called a ganglion. Neurons are specialised cells, which enable the transmission of information in the form of nerve impulses.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-36c777f4.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg"></p>
<p>Neurons can be divided into two groups. The first group takes messages from receptor end organs into the Central Nervous System (CNS). These are sensory or afferent nerves. The second group takes messages away from the CNS to the effector organs. These are known as motor or efferent nerves.</p>
<p>More than one neuron may be involved in the process of relaying information. In such cases, the multiple neurons connect with each other, at a point of connection called a synapse. At the synapse there are chemical transmitters, or neurotransmitters, which are involved in the transmission of messages. Two examples of</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>neuro-transmitters which you may have heard of, are Acetylcholine and Noradrenaline.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-brain-spinal-cord-and-nerves">The Brain, Spinal Cord and Nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-brain-spinal-cord-and-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You will have heard of the central nervous system. This term refers to the brain and the spinal cord. Membranes called meninges cover the brain and spinal cord. Within the cranium, the meninges are found between the skull and brain. In the vertebral column they are found between the vertebrae and the spinal cord. The dura mater and the arachnoid mater are</p>
<p>separated by a potential space - the subdural space.</p>
<p>The three membranes, starting from the outermost are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Dura Mater</li>
<li>Arachnoid Mater</li>
<li>Pia Mater</li>
</ul>
<p>There are two spaces between the three membranes. The space between the arachnoid and pia mater is the sub-arachnoid space and it contains cerebrospinal fluid. In your practice, you have seen patients having cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) removed for laboratory study.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-e2cfcbce.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-5efec315.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-flow-of-the-cerebrospinal-fluid">The Flow of the Cerebrospinal Fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-flow-of-the-cerebrospinal-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-b1992972.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg"></p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-brain">The Brain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-brain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The brain consists of the following parts:</p>
<p>The <strong>cerebellum</strong> undertakes coordination of voluntary muscle movement. Posture and balance are also controlled by the same part of the brain. Finally, the reticular formation found in the core of the brainstem performs the functions of coordination of skeletal muscle and maintaining balance. It also coordinates activity of the autonomic nervous system and performs the function of selective awareness. When you want to continue reading, while the radio is playing, the process that enables this dual activity is referred to as selective awareness.</p>
<p>The <strong>medulla oblongata</strong> comprises certain vital centres. These are the respiratory, cardiac, vasomotor and reflex centres of vomiting, coughing, sneezing and swallowing. As these vital centres suggest by their names, they control the functions mentioned. Temperature regulation is done by the hypothalamus.</p>
<p>The <strong>pons</strong> forms a bridge between the two cerebral hemispheres and other parts of the brain</p>
<p>The other part of the brain is the <strong>midbrain</strong>. It is involved in relaying ascending and descending nerve fibres</p>
<p>The <strong>cerebrum</strong> is the largest area and its cortex has many furrows. One of the big furrows divides the cerebrum into right and left hemispheres. These are further divided into lobes, which are named according to the bones of the cranium under which they lie.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="can-you-remember-the-bones-of-the-cranium">Can you remember the bones of the cranium?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#can-you-remember-the-bones-of-the-cranium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The lobes of the brain named after the cranial bones are the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes. The cerebrum is associated with mental activity, for example, memory and intelligence, sensory, initiation and control of voluntary movement. This part of the brain (cerebrum) can further be subdivided into sections according to their specific function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-spinal-cord">The Spinal Cord<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-spinal-cord" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The spinal cord is part of the central nervous system, which we have already discussed. It is the link between the brain and the rest of the body. The spinal cord is divided into two parts: the anterior median fissure and the posterior median septum.</p>
<p>The spinal cord is composed of grey matter at the centre and white matter on the outside. The grey matter has cells of the sensory nerves, the connector nerves and of the lower motor neurons.</p>
<p>White matter is arranged in tracts that may be sensory or motor. In the spinal cord, neurons transmit impulses to and from the peripheral. In the grey matter of the spinal cord, between the cells of the anterior and posterior horns, are small connector neurons which transmit an impulse straight from the skin to muscles. For example, when you touch a hot bowl of soup, a message is relayed to the spinal cord for you to withdraw your hand quickly. This is referred to as the reflex action.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-c28644d9.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg">
Simple Reflex Arc</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-aa7ad864.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg"></p>
<p>The CNS comprises several nerves that are involved in the relaying of messages, which you will now examine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peripheral-nerves">Peripheral Nerves<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peripheral-nerves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are 31 pairs of spinal nerves and 12 pairs of cranial nerves. The 31 pairs are distributed as eight cervical, twelve thoracic, five lumbar, five sacral and one coccygeal. Each of these nerves supplies a particular area of the body. The illustration opposite outlines the distribution and origins of nerves.</p>
<p>The 12 cranial nerves are numbered from one to twelve.</p>
<ol>
<li>Olfactory</li>
<li>Optic</li>
<li>Occulomotor</li>
<li>Trochlea</li>
<li>Trigeminal</li>
<li>Abducent</li>
<li>Facial</li>
<li>Vestibulocochlea</li>
<li>Glossopharyngeal</li>
<li>Vagus</li>
<li>Accessory</li>
<li>Hypoglossal</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-a4cdb472.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="autonomic-nervous-system">Autonomic Nervous System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autonomic-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The autonomic nervous system supplies the involuntary muscle tissue of the body. It controls the movements of the internal organs and the secretion of glands. The autonomic nerve cells are situated in the brain stem and spinal cord.</p>
<p>The parasympathetic and sympathetic nervous system have opposing effects on the body. They both send weak impulses to the organs and glands maintaining normal activity. In stressful situations the sympathetic impulses become stronger and the organs and glands react to the situation. The parasympathetic nervous system will take over when the stressful situation has passed and the functions of the organs return to normal. Some of the activities controlled by this system include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The rate and force of the heart beat</li>
<li>Vasodilatation</li>
<li>Vasoconstriction</li>
<li>Secretions of the glands, for example, in the alimentary tract and sweat glands</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Some of the organs and the systems controlled by the autonomic nervous system are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cardiovascular system</li>
<li>Eye</li>
<li>Skin</li>
<li>Digestive system</li>
<li>Respiratory system</li>
<li>Urinary system</li>
<li>Genitalia</li>
</ul>
<p>Read more about the nervous system. As a primary reference book, Ross and Wilson, 9th edition, pp. 141-175 is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-are-the-functions-of-the-cerebrospinal-fluid">What are the functions of the cerebrospinal fluid?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-are-the-functions-of-the-cerebrospinal-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You should have included some of the following functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>It is involved in the exchange of substances, for example, nutrients between the CSF and the nerve cells.</li>
<li>It keeps the brain and spinal cord moist.</li>
<li>It is a shock absorber for the brain, spinal cord and nerves.</li>
<li>It supports the brain and spinal cord and protects them.</li>
<li>It maintains pressure around the delicate structures in a uniform manner.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-brain-and-spinal-cord">Disorders of the Brain and Spinal Cord<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-brain-and-spinal-cord" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="increased-intracranial-pressure">Increased Intracranial Pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#increased-intracranial-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>One of the most common consequences of traumatic and non-traumatic lesions in the brain is increased intracranial pressure.</p>
<p>The brain is protected within a rigid bony structure, the cranium. The cranium encloses:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>The brain</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cerebral blood vessels and blood</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF)</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>An increase in any of these three lead to an increase to the intracranial pressure. Increased ICP is a life threatening situation. When pressure increases, arterial supply is affected and the resultant hypoxia causes cerebral oedema which aggravates the problem.</p>
<p>Causes of increased intracranial pressure include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cerebral oedema</li>
<li>Hydrocephalus or obstruction of the flow of the CSF</li>
<li>Space occupying lesions e.g. haematoma, tumours, abscesses</li>
</ul>
<p>Increased intracranial pressure manifests with severe headaches, projectile vomiting and pupil oedema. The brainstem may be compressed, leading to loss of consciousness, respiratory arrest and even death. Raised intracranial pressure, by reflex, slows the heart rate because it also affects the cardiac centre. The heart rate and blood pressure should, therefore, be closely monitored.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-patient-with-increased-intracranial-pressure">Care of the Patient with Increased Intracranial Pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-patient-with-increased-intracranial-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The goal of management of a patient with increased intracranial pressure is to identify and treat the underlying cause and support brain function. Caring for the patient with increased intracranial pressure involves patient assessment through the use of the Glasgow Coma Scale as well as general treatment.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Glasgow Coma Scale For Adult / Child &amp; Infant</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Child/Adult</td><td>Infant</td><td>Score</td></tr><tr><td>Eyes</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Opens eyes spontaneously</td><td>Opens eyes spontaneously</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>Opens eyes to speech</td><td>Opens eyes to speech</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>Opens eyes to pain</td><td>Opens eyes to pain</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>No response</td><td>No response</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td>Verbal</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Oriented</td><td>Coos and babbles</td><td>5</td></tr><tr><td>Confused</td><td>Irritable cry</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>Inappropriate</td><td>Cries to pain</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>Non specific sounds</td><td>Moans to pain</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>No response</td><td>No response</td><td>1</td></tr></tbody></table>
