<table><thead><tr><th>Motor</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Obeys commands</td><td>Spontaneous movements</td><td>5</td></tr><tr><td>Localizes pain</td><td>Withdraws to touch/pain</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>Flexion</td><td>Flexion (decorticate)</td><td>3</td></tr><tr><td>Extension</td><td>Extension (decerebrate)</td><td>2</td></tr><tr><td>No response</td><td>No response</td><td>1</td></tr><tr><td><strong>Total Score:</strong></td><td></td><td><strong>3-14</strong></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Assess for verbal response, pupillary response, reflexes, motor and sensory input. General management involves maintaining a neurological observation chart and administering osmotic diuretics such as IV mannitol.</p>
<p>You may use an indwelling catheter and maintain a strict input and output chart. Control of temperature and observation of vital signs are very important as well as preparation for surgery if the patient's condition deteriorates.</p>
<p>Changes in vital signs are caused by increasing pressure on the thalamus, hypothalamus, pons and medulla. Other clinical manifestations include decrease in motor function and changes in the dilatation and reaction of the pupil of the eye.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="traumatic-lesions-of-the-central-nervous-system">Traumatic Lesions of the Central Nervous System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#traumatic-lesions-of-the-central-nervous-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Injuries can affect the functioning of the central nervous system. Minor injuries can cause a little haemorrhage and inflammatory oedema. Major injuries can cause tears in the meninges and even death. Occasionally, bleeding can occur and form a subdural haematoma. This may manifest with the same signs and symptoms as raised intracranial pressure.</p>
<p>An extradural haemorrhage may occur if one of the main arteries in the brain is ruptured. This process may be accompanied by a fracture of the skull bones. The patient loses consciousness and as time passes, there is increased intracranial pressure, which may eventually result in a coma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="head-injuries">Head Injuries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#head-injuries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> A head injury is any trauma to the scalp, skull or brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-head-injuries">Types of Head Injuries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-head-injuries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include scalp lacerations, skull fractures and brain injuries. Brain injuries are categorised as being minor or major. Concussion is considered a minor brain injury. The patient may not lose total consciousness with this injury. Major brain injuries include contusions and lacerations.</p>
<p>Clinical features will depend on the type of injury present. Diagnostic procedures include x-rays, CT scan, MRI.</p>
<p>The patient who has a head injury requires immediate management at the casualty department and ongoing review and care afterwards. Immediately after receiving the patient, you must maintain an open airway, and ensure they have adequate breathing and circulation. This is because, as you have already learnt, cerebral hypoxia can lead to brain oedema and further damage the brain.</p>
<p>You must determine the baseline condition of the patient by assessing responsiveness, presence of headache, vomiting or double vision. You should also evaluate pupil size, blood pressure, pulse and respiration.</p>
<p>It is important to assess motion and strength of extremities and consider injuries to other organs. An accurate personal history and physical assessment are always paramount. You may start to administer anti-seizure medication and fluids depending on the assessment.</p>
<p>Later on, support of the airway, close observation, fluid and electrolyte balance correction and control of temperature are instituted. Medication to decrease cerebral oedema such as osmotic diuretics, for example, IV mannitol, anti-seizure medication, for instance, epanutin should be administered. Patient support and restraint will also contribute to improvement of the patient.</p>
<p>Always remember that preventing complications is part of the care of your patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-of-head-injury">Complications of Head Injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-of-head-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Unconsciousness</li>
<li>Loss of corneal reflex</li>
<li>Hypothermia</li>
<li>Problems related to motor and sensory deficits</li>
<li>Seizures</li>
<li>Behavioural disorders</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers

Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-unconscious-patient">The Unconscious Patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-unconscious-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> Uconsciousness is an abnormal state in which the patient is unaware of self or environment. Unconsciousness is a manifestation of a large number of pathophysiologic processes including trauma, metabolic disturbances, mass lesions and infections.</p>
<p>The unconscious patient should be nursed in the semi-prone position. The airway should be opened by the use of an oral airway device or the insertion of an endo-tracheal tube. Oxygen should be administered and secretions minimised through suction. Assess the patient's level of consciousness and make a record of the same. Evaluate vital signs half hourly and maintain fluid and electrolyte balances strictly. You should manage restlessness and keep the patient clean, dry and free of pressure sores.</p>
<p>The extremities should be put through a range of motion exercises. This promotes blood supply to various parts. Catheterisation and regular turning are also part of care for the unconscious patient. You should catheterise the patient to avoid wetting, which predisposes them to pressure ulcers. It will also enable you to closely monitor the intake and output. Protection from seizures, complications (for example infection), aspiration, obstruction of the airway, and corneal irritation should all be part of the care plan.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="non-traumatic-cerebro-vascular-disorders-stroke-cerebrovascular-accident">Non-Traumatic Cerebro-Vascular Disorders Stroke (Cerebrovascular Accident)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-traumatic-cerebro-vascular-disorders-stroke-cerebrovascular-accident" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> This is a condition in which neurologic deficits occur as a result of decreased blood flow to a focal (localised) area of brain tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes">Causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cerebrovascular accidents result when there is inadequate supply of blood to the brain (cerebral ischeamia) or cerebral hemorrhage within the brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-stroke-cva">Types of stroke (CVA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-stroke-cva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are three types:</p>
<ul>
<li>Thrombotic</li>
<li>Embolic</li>
<li>Haemorrhagic</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-traumatic-cerebro-vascular-disorders">Non-Traumatic Cerebro-Vascular Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-traumatic-cerebro-vascular-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most common types of ischemic stroke are thrombotic and embolic. Haemorrhagic strokes are generally the result of spontaneous bleeding into the brain tissue itself or the subarachnoid space or ventricles.</p>
<p>The most common cause of haemorrhagic stroke is a ruptured cerebral aneurysm. This is a saccular outpouching of a cerebral artery that occurs at the site of weakness in the vessel wall. The weakness may be the result of atherosclerosis, a congenital defect, trauma to the head, aging or hypertension.</p>
<p>When cerebral haemorrhage occurs, patients loose consciousness, progressing to coma and even death. This condition is common in people aged over 50 years of age.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-manifestations">Clinical Manifestations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-manifestations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The warning signs of stroke include temporary blindness in one eye, hemiplegia and defects in speech and confusion.</p>
<p>In haemorrhage, thrombosis and embolism within the brain, the manifestations depend on the area of the brain affected.</p>
<p>Normally, in the case of a severe stroke, consciousness is lost but is eventually regained. Speech may also be affected but later recovers. Loss of voluntary movement on the side of the body opposite to the side of the brain affected results in a condition referred to as hemiplegia.</p>
<p>Patients affected by this condition need intensive care, which shall be covered in the third section. The care of the patient with a non-traumatic lesion may take several forms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-non-traumatic-lesion-and-cerebro-vascular-accident">Management of Non-Traumatic Lesion and Cerebro-Vascular Accident<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-non-traumatic-lesion-and-cerebro-vascular-accident" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Disorders affecting blood supply to the brain may lead to quick loss of brain function. You will now look at the care of patients who have cerebro-vascular accidents, including strokes, transient ischemic attacks and emboli.</p>
<p>In the acute phase of stroke, you must carry out an assessment, ensure adequate cerebral perfusion pressure and reorient the patient when they regain consciousness. The principles of nursing care for an unconscious patient will apply.</p>
<p>You have already learnt about these. In the rehabilitative phase, the goals are to prevent deformities, retrain the affected limbs and help the patient gain independence in personal hygiene, and other activities of daily living. To do this, good positioning and physical therapy are necessary. Patient and family education are required to achieve the results quickly. The patient with cerebral haemorrhage requires bed rest, treatment of headache, antihypertensive drugs and reduction of cerebral oedema. They should also be prepared for surgery and rehabilitation afterwards just like the patient with head injuries.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 136 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management-of-a-patient-undergoing-intracranial-surgery">Management of a Patient Undergoing Intracranial Surgery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-a-patient-undergoing-intracranial-surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Indications of intracranial surgery include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Brain tumour</li>
<li>Vascular abnormalities such as aneurysms</li>
<li>Cranio cerebral trauma</li>
</ul>
<p>Depending on the location of the pathologic condition a craniotomy may be done at the frontal, temporal, parietal, occipital or a combination of any of these.</p>
<p>Pre-operatively you should assist the patient while they are undergoing diagnostic tests. You can do this by answering questions from the patient and relatives.</p>
<p>Evaluate the patient's condition and prepare them for surgery by shaving the head, giving enema, administering pre-medication as ordered and informing the patient on what to expect after surgery. The patient may need to know about the various operations, drainage, what they can and cannot do and so on. Pre-operative teaching is important in allaying the fears of the patient and the family and also in preparing them for post operative period.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="what-are-some-of-the-intracranial-surgical-operations-that-can-be-performed-in-kenya">What are some of the intracranial surgical operations that can be performed in Kenya?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-are-some-of-the-intracranial-surgical-operations-that-can-be-performed-in-kenya" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>One of the most common intracranial operations performed in Kenya is craniotomy to remove tumours, relieve pressure and evacuate blood clots.</p>
<p>Post-operatively, you must establish proper respiratory exchange, assess the patient's level of consciousness, evaluate for signs and symptoms of increasing intracranial pressure and control cerebral oedema. Steroids and osmotic diuretics will decrease cerebral oedema. Analgesics, changing the patient's position, an in-dwelling catheter and close observation are some of the measures that are put in place.</p>
<p>Always make sure you observe for drainage, which could be leaking cerebrospinal fluid, and for complications of intracranial haemorrhage such as post-operative meningitis, wound infections, pulmonary complications and post-traumatic epilepsy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="brain-tumours">Brain Tumours<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#brain-tumours" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Tumours of the brain may be primary, arising from tissues within the brain or secondary, resulting from a metastasis from a malignant tumour elsewhere in the body.</p>
<p>The clinical features result from the local destructive effects of the tumour, the resulting accumulation of metabolites, displacement of the structures, the obstruction of CSF flow, effects of oedema and increased ICP on cerebral functions.</p>
<p>The management of the patient with a brain tumour involves total or partial removal of the tumour and decompression, radiation and chemotherapy. For surgery, the principles of care of a patient undergoing intracranial surgery will apply.</p>
<p>A patient on radiation requires steroids, close observation and education. Generally, principles applied in the care of patients with cancer will also apply. If a patient is on steroid therapy, they may be predisposed to infections. Always be observant for potential infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infections-affecting-the-neurological-system">Infections Affecting the Neurological System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infections-affecting-the-neurological-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Two infections that affect the neurological system are meningitis and encephalitis.</p>
<p><strong>Meningitis</strong> is an acute inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. The infection may spread and cause suppuration in the brain. Infections can localise in the menengis resulting in Meningitis. They may also spread and cause suppuration in the brain. This could lead to a cerebral abscess. The mode of spread of infections is normally two-fold. The infecting micro-organisms may be blood borne, or they may get to the brain via local spread, that is, if there is communication with brain substance after trauma, therapeutic devices, for example, shunts or surgery. The local spread is a result of infection in the ear or fractures of the skull bones.</p>
<p>The micro-organisms commonly involved</p>
<p><strong>Encephalitis</strong> is the inflammation of the brain substance. It can be caused by trauma and infection. The infection is usually due to bacterial, viral and fungal micro-organisms.</p>
<p>Patients with these infections will present with fever, severe headache, unconsciousness and convulsions. Stiffness of the neck, paralysis of cranial nerves and hemiplegia may also occur.</p>
<p>Patients can go into coma and the risk of death is substantial. Have you nursed any patients with these infections? What clinical picture do they present with?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-management-of-infections-of-the-neurological-system-involves">The management of infections of the neurological system involves:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-management-of-infections-of-the-neurological-system-involves" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Investigations including lumbar puncture to examine the cerebrospinal fluid.</li>
<li>Use of intravenous anti bacterial drugs for meningococcal meningitis (or the</li>
</ul>
<p>most effective drug or those specific to the infective organisms).</p>
<ul>
<li>Anti viral medications for aseptic meningitis, for instance, Zovirax.</li>
<li>Anti fungal medication for cryptococcal meningitis.</li>
<li>Anti pyretic and analgesic medications are necessary.</li>
<li>Anti convulsant drugs may be prescribed to prevent or control seizure activity.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nursing-management-includes">Nursing management includes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-management-includes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Assessment of the vital signs and neurological evaluations two to four hourly.</li>
<li>The patient should be assisted to a position of comfort.</li>
<li>Fluid and electrolyte status is maintained through intravenous fluid placement until the patient is able to resume oral intake.</li>
<li>Supportive care is necessary to prevent complications related to prolonged bed rest. Activity should be gradually increased as tolerated, but adequate bed rest and sleep should be encouraged.</li>
<li>In most cases, meningitis does not require isolation with the EXCEPTION of meningococcal meningitis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-include">Complications include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Dementia</li>
<li>Seizures</li>
<li>Deafness</li>
<li>Hemiplegia</li>
<li>Hydrocephalus</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="demyelinating-disorder-metabolic-disorders-and-vitamin-deficiencies">Demyelinating Disorder, Metabolic Disorders and Vitamin Deficiencies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#demyelinating-disorder-metabolic-disorders-and-vitamin-deficiencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>From our study of the normal structure of the nervous system, can you remember the myelin sheath? This is the covering of the nerve axon. When it is damaged, the conduction of nerve impulses is impaired. Certain disorders can result in impaired formation of the myelin sheath or damage to it (demyelination). One such disorder is multiple sclerosis. Its cause is not well understood. Another cause of demyelination is encephalitis.</p>
<p>Multiple sclerosis is a chronic neurological disease characterised by multiple patchy demyelination of white matter in the central nervous system. Multiple sclerosis is chronic and manifests with impaired vision, paralysis, bladder dysfunction and emotional instability.</p>
<p>These manifestations can occur as acute episodes interspersed with recovery periods. This type of disorder requires patients to receive support and understanding from you, the nurse, and their families as part of the management. Considering the impaired vision and mobility, the environment should be structured in such a way that accidents are avoided.</p>
<p>Medical management will include drugs to control spasticity such as diazepam in combination with physiotherapy. For fatigue, patients may be treated with drugs such as Amantadine. Steroids may be administered for optic neuritis. Anti depressants and counselling is important where patient presents with psychological disturbances.</p>
<p>Vitamin deficiencies sometimes result in serious consequences to the nervous system. The most common deficiencies affecting the nervous system are vitamin B1 and B12 deficiencies. Vitamin B1 deficiency causes unsteadiness, double vision, and mental impairment. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes degeneration of the spinal cord. The deficiencies can occur because of alcoholism, deficiencies in the diet or malabsorption.</p>
<p>Metabolic disorders in the brain could result from hepatic encephalopathy, alcoholism and hypoglycemia. Poisoning of the brain substance can occur as result of direct toxins in substances consumed, drugs or as a result of toxins liberated through the metabolic process in the body, e.g. bilirubin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-adult-with-multiple-sclerosis-vitamin-deficiencies-and-metabolic-disorders">Care of the Adult with Multiple Sclerosis, Vitamin Deficiencies and Metabolic Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-with-multiple-sclerosis-vitamin-deficiencies-and-metabolic-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All patients initially require a thorough assessment. This provides the data for planning and eventually for evaluation. The main goal of care is to ensure the patient with multiple sclerosis should be treated for muscle spasticity through exercises, avoidance of muscle fatigue, prevention of muscle contractures, walking and the use of braces and crutches.</p>
<p>You should also avoid skin pressure and immobility. This decreases the possibility of pressure ulcers. Position change, avoidance of trauma, and giving careful attention to pressure areas are very important.</p>
<p>Assist the patient to overcome inability to coordinate by regularly practising walking techniques and support. If they have bladder dysfunction, catheterise and maintain adequate fluid intake. Bowel training for bowel incontinence is a good practice. For optic and</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>speech problems, adequate attention should be given to training and use of assistive devices. Most importantly, attention to activities of daily living and patient education can help patients lead better quality lives.</p>
<p>Vitamin deficiencies and degenerative disorders of the nerves that result in nerve damage will also require the same care as is given to the patient with multiple sclerosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="degenerative-disorders">Degenerative Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#degenerative-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All patients with degenerative diseases require a structured and predictable environment. This means that you should give education to their caretakers to organise their environment in such a way that home accidents are prevented. They should always have somebody present to help them and should be oriented to their surroundings regularly.</p>
<p>Two degenerative disorders are Alzheimer's disease and Huntington's Chorea</p>
<p>Degeneration of the neurons occurs in certain individuals due to certain disorders. In Alzheimer's disease there is dementia, that is, degeneration of intellectual ability, loss of short-term memory and loss of physical ability. The cause of Alzheimer's disease is not known.</p>
<p>Senile dementia affects elderly individuals and also results in the degeneration of intellectual ability. In Huntington's chorea, patients manifest with unusual grimacing and uncontrolled jerking movements, which we call chorea. This particular condition is inherited as a dominant trait.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="herniation-of-the-intervertebral-disc-and-laminectomy">Herniation of the Intervertebral Disc and Laminectomy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#herniation-of-the-intervertebral-disc-and-laminectomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Herniation refers to squeezing of the disc between two vertebral bodies. It is normally a very painful process and patients should be managed appropriately. The treatment of the herniated disc involves immobilisation to allow for healing of soft tissues and reduction of inflammation. Immobilisation involves the use of traction, bed rest, collars and braces.</p>
<p>Muscle relaxants, anti-inflammatory drugs and analgesics are also generally used. Additionally, a moist heat compress will help the patient. The patient with lumbar disc herniation requires bed rest, anti-inflammatory or analgesic drugs, heat treatment and sometimes surgery. Patient education should be included to ensure the patient co-operates with treatment procedures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laminectomy">Laminectomy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laminectomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Laminectomy is the removal of the lamina to expose the spinal cord. It is recommended for the prevention of irreversible neurological damage, for progressive disease with muscular weakness and for recurring episodes of pain. Pre operative management includes teaching the patient to practice log rolling to ensure the spinal column remains in alignment when turning until healing has occurred. Explain the importance of taking analgesics regularly, deep breathing and leg exercises.</p>
<p>Post-operatively, the patient requires bed rest, use of a pillow under the head and knee flexion to relax back muscles. Assess movement and sensation of extremities for signs of nerve compression. Change of position through logrolling, use of pillows between legs when turning and avoidance of extreme flexion must be part of the care. Assess for haematoma and leakage of cerebrospinal fluid, and for urinary retention. The patient should void within eight hours after surgery.</p>
<p>You should give drugs to reduce inflammation, relieve pain and anxiety and decrease the possibility of infection. The patient should also be given education on self care and should be closely observed for complications.</p>
<p>A more common neurological disease that you may have encountered is epilepsy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epilepsy">Epilepsy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epilepsy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The term refers to two or more unprovoked seizures in one year. The seizures are sudden and uncoordinated. Epilepsy is normally a manifestation of underlying disorders. If they are linked to a particular part of the brain, then they are called focal or partial epilepsy. However, if they cause unconsciousness and general brain dysfunction, they are called generalised epilepsy.</p>
<p>The manifestations of focal epilepsy are hallucinations of taste, smell or hearing. Jacksonian epilepsy affects motor functions, leading to twitching of particular areas. Generalised epilepsy can either be petit mal seizures or grand mal seizures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="grand-mal-seizures">Grand Mal Seizures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#grand-mal-seizures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In grand mal epilepsy, the patient may be aware that the seizure is imminent. This is followed by an aura phase after which there is a generalised tonic contraction. The third phase is the clonic phase where muscles have jerky movements. The tonic and clonic phases are collectively referred to as the ictal phase. Finally the patient enters the phase of relaxation and moves from coma to sleep. This is the post-ictal phase</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="petit-mal-seizures">Petit Mal Seizures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#petit-mal-seizures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Petit mal seizures are characterised by a phase of transient loss of consciousness. Perhaps you have seen patients who stare expressionlessly for some time before they continue with their function without being aware. This is a characteristic of petit mal seizures</p>
<p>Primary epilepsy has no known cause. Some of the causes of secondary epilepsy are cerebral scarring due to head injury, cerebral vascular accidents, infections, degenerative CNS diseases and childhood febrile illnesses. It is important to bear this in mind so that you control febrile illness well and avoid head injury in neonates during obstetric care.</p>
<p>Seizures that occur spontaneously in succession are called status epilepticus. These normally occur without recovery. This condition is considered a major medical emergency. Vigorous muscular contractions impose a heavy metabolic demand and can interfere with respirations. At the height of each seizure, some respiratory arrest occurs which produces venous congestion and hypoxia of the brain. Repeated episodes may lead to irreversible and fatal brain damage.</p>
<p>Factors that precipitate status epilepticus include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Withdrawal of anti epileptic drugs</li>
<li>Fever and infection</li>
<li>Cerebral oedema</li>
</ul>
<p>Management of status epilepticus includes positioning the patient to lie on the lateral position to prevent inhalation of secretions from the mouth. Give IV (not IM) diazepam 10-30mg STAT slowly over three minutes, repeat if there is no response. If no response put 80mg in 500mls of normal saline, adjust rate to control seizures.</p>
<p>Other useful drugs include phenobarbitone sodium - IM 125mg to 250mg, phenytoin sodium (Epanutin) 100mg tds. Treat hyperpyrexia by temperature reducing measures.</p>
<p>Give care as for the unconscious patient. Oral anti convulsants are given as soon as the patient gains consciousness.</p>
<p>The general management of status epilepticus will follow the general care pattern we will now outline. You will learn more about this disorder in children in the unit on paediatric nursing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="care-of-the-adult-patient-with-epilepsy">Care of the Adult Patient with Epilepsy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-patient-with-epilepsy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You have studied epilepsy and its various forms. After a careful assessment of the patient with epilepsy, you should concentrate on meeting the following objectives as part of the management of the disorder:</p>
<ul>
<li>Determine and treat (if possible) the primary underlying cause</li>
<li>Prevent recurrence</li>
<li>Manage the seizure and prevent injury</li>
</ul>
<p>During a seizure period, closely observe the patient and support the patient by giving privacy and ensuring an adequate airway. Do not attempt to place anything in the mouth and always protect the head from injury, for example by placing a folded blanket under the head. After the convulsions have passed, reorient the patient to the environment.</p>
<p>Generally, medications such as phenytoin, carbamazepine and phenobarbitone are useful anti-seizure drugs. Other drugs may be given for tranquilisation. Patient education on a safe environment and coping with stress is also required. If there are underlying causes, these should be treated, for example, in the case of a tumour, surgical excision is recommended.</p>
<p>Other common conditions include:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="parkinson-s-disease">Parkinson's Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parkinson-s-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>Definition:</strong> This is a progressive neuromuscular disease involving degenerative changes and dysfunction of the basal ganglia. It is a disorder of movement and posture.</p>
<p>Patients have deficient amounts of naturally occurring dopamine which is required for normal functioning of the basal ganglia in the brain.</p>
<p>The cause is unknown but it is associated with viral infections such as viral encephalitis or meningitis, cerebral vascular disease, toxicity or poisoning.</p>
<p>The clinical features are initially non specific aches and pains but the key features are tremors, rigidity and slowness of movement (Bradykinesia). Other features include slow eye movements, depression, postural hypotension.</p>
<p>Patients with parkinsonism are susceptible to respiratory complications because of muscle rigidity which prevents excursion and ability to cough. There is disturbance of autonomic nervous system. Patient's appearance deteriorates as they cannot attend to activities of daily living.</p>
<p>Patients with Parkinson's disease require medication such as Levadopa 0.25-0.5mg daily. This relieves symptoms of tremor and rigidity.</p>
<p>The aim of nursing care is to maintain muscular and joint function so that the patient can be as independent as possible. Blood pressure monitoring to detect postural hypotension and teach the patient to avoid rapid postural changes. Moderate exercises to</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>improve muscle tone which reduces stooping and shuffling movements. Patient should be instructed to walk slowly and carefully. Provide adequate rest to prevent fatigue.</p>
<p>General nursing care includes assisting the patient to feed slowly, prevent constipation and provide psychological support to counteract depression, discouragement and hopelessness. Speech therapy should be done to correct dysarthia. Involve patient in own care.</p>
<p>Patients have deficient amounts of naturally occurring dopamine which is required for normal functioning of the basal ganglia in the brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-complications-may-ensue-after-severe-head-injury">What complications may ensue after severe head injury?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-complications-may-ensue-after-severe-head-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Your examples should include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Coma</li>
<li>Paralysis</li>
<li>Respiratory failure</li>
<li>Hypothermia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="what-are-the-functions-of-the-cerebrospinal-fluid">What are the functions of the cerebrospinal fluid?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#what-are-the-functions-of-the-cerebrospinal-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Did you think of the following</p>
<ul>
<li>It is involved in the exchange of substances, for example, nutrients between the CSF and the nerve cells.</li>
<li>It keeps the brain and spinal cord moist.</li>
<li>It is a shock absorber for the brain, spinal cord and nerves.</li>
<li>It supports the brain and spinal cord and protects them.</li>
<li>It maintains pressure around the delicate structures in a uniform manner.</li>
</ul>
<p>You should study further the various nerve cells of the central nervous system and the movement of cerebrospinal fluid. This information can be found in any anatomy book.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-eyes-and-ears">The Eyes and Ears<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-eyes-and-ears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under the special senses, you should consider the vision, hearing, smelling and taste. However, you shall only learn about the diseases of the eye and ear and how to manage them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-eye">The Eye<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the organ of sight, which lies protected in the orbit of the skull. The other protective structures of the eye are eyelids, brows and</p>
<p>eyelashes. The eye blinks by a reflex that serves as further protection. Eyes function as a pair. Anteriorly, a transparent mucus membrane called the conjunctiva covers the eye. The eye surface is kept moist by tears produced by lacrimal glands.</p>
<p>The eye has three layers. These are the sclera and cornea on the outside, the choroids, ciliary body and iris in the middle, and the retina is the inner most part of the eye. Anteriorly the cornea allows light rays to pass through. Since the lens is convex, it refracts or bends light rays to focus on the innermost part of the eye, the retina. Light rays are absorbed by the choroid to stimulate nerve endings.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-ec40a3c8.jpeg" alt="img-31.jpeg"></p>
<p>The cranial nerve that supplies the eye is the optic.</p>
<p>The ciliary body is the point of attachment for muscles and ligaments whose contraction changes the thickness of the lens.</p>
<p>The iris lies behind the cornea and is circular and forms an opening at its centre called the pupil. This varies in size depending on light intensity. You may have seen patients who have organophosphate poisoning and whose pupil were pinpoint in size.</p>
<p>The lens lies behind the pupil.</p>
<p>The innermost part, the retina, has cells involved in changing light rays into nerve impulses. Behind and in front of the cornea and lens is a clear fluid called aqueous fluid (humor) and vitrous humor respectively. The vitrous humor is colloidal. The aqueous and vitrous humor maintain intraocular pressure.</p>
<p>The nerve that supplies the eyes is the optic nerve. Light is focused onto the retina in both eyes and is bent by the lens.</p>
<p>The pupils change size to allow the appropriate amount of light to enter the eye. The eyeballs</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>also move to change the visual field. Once light is changed into nerve impulses, the brain can interpret and form a visual image.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basic-assessment-of-the-eye-and-vision">Basic Assessment of the Eye and Vision<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basic-assessment-of-the-eye-and-vision" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This consists of a careful patient interview and physical assessment of the eye structures. The patient will normally have complaints e.g. blurred vision, itchy eyes, discharge that must be examined.</p>
<p>A basic assessment of the eye includes observing:</p>
<ul>
<li>Eyelids and conjunctiva e.g. for oedema</li>
<li>Corner e.g. for clarity</li>
<li>Sclera e.g. for colour</li>
<li>Iris and pupil e.g. colour shape size</li>
<li>Lens - transparent or opaque</li>
</ul>
<p>Visual acquity means acuteness or sharpness of vision and includes measurement of distance and near vision.</p>
<p>A Snellen's chart is used to measure acuteness of vision. It consists of printed letters or words in various sizes.</p>
<p>The inspection of the internal structures is done by use of an ophthalmoscope.</p>
<p>This allows the examiner to view the back of the eye through the pupil to see the optic nerve, retina, blood vessels and macula.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-1c838499.jpeg" alt="img-32.jpeg">
The Human Eye</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-7662bad3.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg">
The Structure of the Eye</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-eye">Disorders of the Eye<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-eye" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="blepharitis">Blepharitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blepharitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Blepharitis is one of the most common disorders of the eye. It is an inflammation of the eyelids, characterised by irritation, burning, redness and itching of the eyelid margins. The assessment of a patient with blepharitis must gather all the information related to any recent trauma, possible exposure to allergic substances and infection.</p>
<p>In our country, blepharitis is commonly associated with trachoma. During management you should consider the various causes. The drugs commonly used include tetracycline eye ointment, gentamycin and kanamycin eye drops. Any allergens should be eliminated from the patient's environment</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="eye-infections-and-inflammations">Eye Infections and Inflammations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eye-infections-and-inflammations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(a) Hordeolum/Stye: An infection of small glands of lid margins.</p>
<ul>
<li>Causative organism: Staphylococcus aureus.</li>
<li>Clinical features: Tender swollen pustive on eyelid, it eventually ruptures.</li>
<li>Management: Apply warm compresses three to four times a day to facilitate ripening and drainage. This can be done by hot spoon bathing. Tetracycline eye ointment can be applied three times a day in severe cases after cleaning the lid margin. Incision and drainage should be done if it does not resolve.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>b) Chalazion: A Sterile cyst located in the connective tissue in the eyelid.</p>
<ul>
<li>Clinical Features: Small lump, hard and non-tender but may put pressure on the eye and affect vision.</li>
<li>Management: May resolve on its own otherwise incision and drainage is done if it does not resolve. Cleaning of eyes facilitates healing without further complications.</li>
</ul>
<p>Uveitis
Uveitis: Acute inflammation of the uvea (i.e. choroid)</p>
<ul>
<li>Causes: Infection, allergy, toxic agents or systemic disorders e.g. diabetes</li>
<li>Clinical Features: General eye pain around the eyeball. Swelling photophobia, visual impairment.</li>
</ul>
<p>Management
Treat the underlying cause. DO NOT ADMINISTER ANTIBIOTIC WITH STEROIDS this may mask the inflammation and cause further damage to the eye structures. Refer to an ophthalmologist for assessment and further care.</p>
<p>Corneal Ulceration and Corneal Detachment
Ulceration of the cornea may be caused by trauma or cataract surgery. If a patient receives blunt trauma to the eye, the retina may separate from the choroid and vitreous humor seeps behind the eye. This will cause retinal detachment.</p>
<p>Clinically, the patient presents with flashes of light, they may see floating images (floaters) and there is a sensation of veiled sight. On examination, the patient may have loss of vision. Keratitis is the inflammation of the cornea that may be caused by infection, hypersensitivity, and trauma. The management will follow the same pattern as ulceration. Most importantly, the cause of the problem must be removed.</p>
<p>Corneal Ulcer
A patient who has a corneal ulcer requires examination, systemic antibiotics, warm compresses for comfort and padding of the eye. For the patient with retinal detachment, bed rest is always recommended to promote healing and tranquilisers may be administered to reduce anxiety. Surgery may be undertaken in specialised centres.</p>
<p>Ptosis
Weakness of the muscle that elevates the eyelid causes ptosis. This is characterised by the drooping of the upper lid. This drooping makes it difficult to see. The commonest causes of ptosis is drugs, trauma and muscle weakness. The etiologic factor should be removed to promote vision.</p>
<p>Conjunctivitis
This is the inflammation of the conjunctiva. Infections, allergens, chemical agents or physical irritants commonly cause it. The signs and symptoms of conjunctivitis include redness, a burning sensation in the eye and tearing.</p>
<p>Patients have a gritty sensation in the eye, and there may be itching and discharge. Bacteria, viruses and other agents may also cause conjunctivitis. The treatment includes antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs and analgesic drugs. One of the common drugs that you are likely to use is tetracycline eye ointment.</p>
<p>Trachoma
Trachoma is one of the most widespread eye problems in the drier regions of our country. It is caused by the agent chlamydia trachomatis. Flies normally transfer the micro-organisms from person to person. It is a common cause of blindness in Kenya. The micro-organisms will affect the conjunctiva leading to conjunctivitis. As the inflammation proceeds, the eyelids get turned inwards causing scratching and scarring.</p>
<p>Finally, this may end up in blindness. This is a preventable cause of blindness. The main factors to concentrate on in prevention are good personal hygiene, avoiding the sharing of handkerchiefs, and getting rid of flies. The treatment of trachoma involves use of antibiotics and the commonest one is tetracycline.</p>
<p>Cataract
Cataract: is the opacity of the lens.</p>
<ul>
<li>Causes: Cataracts may be associated with aging, trauma, congenital or secondary to other medical conditions.</li>
</ul>
<p>Pathophysiology
Cataracts associated with aging may result from a decrease in protein, accumulation of water and an increase in sodium content that disrupts the normal fibres of the lens. This leads to opacification of the lens.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 143 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The primary symptom of cataracts is a progressive loss of vision. The degree of loss depends on the location and extent of opacity, it can manifest with:</p>
<ul>
<li>Gradual painless blurring and loss of vision</li>
<li>Glare at night and in bright light</li>
<li>Haloes around lights</li>
<li>Cloudy white opacity on the pupil</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is done by direct inspection of lens with an ophthalmoscope after pupil dilation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Surgery is the treatment of choice under local anaesthesia, the lens is extracted. An intraocular lens implant may be inserted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pre-operative-management">Pre-operative Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pre-operative-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Informed consent is signed by the patient</li>
<li>Health messages on the expected post-operative restrictions are given e.g. avoid bending over or rubbing eyes to avoid dislodging of implant</li>
<li>Treat patient for any coughing or sneezing to avoid complications</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="post-operative-care">Post-operative Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-operative-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Immediately after surgery</li>
<li>Position patient to lie on back or on the side of the unoperated eye to prevent strawling by patient</li>
<li>Keep eye padded for rest</li>
<li>Clean aseptically before instilling eye ointment</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="complications">Complications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These include infection, bleeding and elevated IOP. The patient is instructed to promptly report when they notice signs of complications.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glaucoma">Glaucoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glaucoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Glaucoma: is an eye disease characterised by progressive nerve atrophy and loss of vision.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The normal range of aqueous humor pressures in the eye ranges from 10 to 21 mmhg. In a normal eye there is a balance between the production and drainage of aqueous humor that allows the intraocular pressure to remain relatively constant. An increased intraocular pressure results from a blockage in the outflow. When this blockage persists, the optic nerve is damaged with loss of vision. In primary open-angle glaucoma, the changes occur slowly. The process can also occur more rapidly in response to injury infection or as a complication of surgery.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Open Angle Glaucoma</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Intraocular pressure of &gt; 24mmHg</li>
<li>Slow loss of vision, peripheral vision lost before central vision</li>
<li>Persistent dull pain in eyes</li>
<li>Difficulty adjusting to darkness</li>
<li>Failure to detect color changes</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>Angle Closure Glaucoma</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>In its acute form, it presents with severe ocular pain, decreased vision, pupil enlarged and fixed eye red, steamy cornea</li>
<li>It may cause nausea and vomiting</li>
<li>Intraocular pressure may exceed 50mmHg</li>
<li>Permanent blindness can occur if there is marked increase in pressure for 24-48 hours</li>
</ul>
<ol start="3">
<li>Congenital Glaucoma</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>Enlargement of eye, lacrimation, photophobia, blepharospasm</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Tests include: Tonometry: measurement of intraocular pressure, Ophthalmoscopy to evaluation of colour and shape of optic cup.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is first medical (conservative). Surgical intervention is indicated where conservative management fails.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conservative-management">Conservative Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conservative-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Drugs are used to lower the intraocular pressure and prevent loss of vision. Drug therapy does this by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Increasing outflow of aqueous humor</li>
<li>Decreasing product of aqueous humor</li>
</ul>
<p>Drugs of choice include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Miotics constrict pupil e.g pilocarpine</li>
<li>Cholinesterase inhibitors to constrict ciliary muscle e.g eserine</li>
<li>Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors to decrease aqueous humor production e.g. diamox</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 144 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="surgical-management">Surgical Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surgical-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Trabeculectomy is the common procedure performed. This creates an opening in the trabecular meshwork to allow for draining. The specific management includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Observations post anaesthesia</li>
<li>Protection of operative eye with patal or shield</li>
<li>Maintaining comfort in the eye by drug instillation</li>
<li>Regular assessment of intraocular pressure</li>
<li>Administration of medications in combination to protect the eye from infections and inflammation i.e. antibiotics and steroid</li>
<li>Patients to avoid lifting heavy objects and any straining e.g. at defecation to avoid prolapse of eye contents</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="colour-blindness">Colour Blindness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#colour-blindness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>At this point it is important also to make a note about the condition known as colour blindness. In this disorder individuals confuse, mismatch or have reduced acuity for colour discrimination. Mostly, this is a genetic problem.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="general-care-of-eye-injury">General Care of Eye Injury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-care-of-eye-injury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Eye injuries are a common occurrence in our environment. The types of injuries include lacerations to eyelids, corneal injuries, foreign bodies on cornea or in penetrating injuries, splashes to the eye. Preventive measures are more important in this case, but for the patient who already has an injury to the eye, you must undertake the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>If there is any penetrating object, leave it in situ, cover the eye lightly with a sterile dressing and refer immediately.</li>
<li>In the case of splashes to the eye, irrigate the eye with saline solution for 15 minutes.</li>
<li>Prepare for examination of the eye and assist in determination of the extent of the injury.</li>
<li>Advise the patient on care and follow-up. Patients with severe injuries may have their eyes padded and should be advised to take good care of the eye to minimise infection and to seek medical care as soon as possible.</li>
</ul>
<p>You need to learn skills used in treatment of eye conditions e.g. Hot spoon bathing, eye irrigation, version of eyelid to manage eye injuries.</p>
<p>For the patient having eye surgery you must assist in the immediate pre-operative management by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Preparing for general anaesthesia, for example, evacuation of bowel.</li>
<li>Removal of dentures.</li>
<li>Trimming eyelashes.</li>
<li>Instructing the patient regarding post-operative restrictions such as no showers or shampoos, no lifting and no sleeping on operated side until healing has taken place. They should also avoid sneezing and breathing through their noses as this increases intra-ocular pressure.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the post-operative period, the patients require good positioning, preferably, the dorsal recumbent position, with the use of lateral pillows. The patient also requires education on what to report, for example, severe pain, bleeding and how to communicate if they cannot see. Analgesics and other drugs may also be prescribed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-ear">The Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The ear is the organ of hearing, and comprises the external ear, a middle ear and an inner ear. The external part of the ear has the auricle, which is externally visible. The auricle concentrates sound into the ear canal. The external auditory meatus ends at the eardrum, also called the tympanic membrane.</p>
<p>After this membrane is the middle ear, which has structures made up of three tiny bones: the tapes, the incus and malleus. By vibration, the three bones transmit sound waves to the inner ear. The three bones are called ossicles.</p>
<p>A coclear, which is the real organ of hearing, and semicircular canals that are involved in balance, is found in the inner ear.</p>
<p>Once the auricle has concentrated sound waves, they vibrate the tympanic membrane, which causes movement of the three tiny bones. The moving sound waves cause movement of fluid in the cochlear and specialised cells pick these waves to produce nerve impulses. These specialised cells are in the organ of Corti.</p>
<p>The brain interprets the impulses from the semi-circular canals. The three semi-circular canals are at right angles to each other. They, therefore, represent the three planes of position.</p>
<p>The nerve that supplies the ears is the vestibulo-cochlear nerve, which has a vestibular branch for balance and cochlear branch for hearing. The external auditory meatus produces wax or cerumen that protects the ear.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 145 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-ears">Disorders of the Ears<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-ears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
