<p>The diseases that affect the ears can be classified into those affecting the external ear, the middle ear and the inner ear.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-ear">External Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tumours, foreign bodies or simple inflammation are the conditions that commonly afflict the external ear. Inflammation of the external auditory meatus is called external otitis. It is caused by irritation by various substances, for example objects placed in the ear. Ear wax produced from the ear canal may cause obstruction.</p>
<p>The external ear may also suffer from tumours, which can be benign or malignant. General ear care can help prevent obstruction and inflammation. Tumours are normally excised if they cause hearing loss.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-otitis">External Otitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-otitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The external otitis can be bacterial or fungal or due to an allergic reaction e.g. from soaps, hairsprays.</p>
<p>The patient experiences pain on touching or moving the auricle. Some people are prone to infection from swimming in contaminated water and this is referred to as 'Swimmers ear'. Furuncles also occur and these are mainly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Incision and drainage of the furuncle is rarely done and this is best managed by administration of antibiotics and application of hot packs. This usually results in resolution of the furuncle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cerumen">Cerumen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerumen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cerumen in the ear canal may occasionally be impacted causing ear ache and hearing difficulties. These wax deposits may be softened using warm glycerine drops. When cerumen becomes difficult to dislodge, it can be removed with a cerumen spoon under magnification.</p>
<p>In some instances, foreign bodies are inserted accidentally into the ear canal. Insects can easily be removed by instillation of oil drops as the oil allows the insects to float and be flushed out. For foreign bodies of vegetable origin, irrigation with any fluid is contraindicated as they have a tendency to swell making removal difficult. Removal of foreign bodies should be by a skilled person as the object may be pushed even deeper, lacerating the skin of the canal and perforating the ear drum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-ear">External Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tumours, foreign bodies or simple inflammation are the conditions that commonly afflict the external ear. Inflammation of the external auditory meatus is called external otitis. It is caused by irritation by various substances, for example objects placed in the ear. Ear wax produced from the ear canal may cause obstruction.</p>
<p>The external ear may also suffer from tumours, which can be benign or malignant. General ear care can help prevent obstruction and inflammation. Tumours are normally excised if they cause hearing loss.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-otitis">External Otitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-otitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The external otitis can be bacterial or fungal or due to an allergic reaction e.g. from soaps, hairsprays.</p>
<p>The patient experiences pain on touching or moving the auricle. Some people are prone to infection from swimming in contaminated water and this is referred to as 'Swimmers ear'. Furuncles also occur and these are mainly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Incision and drainage of the furuncle is rarely done and this is best managed by administration of antibiotics and application of hot packs. This usually results in resolution of the furuncle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cerumen">Cerumen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerumen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cerumen in the ear canal may occasionally be impacted causing ear ache and hearing difficulties. These wax deposits may be softened using warm glycerine drops. When cerumen becomes difficult to dislodge, it can be removed with a cerumen spoon under magnification.</p>
<p>In some instances, foreign bodies are inserted accidentally into the ear canal. Insects can easily be removed by instillation of oil drops as the oil allows the insects to float and be flushed out. For foreign bodies of vegetable origin, irrigation with any fluid is contraindicated as they have a tendency to swell making removal difficult. Removal of foreign bodies should be by a skilled person as the object may be pushed even deeper, lacerating the skin of the canal and perforating the ear drum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-middle-ear">The Middle Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-middle-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The middle ear is a cavity, which has the eardrum and the auditory ossicles. In the middle ear, we can have otitis media, caused by micro-organisms such as staphylococcus aureus, and inflammation caused by the insertion of foreign objects. This condition may</p>
<p>be complicated or caused by a simple common cold.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="problems-of-the-middle-ear">Problems of the Middle Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#problems-of-the-middle-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perforation of the tympanic membrane can result from accidents involving the skull. Traumatic damage may be from blast effects of explosives. Infection such as acute and chronic suppurative otitis media can also cause perforation. Other causes include foreign bodies, burns of the face that extend to the ear and accidental or deliberate blows to the face.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="otitis-media">Otitis Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#otitis-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acute Otitis media is an inflammation of the middle ear as a result of entrance of pathogenic bacteria into the normally sterile middle ear. The mode of entry of the micro organisms is via the auditory canal from the respiratory tract. Bacteria that commonly cause this condition include streptococcus pneumoniae, staphylococcus and Haemophilus Influenzae. Occasionally, infection also spreads from the external ear if the tympanic membrane is perforated. Infection usually leads to accumulation of pus in the middle ear and outward bulging of the tympanic membrane. When the membrane ruptures, there is purulent discharge from the ear (otorrhoea).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-middle-ear">The Middle Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-middle-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The middle ear is a cavity, which has the eardrum and the auditory ossicles. In the middle ear, we can have otitis media, caused by micro-organisms such as staphylococcus aureus, and inflammation caused by the insertion of foreign objects. This condition may be complicated or caused by a simple common cold.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="problems-of-the-middle-ear">Problems of the Middle Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#problems-of-the-middle-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Perforation of the tympanic membrane can result from accidents involving the skull. Traumatic damage may be from blast effects of explosives. Infection such as acute and chronic suppurative otitis media can also cause perforation. Other causes include foreign bodies, burns of the face that extend to the ear and accidental or deliberate blows to the face.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="otitis-media">Otitis Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#otitis-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Acute Otitis media is an inflammation of the middle ear as a result of entrance of pathogenic bacteria into the normally sterile middle ear. The mode of entry of the micro organisms is via the auditory canal from the respiratory tract. Bacteria that commonly cause this condition include streptococcus pneumoniae, staphylococcus and Haemophilus Influenzae. Occasionally, infection also spreads from the external ear if the tympanic membrane is perforated. Infection usually leads to accumulation of pus in the middle ear and outward bulging of the tympanic membrane. When the membrane ruptures, there is purulent discharge from the ear (otorrhoea).</p>
<p>Chronic otitis media results from repeated attacks of otitis media causing persistent perforation of the ear drum. Bacterial resistance to antibiotic therapy and virulence of the infecting organisms are causative factors. Chronic otitis media presents with persistent or intermittent foul smelling discharge. Pain may be present with varying degrees of deafness.</p>
<p>Complications associated with otitis media include mastoiditis, brain abscess and seventh cranial nerve paralysis.</p>
<p>The treatment of otitis varies according to the organisms and severity. Broad-spectrum antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs are given for the pathogens, as well as for pain and inflammation. Myringotomy, which is an incision into the posterior aspect of the tympanic membrane, is made surgically for drainage purposes. Your role here is to observe the drainage and assess hearing. In chronic otitis media and inflammation of the mastoid process (mastoiditis), antibiotics and surgery are the choice interventions. The surgical operations performed are simple mastoidectomy or radical mastoidectomy, which involve complete or partial removal of the mastoid bone.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inner-ear">Inner Ear<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inner-ear" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The inner ear also suffers otitis interna, labyrinthitis and sensorineural hearing loss. Patients who have disorders of the inner ear are likely to have vertigo (giddiness), tinnitus (buzzing in the ears) and unilateral deafness. The infections of the external ear may spread to the inner ear so they should be immediately treated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="motion-sickness">Motion Sickness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#motion-sickness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is disturbance of equilibrium caused by constant motion. There is excessive stimulation of the semicircular canal and vestibular apparatus resulting in dizziness, nausea and vomiting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="meniere-s-disease">Meniere's Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meniere-s-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an inner ear problem where there is labyrinthine dysfunction. It is characterised by the presence of a triad of symptoms which</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>include paroxysmal whirling vertigo, tinnitus and sensorineural hearing loss.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hearing-loss">Hearing Loss<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hearing-loss" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is classified as either conductive or sensorineural. Conductive hearing loss results from impairment of the outer ear, middle ear or both. There is impaired transmission of sound waves from outside to the oval window. Causes of conductive hearing loss include presence of wax or foreign bodies in the ear canal, otitis media, barotraumas, otosclerosis and injury to the tympanic membrane.</p>
<p>Sensorineural hearing occurs where sensitivity to and discrimination of sound is impaired. Sounds may be conducted properly through the external and middle ear but are not analyzed correctly in the inner ear. This can result from disease of the cochlea, the cochlear branch of the vestibular nerve or the hearing area of the brain.</p>
<p>Otitis is one of the most common ear problems.</p>
<p>The treatment of otitis varies according to the organisms and severity. Broad spectrum antibiotics and anti-inflammatory drugs are given for the pathogens, as well as for pain and inflammation. Myringotomy, which is an incision into the posterior aspect of the tympanic membrane, is made surgically for drainage purposes. Your role here is to observe the drainage and assess hearing.</p>
<p>In chronic otitis media and inflammation of the mastoid process (mastoiditis), antibiotics and surgery are the choice interventions. The surgical operations performed are simple mastoidectomy or radical mastoidectomy, which involve complete or partial removal of the mastoid bone.</p>
<p>The nursing care of a patient following ear surgery involves:</p>
<ul>
<li>Inspecting for drainage and observing vital functions</li>
<li>Changing of dressings</li>
<li>Providing post-operative pain relief</li>
<li>Educating the patient to sneeze and cough with an open mouth</li>
<li>Advising patients to avoid flying, swimming and any activities that may jeopardise the healing process</li>
<li>Providing antibiotics</li>
<li>Observing patients for complications such as vertigo and hearing loss</li>
</ul>
<p>The patient with hearing loss should also be taught methods of communication that do not involve the use of sound, for example, lip reading.</p>

<ul>
<li>Inspecting for drainage and observing vital functions</li>
<li>Changing of dressings</li>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-senses">Other Senses<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-senses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The other senses, which you will briefly cover, are smell experienced by the nose, taste experienced by the tongue, and touch experienced by the skin.</p>
<p>To be able to smell, chemical particles from substances get into the nose and epithelia cells on the upper part of the nose, where olfaction or smelling is carried out. The olfactory nerve is a cranial nerve involved in enabling the sense of smell.</p>
<p>Taste is facilitated by the taste buds found on the tongue. The tongue can distinguish sweet, sour, bitter, salty and other tastes. A part of the glosso-pharyngeal nerve supplies the tongue with its sensory ability.</p>
<p>Look up the structure of the nose and throat to reinforce what you have been learning.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-endocrine-system">The Endocrine System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-endocrine-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The endocrine system consists of glands widely separated with no anatomical links. The endocrine glands are termed as ductless and they secrete chemicals known as hormones.</p>
<p>Hormones are chemical messengers produced by ductless/endocrine glands, which flow directly into the blood where they are carried to another organ to influence activity, growth or nutrition. The hormones, together with the autonomic nervous system that you studied earlier, regulate the internal environment. The endocrine glands are:</p>
<ul>
<li>1 Pituitary gland</li>
<li>1 Thyroid gland</li>
<li>4 Parathyroid glands</li>
<li>2 Adrenal (suprarenal) glands</li>
<li>The pancreatic islets (islets of langerhans)</li>
<li>1 Pineal gland or body</li>
<li>1 Thymus gland</li>
<li>2 Ovaries in the female</li>
<li>2 Testes in the male</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-ab648cdf.jpeg" alt="img-34.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-pituitary-gland-and-the-hypothalamus">The Pituitary Gland and the Hypothalamus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pituitary-gland-and-the-hypothalamus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The pituitary gland lies within the sella turcica, a depression within the sphenoid bone, inferior to the hypothalamus. You have learnt that it is composed of three lobes, the posterior, anterior and middle lobes.</p>
<p>The pituitary gland and the hypothalamus act as a unit. The hypothalamus has a direct controlling effect on the pituitary gland and an indirect effect on many others.</p>
<p>The pituitary gland has three parts: the anterior lobe, posterior lobe and intermediate lobe. The term neurohypophysis refers to the posterior lobe, while adenohypophysis refers to the anterior lobe.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Hormones of the Hypothalamus and the Anterior Pituitary Gland and their Targets</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Hypothalamus</td><td>Anterior Pituitary</td><td>Target</td></tr><tr><td>Growth hormone releasing factor</td><td>Growth hormone</td><td>All tissues and very many glands</td></tr><tr><td>Growth hormone release inhibiting factors (Somatotrophin)</td><td>Growth hormone inhibition</td><td>All tissues, thyroid, pancreas</td></tr><tr><td>Thyroid releasing factor</td><td>Thyroid stimulating hormone</td><td>Thyroid gland</td></tr><tr><td>Corticotrophin releasing factor</td><td>Adreno-corticotropic hormone</td><td>Adrenal cortex</td></tr><tr><td>Prolactin inhibiting factor</td><td>Prolactin</td><td>Breast</td></tr><tr><td>Luteinising Hormone releasing factor</td><td>Follicle stimulating hormone, luteinising hormone, prolactin</td><td>Ovaries and Testes Breast</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-posterior-lobe">The Posterior Lobe<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-posterior-lobe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The posterior lobe of the pituitary secretes two hormones: antidiuretic hormone and oxytocin. The antidiuretic hormone increases permeability to water of the distal renal tubules. You shall study this later. It also stimulates the contraction of the smooth muscles in blood vessels hence raising blood pressure. Oxytocin causes contraction of the uterus and cells in the lactating breast. You will study this in greater detail when dealing with Reproductive Health in module two.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="did-you-know-that-these-two-hormones-are-actually-produced-by-the-hypothalamus-but-stored-in-the-posterior-pituitary-gland">Did you know that these two hormones are actually produced by the hypothalamus but stored in the posterior pituitary gland?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#did-you-know-that-these-two-hormones-are-actually-produced-by-the-hypothalamus-but-stored-in-the-posterior-pituitary-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-anterior-lobe">The Anterior Lobe<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-anterior-lobe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Anterior Lobe produces several hormones. The growth hormone promotes fat metabolism while promoting fat mobilisation and catabolism. The thyroid stimulating hormone stimulates the synthesis and secretion of the thyroid hormones. The adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulates the growth of the adrenal cortex and secretion of glucocorticoids, for example, cortisol.</p>
<p>Follicle stimulating hormones cause the growth of the Graafian follicle and spermatogenesis. They also facilitate the secretion of oestrogen. Luteinising hormones are required for ovulation. They also stimulate the corpus luteum to secrete progesterone. You will revisit these hormones under reproductive health. Prolactin promotes breast development, stimulates progesterone secretion and promotes breast development during delivery</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thyroid-gland">Thyroid Gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The thyroid gland is situated in the neck in front of the larynx and trachea. It consists of two lobes one on either side of the thyroid cartilage.</p>
<p>It's regulated by thyroid stimulating hormone from the anterior lobe.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The thyroid gland produces tetra-iodothyronine (thyroxine), triiodothyronine and calcitonin hormones.</p>
<p>The first two hormones may enhance the</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>affects of other hormones (adrenaline and noradrenaline), are essentials for physical growth and mental development and helps in regulating the metabolic rate of all body cells. Calcitonin controls calcium content of the blood by increasing bone formation and inhibiting bone breakdown and this results in decreased blood calcium levels.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-9845ed91.jpeg" alt="img-35.jpeg">
Thyroid and Parathyroid Glands</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parathyroid-glands">Parathyroid Glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parathyroid-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are four small parathyroid glands, two embedded in the posterior surface of each lobe of the thyroid gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Secretes the hormone parathormone which is an antagonist to calcitonin.</li>
<li>It increases the release of calcium and phosphate into the blood by causing less new bone to be formed and more old bone to be broken down. This helps in maintaining blood calcium within normal limits (9-11mg/dl or 2.25-2.74 mmol/L).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-adrenal-glands">The Adrenal Glands<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-adrenal-glands" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The adrenal glands are located on the upper side of each kidney. Each adrenal gland has a cortex and medulla. The cortex produces glucocorticoids, mineral corticoids and sex hormones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-medulla">Adrenal Medulla<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-medulla" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The adrenal medulla produces the two catecholamines, epinephrine and norepinephrine. These perform the functions of stimulating the breakdown of glycogen by skeletal muscle, increasing blood concentration of free fatty acids, constricting most blood vessels in the body and constriction of bronchial smooth muscle. You should be able to link this to the autonomic nervous system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-cortex">Adrenal Cortex<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-cortex" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cortex produces glucocorticoids, mineral corticoids and sex hormones. These are steroids and are known as corticosteroids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="glucocorticoids">Glucocorticoids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glucocorticoids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The main glucocorticoids are cortisol and corticosterone. They perform the following main functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Regulating carbohydrate metabolism</li>
<li>Promoting utilisation of glycogen</li>
<li>Raising blood glucose level through gluconeogenesis</li>
<li>Promoting water and sodium re-absorption from the renal tubules</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mineralcorticoids">Mineralcorticoids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mineralcorticoids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The main mineralocorticoid is aldosterone its functions are associated with the maintenance of the electrolyte balance in the body. It increases sodium reabsorption in the kidneys while increasing potassium excreted. The amount of aldosterone produced is influenced by the sodium level in the blood and the renin angiotensin mechanism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sex-hormones">Sex Hormones<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sex-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In men, androgens are associated with deposition of proteins in muscles and retention of nitrogens. This will be covered again in the unit on Reproductive Health.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pancreas">The Pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Pancreas is an elongated gland with the head lying in the C shaped beginning of the small intestine (duodenum), with its body extending horizontally behind the stomach and its tail touching the spleen.</p>
<p>This gland is located behind the stomach in the abdominal cavity. It has both exocrine and endocrine properties. The Islets of Langerhans in the pancreas produce insulin, glucagon and somatostatin hormones. Insulin produced by beta cells (B cells) promotes cellular uptake of glucose, stimulates intracellular synthesis of glycogen, fat and proteins, and stimulates uptake of sodium and potassium. Glucagon produced by delta cells (D cells), on the other hand, antagonises insulin in the liver (breakdown of glycogen), inhibits protein</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>synthesis and induces hepatic fatty acid breakdown. Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of the other two hormones.</p>
<p>You will cover the disorder diabetes mellitus, which is related to these two hormones later.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-6a08030a.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gonads">Gonads<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gonads" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are the primary sex organs in the male termed as the testes and in the female termed as the ovaries.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ovaries">Ovaries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ovaries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are a set of paired glands in the pelvis that produce some of the following hormones:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="estrogens">Estrogens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#estrogens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This includes estradiol and estrone which are steroid hormones secreted by the cells of the ovarian follicles. They promote the development and maintenance of the female sexual characteristics and are also responsible for breast development and the sequence of events in the menstrual cycle. You will learn more details about estrogen and its functions in module two on reproductive health.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="progestrone">Progestrone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#progestrone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>It is secreted by the corpus luteum (that is the tissue left behind after the rapture of a follicle during ovulation). Progestrone with oestrogen maintains the lining of the uterus which is necessary for successful pregnancy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="testes">Testes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These are paired organs within a sac of skin called the scrotum which hangs from the groin area of the trunk.</p>
<p>They are composed mainly of sperm producing seminiferous tubules. Interstitial cells are found in areas between these tubules and they produce androgens (male sex hormones). The main androgen produced is testosterone. This hormone is responsible for the growth and maintenance of the male sexual characteristics and for sperm production</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thymus-gland">Thymus Gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thymus-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a gland in the mediastinum just beneath the sternum. It is large in children until puberty, when it begins to atrophy throughout adulthood. In old age the gland remains as a small amount of fat and fibrous tissue. It consists of two pyramidal lobes and each lobule is composed of a dense cellular cortex and an inner less dense medulla.</p>
<p>The thymus gland secretes the hormones thymosin and thymopoietin which are thought to stimulate the production of specialised lymphocytes called T lymphocytes necessary for cell mediated immunity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endocrine-disorders">Endocrine Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocrine-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nervous and endocrine systems control most functions in the human body. Endocrine dysfunction may result from deficient or excessive hormone secretion, transport abnormalities, an inability of target tissue to respond to a hormone or inappropriate stimulation of the target tissue receptor.</p>
<p>You have studied some glands and their hormones in the preceding pages. You will now concentrate on the disorders affecting these glands.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-hypothalamus">The Hypothalamus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-hypothalamus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the mother gland and it controls the functions of most of the other glands. The disorders that can affect the hypothalamus are encephalitis, head injury, tumours in the brain and haematomas. Since it has many functions, the effects of disease on the hypothalamus will be varied. The effects include obesity, restlessness, disordered temperature regulation, diabetes insipidus and precocious puberty.</p>
<p>The nervous and endocrine systems control most functions in the human body. Endocrine dysfunction may result from deficient or excessive hormone secretion, transport abnormalities, an inability of target tissue to respond to a hormone or inappropriate stimulation of the target tissue receptor.</p>
<p>You have studied some glands and their hormones in the preceding pages. You will now concentrate on the disorders affecting these glands.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers

Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-hypothalamus">The Hypothalamus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-hypothalamus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the mother gland and it controls the functions of most of the other glands. The disorders that can affect the hypothalamus are encephalitis, head injury, tumours in the brain and haematomas. Since it has many functions, the effects of disease on the hypothalamus will be varied. The effects include obesity, restlessness, disordered temperature regulation, diabetes insipidus and precocious puberty.</p>
<p>The nervous and endocrine systems control most functions in the human body. Endocrine dysfunction may result from deficient or excessive hormone secretion, transport abnormalities, an inability of target tissue to respond to a hormone or inappropriate stimulation of the target tissue receptor.</p>
<p>You have studied some glands and their hormones in the preceding pages. You will now concentrate on the disorders affecting these glands.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pituitary-disorders">Pituitary Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pituitary-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>If the posterior lobe of the pituitary is affected by either injury or disease, it can result in diabetes insipidus, which manifests with polyuria and polydipsia. The management will involve either surgery or hormone therapy. The most prominent disorders of the pituitary, however, are those that affect the anterior pituitary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-anterior-pituitary-gland">Disorders of the Anterior Pituitary Gland<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-anterior-pituitary-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This refers to the hyper-function of the pituitary. Excess of trophic hormones usually produce syndromes related to hormone excess from the target organ e.g if thyroid stimulating levels are excessive, hyperthyroidism develops while if adrenocorticotropic hormone is involved, cushings diseases (hypercortisolism) results.</p>
<p>Enlargement of the anterior pituitary can lead to hyper-secretion of one or many of the hormones that we mentioned. When this happens, the function performed by the particular hormone is also affected. It can also lead to loss of temporal vision.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hyperpituitarism">Hyperpituitarism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperpituitarism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the hyper-function of the pituitary. It can result in:</p>
<ul>
<li>Excess prolactin, which leads to amenorrhoea and inappropriate secretion of breast milk. In males it leads to impotence.</li>
<li>If it starts in childhood, hyperpituitarism can result in gigantism. When it occurs in adulthood it leads to acromegaly. In acromegaly individuals have enlarged hands, feet and lower jaw. They also have coarse facial features and impaired glucose tolerance. The clinical picture for somebody with this condition is typical and you are not likely to miss it if you are attentive.</li>
<li>Cushing's syndrome, which you shall learn about later.</li>
</ul>
<p>Since the hormones are many, several disorders can result which will vary the clinical picture.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypopituitarism">Hypopituitarism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypopituitarism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is a rare disorder that involves a decrease in one or more of the anterior pituitary hormones. Primary hypofunction may be as a result of autoimmune disorders, infections, tumours, vascular diseases or destruction of the gland from trauma, radiation or surgical procedures but the most common cause is a tumour. This is the result of a deficiency of growth hormone, which produces retardation in children. Males may have testicular atrophy. Females will develop amenorrhoea.</p>
<p>Other effects include: decreased muscle strength, defective renal function, altered thyroid metabolism and reduced basal metabolic rate. Glucocorticoid and androgen abnormalities can occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hyperaldosteronism">Hyperaldosteronism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperaldosteronism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Excessive aldosterone leads to hypernatraemia, hypertension and headache.</p>
<p>The treatment of hyperaldosteronism involves surgery, potassium supplements and sodium restriction. Nursing care involves assessing the patient and instituting interventions for hypokalaemia. These were covered under electrolyte imbalance. Maintenance therapy of the hormones may be given after adrenalectomy, that is, the removal of the adrenal gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diabetes-insipidus-and-syndrome-of-inappropriate-secretion-of-anti-diuretic-hormone-siadh">Diabetes Insipidus and Syndrome of Inappropriate Secretion of Anti-diuretic Hormone (SIADH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetes-insipidus-and-syndrome-of-inappropriate-secretion-of-anti-diuretic-hormone-siadh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Diabetes insipidus results from a lack or a deficiency of ADH. The patient will present with polyuria and polydipsia, accompanied by hemoconcentration. It is managed by rehydration and electrolyte replacement.</p>
<p>On the other hand, SIADH is due to over-secretion of ADH and the patient presents with hemodilution, and decreased urinary output. These two conditions may be the result of an</p>
<p>injury or infection to the brain, pituitary and/or hypothalamus.</p>
<p>In SIADH the nursing interventions that you should put in place include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Restriction of fluid intake and maintenance of electrolyte balance</li>
<li>Good positioning to enhance venous return</li>
<li>Frequent patient turning to avoid dependent oedema leading to pressure ulcers</li>
<li>Anti-seizure precautions because of the possibility of brain oedema and raised intracranial pressure</li>
<li>Assistance with ambulation and provision of hygiene</li>
</ul>
<p>The main goal of nursing intervention should be the restoration of fluid balance.</p>
<p>We have learnt that hyperfunction of the anterior pituitary may result in acromegally. This requires surgery to the pituitary gland. The pre and post-operative management will follow that of the patient undergoing intracranial surgery.</p>
<p>For the patient who undergoes surgery, hormone replacement therapy may be instituted afterwards. Radiation and drugs may be used to counter the effects of growth hormone. Meanwhile, treatment of hypopituitarism consists of surgery for tumour removal, permanent hormone replacement and a dietary plan to target nutritional deficiencies.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-disorders">Adrenal Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adrenocortical insufficiency results in Addison's disease. This disease may be a result of an auto immune reaction or an infection which leads to hypofunction of the adrenal glands.</p>
<p>Addison's disease results in muscle weakness, loss of appetite and hypotension. The disease can be accelerated by stress and infections, resulting in what is referred to as Addison's crisis, which manifests as extreme weakness, severe hypotension, hypoglycemia, vomiting, diarrhoea and coma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-adult-with-addison-s-crisis">Care of the Adult with Addison's Crisis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-with-addison-s-crisis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The adult with Addison's crisis requires urgent assessment to ensure that the life-threatening manifestations such as hypoglycemia are managed. The main management will be supportive while investigations take place and, later, hormonal replacement may be considered.</p>
<p>When there is adrenal insufficiency, patients may receive steroid therapy. These steroids have some adverse effects.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-management-of-adrenocortical-insufficiency">General Management of Adrenocortical Insufficiency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-management-of-adrenocortical-insufficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You have learnt that adrenocortical insufficiency can result from the hypofunction of the gland, Addison's disease or the deficiency of corticosteroids and adrogens. When a patient with Addison's disease is hospitalised, vital signs and signs of fluid volume deficit should be monitored in addition to electrolyte imbalance. In addition, daily weights, diligent steroid administration, protection against exposure to infection and assistance with daily hygiene should be part of the management. This patient needs to be protected from noise, light and environmental temperature.</p>
<p>In the long term, the patient must learn about chronic use of steroids. The goals of nursing for this patient, therefore, should involve managing selfcare, relief of symptoms, adjusting medication to personal life situation, avoiding insufficiency and actively participating in the long-term treatment plan.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 152 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-456d2637.jpeg" alt="img-37.jpeg"></p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 153 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>For patients who have to undertake the long-term use of corticosteroids, interventions that are necessary include a diet high in protein, calcium and potassium but low in fat.</p>
<p>Other measures include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Sleep and rest and avoidance of caffeine</li>
<li>Restriction of sodium and avoidance of oedema</li>
<li>Blood sugar monitoring</li>
<li>Frequent eye examination to avoid cataracts.</li>
<li>General safety measures to avoid injury and good personal hygiene</li>
<li>Activity to avoid muscle atrophy</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypersecretion">Hypersecretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypersecretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hypersecretion from the adrenal cortex can result in adrenogenital syndrome and Cushing's syndrome.</p>
<p>In adrenogenital syndrome, boys get premature (precocious) puberty and girls acquire male sexual characteristics.</p>
<p>If hypersecretion occurs in adulthood, women have musculinisation with atrophy of breasts and enlargement of the clitoris.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cushing-s-syndrome">Cushing's Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cushing-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cushing's syndrome is a result of excessive corticosteroids, particularly glucocorticoids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The patient presents with several features which can be seen in most body parts. Glucocorticoids causes pronounced changes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Weight gain is the most common feature resulting from accumulation of adipose tissue in the trunk, face (main face) and cervical area (buffalo hump).</li>
<li>Glucose intolerance because of cortisol induced insulin resistance and increased gluconeogenesis.</li>
<li>Muscle wasting leading to muscle weakness especially in the extremities.</li>
<li>Increased calcium resorption and inhibited collagen synthesis leads to pathological fractures, bone and back pain.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mineralocorticoids:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>In excess may cause hypertension</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>In excess may cause acne and feminisation in men</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Menstruation disorders and impotence from adrenal carcinoma</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-the-adult-with-cushing-s-syndrome">Management of the Adult with Cushing's Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-the-adult-with-cushing-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Medications:
This is required before surgery or radiation in cases where Cushing's syndrome results from pituitary tumor. Or in the case of inoperable pituitary or adrenal malignancies.</li>
</ul>
<p>The aim is to control the symptoms and examples of drugs used include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Mitotane - Used in adrenal cancer directly suppresses activity of adrenal cortex</li>
<li>Metyrapone or Ketoconazole (or both) inhibits cortisol synthesis</li>
<li>Somatostatis (octreatide) suppresses ACTH secretion</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="surgery">Surgery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Adrenalectomy is done if the disease is caused by adrenal cortex tumour (only one is usually involved)</li>
<li>Bilateral adrenalectomy is done for an ACTH producing ectopic tumour</li>
<li>Surgical removal of the pituitary gland is indicated if there is a pituitary disorder (Refer to nursing care of a patient after cranial surgery)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-adult-with-cushing-s-syndrome">Care of the Adult with Cushing's Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-with-cushing-s-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You learned that Cushing's syndrome is a result of high corticosteroids secretion. This may result from prolonged administration of high doses of corticosteroids, ACTH secreting pituitary tumour, cortisol secreting tumour within the adrenal cortex and secretion of ACTH from carcinoma of the lungs.</p>
<p>Therapeutic management involves adrenal cortical adenoma, carcinoma or hyperplasia removal. Pre-operative or post-operative management will, therefore, be necessary. Administration of steroids may also be undertaken. The specific nursing management includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Vital signs monitoring</li>
<li>Taking and recording daily weights</li>
<li>Monitoring for signs of infection, abdominal pain, thromboembolic phenomena, bone pain and arthritis</li>
<li>Glucose monitoring</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Management of mental status especially depression</li>
</ul>
<p>For the patient due for adrenalectomy, glucose and blood pressure monitoring is necessary. The patient requires a high protein meal before surgery. IV fluids, nasograstic suctioning, high doses of cortisone, close monitoring of vital functions are very critical in the immediate post-operative period. Always be alert for signs of glucocorticoid imbalance. Bed rest is important until blood pressure stabilises. Infection prevention should not be forgotten.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thyroid-disorders">Thyroid Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyroid-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Thyroid disorders are manifested as hyperfunction (thyrotoxicosis), hypofunction, inflammation or enlargement. Two thyroid disorders are Goitre and Hyperthyroidism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="goitre">Goitre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#goitre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an enlargement of the thyroid gland. It may be caused by a variety of factors, including hypofunction and tumours. Hypothyroidism, when occurring in infancy, can produce cretinism. Individuals with cretinism will have a vacant expression, protruding tongue and physical and mental retardation. The physical retardation is what we refer to as dwarfism. Myxoedema is the manifestation of hypothyroidism in adults. Patients have oedema of the skin, and a slowing down of mental and physical activity. There is normally intolerance to cold, muscle weakness, hoarse voice and weight gain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-goitre">Types of Goitre<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-goitre" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Simple goitre - There is no clear cause for enlargement of the thyroid which is usually smooth and soft.</li>
<li>Multiple nodular goitre - Is the most common especially in older patients. It's the most common cause of tracheal and oesophageal compression and may cause laryngeal nerve palsy.</li>
<li>Solitary nodular goitre (Plummers syndrome) - They are usually cystic or benign with a history of pain, rapid enlargement or associated lymph nodes.</li>
<li>Fibrotic goitre (Riedel's thyroiditis) - Rare condition which is irregular and hard producing a 'woody' gland. It is often difficult to distinguish from carcinoma.</li>
<li>Malignancy - It's a rare condition in the thyroid.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes">Causes:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypertrophy caused by excess stimulation</li>
<li>Growth stimulating immunoglobulins</li>
<li>Goitrogens which inhibit synthesis of thyroid hormone only in individuals who live in an iodine deficient area</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Majority are painless but pain or discomfort can occur in acute cases</li>
<li>Diffuse or nodular goitre can cause dysphagia and difficulty in breathing, this may also result into oesophageal or tracheal compression</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="investigations">Investigations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#investigations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Thyroid function tests of thyroid stimulating hormone, thyroxine and thiodothyronine to determine whether a goitre is associated with hyperthyroidism, hypothyroidism or normal thyroid function.</li>
<li>Chest and thoracic inlet x-rays to detect tracheal compression.</li>
<li>Measurement of thyroid antibodies to assess for thyroiditis.</li>
<li>Ultrasound to demonstrate whether the nodules are cystic or solid.</li>
<li>Thyroid scan to determine whether the nodule is malignant.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A goitre associated with normal thyroid function in pregnancy and puberty rarely requires intervention and patient needs to be reassured. Surgery to remove large goitres may be necessary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indications-for-surgical-intervention">Indications for Surgical Intervention<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indications-for-surgical-intervention" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>The possibility of malignancy where there is a history of rapid growth, pain, cervical lymphadenopathy or previous irradiation.</li>
<li>Pressure symptoms on the trachea.</li>
