<li>Cosmetic reasons.</li>
<li>A large goitre may cause anxiety to the patient even if benign.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 156 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="aetiology-and-pathophysiology">Aetiology and pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aetiology-and-pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Nearly 99% of all cases are caused by intrinsic thyroid disease and a pituitary cause is usually rare.</p>
<p>Graves disease (diffuse toxic goitre) is the most common cause and is due to autoimmune process. The patient develops antibodies that stimulate over production of thyroid hormones. Graves' disease is also characterised by remissions and exacerbations and if not treated it may progress to destruction of thyroid tissue causing hypothyroidism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In Grave's disease there is thyroid enlargement, increased metabolic rate, intolerance to heat and nervousness. Patients sweat profusely, there is atrial fibrillation, and loss of weight in the presence of a good appetite.</p>
<p>Nodular goitres which are characterised by small discrete autonomously functioning but not TSH dependent nodule that secretes thyroid hormone. If associated with signs of hyperthyroidism a nodule is termed toxic. Where there are multiple nodules they're called multinodular goitre or single nodule (uninodular goitre, thyroid adenoma).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Serum T4 and T3 are measured with immunoassay techniques and are elevated.</li>
<li>T3 resin uptake (T3RU) is also elevated.</li>
<li>Electrocardiogram (ECG) may show tachycardia, atrial fibrillation and alteration in R and T waves.</li>
<li>In non pregnant and non lactating patients 24 hour radioactive iodine uptake may be done.</li>
</ul>
<p>Toxic Nodular Goitre is more severe and patients have exophthalmos. Sometimes patients with thyrotoxicosis can also present with a thyroid crisis in which the symptoms are similar to those of thyrotoxicosis but more severe and acute.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="drug-therapy-of-hyperthyroidism">Drug Therapy of Hyperthyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drug-therapy-of-hyperthyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The most commonly used drugs are:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Antithyroid drugs like Thionamides, propylthiouracil (PTU) or carbimazole and methimazole (Tapazol). These drugs inhibit the synthesis of the thyroid hormones. Propylthiouracil also blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Improvement usually begins one to two weeks after initiation of treatment. Therapy is continued for six months to two years.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Iodine administered in large doses inhibits synthesis of active thyroid hormones and blocks the release of the hormone into circulation e.g solution of potassium iodide.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>B-adrenergic Blockers such as Propranol or Inderal is most frequently used. It relieves the symptoms of thyrotoxicosis, arrhythmias and hypertension.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Also administer digoxin to prevent heart failure.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If surgery is to be performed propylthiouracil with iodine therapy added for 10 days before surgery is recommended.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Radioactive iodine-limits thyroid hormone secretions by damaging or destroying thyroid tissue.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hyperthyroidism">Hyperthyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperthyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This condition is also referred to as thyrotoxicosis (or thyroid overactivity). It is defined as sustained increased synthesis and release of thyroid hormones by the thyroid gland. It affects about 2-5% of all females between ages 20 and 40 years. It occurs as primary hyperthyroidism, also called Grave's disease, or as secondary hyperthyroidism, also called Toxic nodular Goitre.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypothyroidism-myxoedema">Hypothyroidism Myxoedema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypothyroidism-myxoedema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Is a disorder that results when the thyroid gland produces an insufficient amount of thyroid hormones. It is more common in women between ages 30 - 60 but the disorder can occur at any stage of life.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-hypothyroidism">Types of Hypothyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-hypothyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hypothyroidism may be either primary or secondary.</p>
<p>Primary Hypothyroidism is more common and may be caused by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Congenital defects in the gland</li>
<li>Loss of thyroid following treatment for hyperthyroidism with surgery or radiation</li>
<li>Antithyroid medication</li>
<li>Thyroiditis</li>
<li>Endemic ion deficiency</li>
</ul>
<p>Secondary Hypothyroidism may result from:</p>
<ul>
<li>Pituitary thyroid stimulating hormone deficiency</li>
<li>Peripheral resistance to thyroid hormones</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the thyroid hormone production decreases, the thyroid gland enlarges in a compensatory attempt to produce more hormones. The goitre that results is usually a simple or non toxic form. People living in areas where the soil is deficient in iodine are one prone to become hypothyroid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypothyroidism affects all body systems</li>
<li>Endocrine - goitre</li>
<li>Neurological - Lethargy, confusion, slow speech and memory impairment</li>
<li>Respiratory - Pleural effusion</li>
<li>Cardiovascular - hypotension, body cardia, enlarged heart and anaemia</li>
<li>Gastrointestinal - Constipation</li>
<li>Musculoskeletal - Muscle stiffness, weakness, fatigue</li>
<li>Reproductive - Menorrhagia (female), infertility (female), reduced libido (male)</li>
<li>Integumentary - hair loss, brittle nails, coarse dry skin and non-pitting oedema</li>
<li>Metabolic Processes - hypothermia, anorexia, weight gain, systemic oedema</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-hypothyroidism">Management of Hypothyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-hypothyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hypothyroidism is treated with an objective of restoring a normal metabolic rate. For this purpose, administration of the thyroid hormone (Levothyroxine, liotrix or thyroid extract) is one of the main treatment measures. At the time of administration, you must be on the lookout and observe for diuresis, exaggerated reflexes and high pulse rate. In severe hypothyroidism, you should endeavour to maintain vital functions through monitoring blood gases, assisted ventilation, monitoring fluid intake, replacement of the thyroid hormone and treating the precipitating factors.</p>
<p>Hospitalising the patient if they are in thyroid storm/crisis, administering sedatives and giving vitamin supplements can be used in the management of hyperthyroidism. Other drugs administered are digoxin for heart failure and propranolol (inderal) for arrhythmias and hypertension. Anti-thyroid drugs, including methimazole (Topazol) and Propylthiouracil, are also given.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-hyperthyroidism">Management of Hyperthyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-hyperthyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The patient is nursed using the nursing process. The therapeutic goals are to block the adverse effects of thyroid hormones and stop their over secretion. The choice of treatment is influenced by the patient's age, severity of the disorder, complicating features and patients preferences. Management involves drug therapy with antithyroid medication, use of B-adrenergic blockers, radioactive iodine and subtotal thyroidectomy</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="drug-therapy-of-hyperthyroidism">Drug Therapy of Hyperthyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#drug-therapy-of-hyperthyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The most commonly used drugs are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Antithyroid drugs like Thionamides, propylthiouracil (PTU) or carbimazole and methimazole (Tapazol). These drugs inhibit the synthesis of the thyroid hormones. Propylthiouracil also blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Improvement usually begins one to two weeks after initiation of treatment. Therapy is continued for six months to two years.</li>
<li>Iodine administered in large doses inhibits synthesis of active thyroid hormones and blocks the release of the hormone into circulation e.g solution of potassium iodide.</li>
<li>B-adrenergic Blockers such as Propranol or Inderal is most frequently used. It relieves the symptoms of thyrotoxicosis, arrhythmias and hypertension.</li>
<li>Also administer digoxin to prevent heart failure.</li>
<li>If surgery is to be performed propylthiouracil with iodine therapy added for 10 days before surgery is recommended.</li>
<li>Radioactive iodine-limits thyroid hormone secretions by damaging or destroying thyroid tissue.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nutritional-therapy">Nutritional Therapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutritional-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>High caloric diet of 4000 to 5000kcal per day to satisfy hunger and prevent tissue breakdown.</li>
<li>Protein allowed in a meal should be 1 to 2g/kg of ideal body weight.</li>
<li>Increased carbohydrate is required to compensate for disturbed metabolism, provide energy and spare protein.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nutritional-therapy">Nutritional Therapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutritional-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>High seasoned and high fibre diet should be avoided because it stimulates the already hyperactive gastrointestinal</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>tract. Subtotal thyroidectomy should be performed only in patients who have been previously on medication. Antithyroid drug is stopped 10-14 days before operation and instead patient is given potassium iodide 100mg three times daily. This reduces the vascularity of the gland.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="particular-indications-for-surgery">Particular indications for surgery:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#particular-indications-for-surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Patients choice</li>
<li>A large goiter unlikely to respond to antithyroid medication</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indications-for-either-surgery-or-radioactive-treatment-are">Indications for either surgery or radioactive treatment are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indications-for-either-surgery-or-radioactive-treatment-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Persistent drug side effects</li>
<li>Poor compliance with drug therapy</li>
<li>Recurrent hyperthyroidism after drugs</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-thyroid-disorders">Management of Thyroid Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-thyroid-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Once there is indication for surgery the patient must be adequately prepared pre-operatively to avoid post-operative complications.</p>
<p>All patients with hyperthyroid states require a calm and quiet environment. You will now look at the care of the adult undergoing thyroidectomy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-patient-undergoing-thyroidectomy">Care of the Patient Undergoing Thyroidectomy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-patient-undergoing-thyroidectomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The following steps should be taken when providing pre-operative care:</p>
<ul>
<li>Provide a restful, quiet environment.</li>
<li>Regulate nutritional intake, that is, food should be high in carbohydrate and protein.</li>
<li>Support the patient during investigations.</li>
<li>Prepare the patient for surgery by sharing information, giving instructions on what to expect, consent and pre-medication.</li>
<li>Signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis must be alleviated and cardiac problems must be controlled.</li>
<li>The patient must be assessed for signs such as swelling of buccal mucousa and other mucous membranes, excessive salivation, nausea and vomiting and skin reactions. If toxicity occurs iodine administration should be discounted and doctor notified.</li>
<li>Pre-operative teaching should include comfort and safety measures. Coughing and deep breathing exercises should be practiced including how to support the neck manually while turning in bed because this</li>
</ul>
<p>minimises stress on the suture line after surgery and exercises of the neck.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-operatively">Post-operatively<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-operatively" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When providing post-operative care for the patient who has undergone a thyroidectomy, you should ensure that you:</p>
<ul>
<li>Oxygen, suction equipment and a tracheostomy tray are readily available in case airway obstruction occurs. Place patient in Fowler's position and support head with pillows</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-operatively">Post-operatively<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-operatively" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Assess patient every two hours for 24 hours for signs of haemorrhage or tracheal compression e.g. irregular breathing, neck swelling, blood on the anterior and posterior dressing.</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs temperature, pulse, respiration and blood pressure</li>
<li>Check for signs of tetany secondary to hypothyroidism e.g. tingling in toes, fingers or around mouth, muscular twitching.</li>
<li>Ensure control of postoperative pain by giving medications.</li>
<li>Reassure the patient that some hoarseness is expected for three to four days after surgery because of oedema.</li>
<li>Neck exercises should be performed three or four times daily to promote comfort and return of full range of motion.</li>
<li>Fluids are administered as soon as the patient can tolerate them and soft diet is introduced by the second day.</li>
<li>If the patient progresses well post-operatively ambulation is encouraged on the first day.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-include">Complications include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Thyrotoxicosis crisis (thyroid storm) which is an acute but rare condition in which all the hyperthyroid manifestation are worsened and may include severe tachycardia, heart failure, hyperthermia, restlessness.</li>
<li>Recurrent laryngeal nerve damage which may lead to vocal card paralysis.</li>
<li>Difficulty in breathing due to swelling of neck tissues, haemorrhage, haematoma formation.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Laryngeal stridor (harsh vibratory sound) may occur during respiration due to tetany from damaged or removal of parathyroid.</li>
<li>Early post-operative bleeding</li>
<li>Recurrent hyperthyroidism occurs in 1-3% within one year and then 1% per year</li>
<li>Hypothyroidism occurs in about 10% of patients within one year.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parathyroid-disorders">Parathyroid Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parathyroid-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hyperparathyroidism">Hyperparathyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hyperparathyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This involves secretion of increased levels of parathyroid hormone. We have learnt that this hormone is involved in calcium metabolism. The objective of management is to relieve symptoms and prevent complications. The choice of therapy depends on the urgency of the problem, the degree of hypercalcemia, the underlying disorder, the status of renal and hepatic function, the patient's clinical presentation and the merits of each mode of treatment.</p>
<p>In severe cases, surgery is performed. In less acute cases, conservative management involving close monitoring, high fluid, and moderate calcium, sodium, and phosphorous supplementation are choice actions. Diuretics may also be administered. Diuretic medication will act on the kidney to cause fluid loss and hence lower the possibility of kidney stone formation. One of the drugs used as a diuretic is Frusemide (e.g. lasix). Some drugs, for example, mithramycin lower serum calcium. Oestrogen therapy for post-menopausal women can also be helpful. Strict monitoring of intake and output and levels of calcium, potassium and phosphate are necessary.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="hypoparathyroidism">Hypoparathyroidism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypoparathyroidism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>In hypoparathyroidism, the main objectives of treatment are to treat tetany when present and prevent long-term complications of low calcium levels in plasma. IV calcium gluconate and vitamin D are used in this case.</p>
<p>Digitalisation and the use of side rails are important nursing alerts to prevent cardiac arrest and falls during tetany. Anti-seizure precautions should be instituted.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diabetes-mellitus">Diabetes Mellitus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>You learnt that insulin is a hormone involved in glucose metabolism. The other hormones involved in glucose metabolism are glucagon, adrenaline, growth hormone and somatotrophin. Try to remember them and their functions.</p>
<p>Diabetes mellitus can be divided into:</p>
<ul>
<li>Type I or Insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus (IDDM).</li>
<li>Type II or Non-insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus (NIDDM).</li>
<li>Type III, due to excessive corticosteroids, for example in Cushing's syndrome or over enthusiastic treatment of addison's disease with corticosteroids</li>
<li>Type IV, also called gestational diabetes. It's due to the presence of a hormone called human placental lactogen, which antagonises the effects of insulin.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-diabetes-mellitus">Management of Diabetes Mellitus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the management of diabetes mellitus, the goals are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maintenance of a near-normal blood glucose level as possible</li>
<li>Achievement of optimal serum lipids</li>
<li>Provision of adequate calories for attaining reasonable weight</li>
<li>Prevention and treatment of complications</li>
<li>Avoidance of hypoglycaemia</li>
</ul>
<p>The three modalities utilised in the management are drugs, including insulin and oral hypoglycaemic drugs such as diabenese, diet and exercise. These three have to be well balanced to avoid complications. Patient education is also important to decrease complications. Patients require education, which cover medication, injection sites, use of foods, blood glucose monitoring, exercise and activity home management and lifestyle improvement.</p>
<p>Both short-term and long-term complications may arise. Short-term complications include hyperglycemia, hypoglycaemia, ulcers, and coma, while long-term effects are nephropathies (kidney involvement), neuropathies (involvement of the nervous system) and visual problems.</p>
<p>Administering oxygen, establishing IV access, determining blood sugar levels and monitoring vital signs manage Ketoacidosis. IV glucose and glucagon can also be administered as necessary.</p>
<p>Hyperosmolar nonketosis is treated with IV fluids and insulin. Electrolyte and vital signs are then</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>closely monitored. Micro-vascular complications are best treated by preventive measures. Care of the eyes, care of the feet and avoiding injurious substances to the kidney will improve the patient's life.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="type-i-diabetes">Type I Diabetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-i-diabetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This type of diabetes has no clearly known cause. It is thought that some individuals have antibodies against cells producing insulin. It is also thought that hypersensitivity reactions may destroy the part of the pancreas involved in secretion of the hormones (the Islets of Langerhans). In this disorder, patients do not produce their own insulin. Hyperglycemia, ketoacidosis, polyuria and polydipsia, and loss of weight are characteristic manifestations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="type-ii-diabetes">Type II Diabetes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-ii-diabetes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Individuals with Type II diabetes have insulin, which may be low, normal or high, but they may have insulin resistance. In Type II diabetes, there is glycosuria (sugar in urine) and hyperglycaemia. It can complicate with hyperosmolar non-ketosis with or without coma, susceptibility to infection, vascular, renal and ophthalmic disorders. Some of the patients with Type II diabetes may be obese. Type II diabetic patients can generally be well managed throughout their lives</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-4-digestive-system">SECTION 4: DIGESTIVE SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-4-digestive-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This section is about the structure and function of the digestive system. This system consists of the gastrointestinal tract and accessory organs of digestion which include the liver, gall bladder and pancreas.</p>
<p>The management of adults with disorders of the digestive system and associated organs will also be covered.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-e502bf67.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg">
The Digestive System</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>At the end of this section you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the structure and function of the digestive system</li>
<li>Describe the function of the accessory structures of digestion</li>
<li>Describe food metabolism</li>
<li>Describe the disorders of the digestive organs and associated organs</li>
<li>Utilise the nursing process in the management of adults with disorders of the digestive system and associated organs</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-gastrointestinal-tract">The Gastrointestinal Tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-gastrointestinal-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The gastrointestinal tract is a long tubular structure, which starts at the mouth and ends at the anus. The walls of the tract from the oesophagus onwards form four layers of tissues. The layers are the adventitia or outer covering, muscle layer, submucous layer, and mucous membrane lining. The tract is well supplied with nerves and blood vessels.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-mouth">The Mouth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-mouth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is also called the oral cavity. Food taken in is chewed and mixed with saliva that contains the enzyme amylase (ptyalin). The tongue, which performs taste functions, turns the food in</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>the mouth that is called mastication and also assists in swallowing.</p>
<p>The pharynx is also involved in food swallowing before the food moves into the oesophagus</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pharynx">The Pharynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a tube like passageway about 12-14cm that connects the mouth and oesophagus and is important in swallowing.</p>
<p>As food and fluids pass through the pharynx into the oesophagus the trachea is closed by the epiglottis to prevent aspiration into the lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-oesophagus">The Oesophagus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-oesophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a pliable muscular structure approximately 25cm long that extends from the pharynx to the cardiac end of the stomach. Swallowed food is propelled to the stomach by peristalsis (sequential contraction and relaxation of outer longitudinal and inner circulation layers of muscles). It is the presence of food in the pharynx which triggers peristalsis.</p>
<p>The oesophagus has a lower sphincter, which prevents regurgitation of food. Food is also prevented from regurgitating by the acute angle of attachment of the stomach to the oesophagus via the diaphragm, and increased muscle tone of the oesophageal sphincter.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-stomach">The Stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The stomach is a dilated pouch, which occupies the upper abdomen, and lies slightly to the left. It consists of a fundus, body and antrum. At the lower end, the stomach has a sphincter called the pylorus. There are special secretor glands on the walls of the stomach, which secrete gastric juice. This juice contains enzymes, hydrochloric acid, intrinsic factor, mucous, water and mineral salts. The Intrinsic factor is a protein essential for absorption of vitamin B12 which is essential for erythropoiesis (RBC formation). In the stomach a gastric hormone is also manufactured and this hormone regulates enzyme production to facilitate digestion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-stomach">Functions of the Stomach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Temporary reservoir</li>
<li>Production of gastric juice</li>
<li>Absorbing water, vitamins and alcohol</li>
<li>Moving the food into the next point in the digestion process, which is the intestine</li>
</ul>
<p>To be able to understand the functions of the stomach in more detail, read further on gastric motility, gastric emptying and gastric secretion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-gastric-juice">Functions of the Gastric Juice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-gastric-juice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Liquifying of food by the water</li>
<li>Digestion, where hydrochloric acid acidifies the food and stops action of ptyalin that comes with saliva, kills micro-organisms and provides an environment for digestion of proteins by the pepsin</li>
<li>Assisting in absorption of vitamin B12 through intrinsic factor</li>
<li>Mucus, which prevents autodigestion by the hydrochloric acid</li>
<li>Lubricating the contents</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-small-intestines">The Small Intestines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-small-intestines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a tube about 5m long, which is divided into three parts: the duodenum, at which the pancreatic duct and common bile duct open, the jejunum which is the middle part, and the ileum. The intestines have four layers as you saw earlier.</p>
<p>The mucous membrane has folds and finger-like projections called the villi. These increase the surface area for absorption. This part of the GastroIntestinal Tract (GIT) is involved in continuing the movement of the food as it gets absorbed. Digestion (the actual chemical breakdown of food) also takes place here, as does the secretion of certain hormones. These hormones are cholecystokinin, pancreozymin and secretin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-large-intestines">The Large Intestines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-large-intestines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The small intestine gives way to the large intestine, that is, the colon, the rectum and anal canal. The colon is divided into the caecum, ascending colon, transverse colon, descending colon and sigmoid colon. From the caecum is the blind-ended tube, the appendix, which has no known function. The rectum and anus are the distal ends of the gastrointestinal tracts. The anus has an internal sphincter, which is under autonomic nervous control, and the external sphincter, which is under voluntary control.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-large-intestines">Functions of the Large Intestines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-large-intestines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Absorption</li>
</ul>
<p>An important function of the large intestine is absorption of water and electrolytes e.g. potassium. Absorption of water continues until the familiar semisolid consistency of fences is achieved. Other substances which are also absorbed into the blood capillaries from the large intestine are mineral salts, vitamins and some drugs.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Microbial activity</li>
</ul>
<p>There are micro-organisms which colonise the large intestine and they synthesise vitamin K and folic acid. Examples are Escherichia coli, enterobacter aerogenes, streptococcus faecalis and clostridium perfringens. The micro-organisms also breakdown proteins which were not digested in the small intestines and amino acids which are produced are deaminated and ammonia is transported to the liver for conversion into urea.</p>
<ul>
<li>Mass movement</li>
</ul>
<p>At fairly long intervals (about twice an hour) a strong peristaltic wave sweeps along the transverse colon forcing contents into the descending and sigmoid colons. This mass movement is often precipitated by entry of food into the stomach. This combination of stimulus and response is what is referred to as the gastrocolic reflex.</p>
<p>Associated Structures of the GIT</p>
<p>The associated structures of the digestive tract include the liver, the gall bladder (which is also called the biliary tract) and the pancreas.</p>
<p>The Liver</p>
<p>The liver is the heaviest internal organ in the human body weighing between 1200gm to 1600gm in an adult. It is located under the right diaphragm. It occupies the greater part of the right hypochondriac region, part of the epigastric region and extends into the left hypogastric region.</p>
<p>Most of the liver is enclosed in the peritoneum and has a fibrous capsule, which divides it into the right and left lobes. These are further subdivided into lobules that are composed of rows of hepatic cells. There are sinusoids or capillaries that are located between the rows of cells.</p>
<p>Phagocytic cells called Kupffer cells, which perform phagocytosis of bacteria and toxins, line these sinusoids. There are also bile ducts formed from bile capillaries (the canaliculi), which carry bile secreted by hepatic cells. Blood supply to the liver is by the portal circulatory system.</p>
<p>Functions of the Liver</p>
<ul>
<li>Carbohydrate metabolism - the main function of the liver in carbohydrate metabolism is maintenance of blood glucose concentration. This involves conversion of glucose to glycogen in the presence of insulin and converting liver glycogen back to glucose in the presence of glucagons.</li>
<li>Protein metabolism - In deamination of amino acids, the nitrogen portion is removed and this amino acid breakdown leads to formation of urea, synthesis of plasma proteins and non essential amino acids. Most of the blood clotting factors occur in the liver.</li>
<li>Mononuclear phagocyte functions - This is carried out by Kupffer cells which line the sinusoids and the breakdown of erythrocytes and phagocytosis of microbes occur.</li>
</ul>
<p>When haemoglobin is broken down, bilirubin is formed. Since it is insoluble in water, it is bound to albumin for easy transport to the liver. In this form it is called unconjugated bilirubin. It is then conjugated with glucuronic acid to make it soluble (conjugated) and excreted in bile. The bile contains water, cholesterol, bile salts, pigments and other substances. This bile enters the intestines. Most bilirubin is broken down to stercobilinogen and excreted in faeces. This gives stool its brown colour and characteristic odour. Some small amounts of bilirubin are excreted in urine and the rest is reabsorbed to go back to the liver and begin the process all over. If there is a problem in the excretion of bilirubin, then it may get to the skin and mucous membranes and give a yellow colour.</p>
<ul>
<li>Fat metabolism: Fat is desaturated and converted to a form that can be used by the tissues to provide energy</li>
<li>Production of heat</li>
<li>Detoxification of drugs and noxious substances</li>
<li>Inactivation of hormones such as insulin, glucagon, cortisol, aldosterone, thyroid and sex hormones</li>
<li>Synthesis of vitamin A from carotene</li>
<li>Secretion of bile</li>
<li>Storage of vitamins and ions. Fat soluble vitamins stored in liver are A,D,E,K</li>
</ul>
<p>Water soluble vitamins include riboflavin, niacin, pyridoxine, folic acid</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 162 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>and vitamin B12, ions are ions and copper</p>
<ul>
<li>Metabolism of ethanol</li>
</ul>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-398428c1.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-gall-bladder">The Gall Bladder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-gall-bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The gall bladder and its duct system are called the biliary tract. This is a sac located below the liver. Its function is to concentrate the bile produced by the liver and store it. The ducts begin right from the liver where the inner lobular ducts unite to form the two main right and left hepatic ducts. These also join with the cystic duct from the gall bladder to form the common bile duct that finally enters the duodenum. A sphincter keeps the entry point closed except when stimulated by food present in the gastrointestinal tract. The functions of the gall bladder include storage of bile, adding mucous to bile, concentrating bile and, by contraction, expelling bile.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-9bb80650.jpeg" alt="img-40.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pancreas">The Pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pancreas is a long slender organ that is about 12 to 5cm long. The head of the pancreas is tucked into the curve of the duodenum and its tail touches the spleen. It is divided into lobes and lobules. The pancreas has both exocrine and endocrine functions. By exocrine action, pancreatic enzymes are released to aid in digestion, and by endocrine action the cells of Islets of Langerhans secrete insulin, glucagon and somatostatin hormones. These are hormones you have already learnt about. The pancreatic duct extends the whole length of the pancreas and opens into the duodenum. However, before it opens into the duodenum, it joins the common bile duct to form the Ampulla of the bile duct.</p>
<p><strong>Remember:</strong></p>
<p>The pancreas has the function of producing the pancreatic juice, which aids in the digestion of carbohydrates, proteins and fats.</p>
<p>Some of the pancreatic enzymes include chymotrypsin, peptidase, pancreatic amylase and lipase. Having studied the various structures involved in digestion, you shall now proceed to look at the process of food metabolism.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-95fe8027.jpeg" alt="img-41.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="food-metabolism">Food Metabolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#food-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>You are now going to look at the process of food metabolism by summarising the process of digestion, absorption and utilisation of various food nutrients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="carbohydrates">Carbohydrates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The digestion of carbohydrates begins in the mouth where salivary amylase converts cooked starch into disaccharides. In the stomach, the hydrochloric acid in the gastric juice stops the action of the salivary amylase. In the small intestines, pancreatic juice, which contains amylase, sucrase, maltase and lactase, completes the digestion from disaccharides to monosaccharides, mainly glucose. Glucose is absorbed into capillaries of the villi and transported to the portal circulation to the liver. Insulin and glucagon are involved in the utilisation and storage of glucose.</p>
<p>Carbohydrates are broken down by use of oxygen in aerobic oxidation to liberate energy. In the absence of oxygen, anaerobic respiration takes place. The energy liberated is in the form of Adenosine Triphosphate (ATP). Molecules in the form of lactic acid can also be produced in anaerobic oxidation. The other products include carbon dioxide and water. Excess glucose is stored as fat, or glycogen in the liver.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="proteins">Proteins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#proteins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Protein digestion begins in the stomach where hydrochloric acid in gastric juice works on pepsinogen to make pepsin, which in turn converts all proteins to smaller molecules, the</p>
<p>polypeptides. Then trypsin and chymotrypsin from the pancreatic juice reduce the polypeptides further to dipeptides and tripeptides.</p>
<p>In the small intestines, peptidase converts these into amino acids, which are absorbed and transported to the liver. In the liver the amino acids form albumin, globulin, prothrombin and fibrinogen. You may remember that some of these are utilised in the clotting of blood. Amino acids also aid in cell repair and replacement, production of hormones, enzymes, and antibodies. Deamination is done in the liver to produce urea, which is excreted in urine. Proteins can also provide energy when there is starvation or be deposited as fats after conversion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fat">Fat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Digestion of fat begins in the small intestines where bile salts emulsify fats and pancreatic juice converts fats to fatty acids and glycerol. The digestion is completed in the small intestines.</p>
<p>Fatty acids and glycerol are absorbed and transported to the liver. They can be broken down to produce energy, carbon dioxide and water, or stored. In the process of fat breakdown, ketone bodies are produced which can be excreted in urine or expired in air. An example of a ketone body is acetone.</p>
<p>Fat can also be synthesised from carbohydrates and proteins for storage purposes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vitamins-and-minerals">Vitamins and Minerals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vitamins-and-minerals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Vitamins and minerals form the coenzymes that are so important in chemical reactions. Deficiency of vitamins leads to many nutritional diseases which include: scurvy, rickets, and pellagra.</p>
<p>Minerals make up the electrolytes which were mentioned at the beginning of this unit.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-gastrointestinal-tract">Disorders of the Gastrointestinal Tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-gastrointestinal-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Disorders of the Gastrointestinal Tract include disorders of the mouth, oesophagus, stomach, small and large intestines, liver, gall bladder and the pancreas. You will also read about management and care of patients who suffer from these disorders.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 164 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Disorders of the Mouth</p>
<p>The mouth is the first port of call for food in the body. In the mouth, various disorders can give patients problems. The most common mouth disorder is dental caries. This is destruction of the teeth by bacteria and their products. The process starts with the enamel, and as it progresses, toothache ensues.</p>
<p>Bacterial and fungal infections also affect the mouth. Oral thrush (candidiasis) commonly affects children and immuno-compromised clients. Disorders of the oral cavity are better off prevented. Good oral hygiene is recommended for all individuals. Antifungal medication and betadine gargles are used in the treatment of mouth infections.</p>
<p>Cancer of the oral cavity occurs predominantly in persons with a history of alcohol abuse and smoking. It presents with alteration in taste and later pain.</p>
<p>On examination, the patient will have white patches on the oral mucosa, ulcers and bleeding.</p>
<p>The management includes surgery, radiation and proper nutrition. As the condition proceeds, the patient may require maintenance of a patent airway, fluid, electrolyte and nutrition balance. Frequent saline mouthwash is necessary to relief the dryness. Cysts and other tumours of the oral cavity are also common. These may require the same management.</p>
<p>Disorders of the Oesophagus</p>
<p>There are several disorders that may occur in the oesophagus.</p>
<p>Oesophagitis</p>
<p>Oesophagitis is the inflammation of the oesophagus. It is caused by chemical injury, infections and trauma. Consuming hot and spicy food can cause the injury. Oesophagitis is also caused by reflux of gastric contents. It manifests with heartburn and pain, which is retro-sternal and radiates to the shoulder and the back.</p>
<p>A patient who has oesophagitis would require treatment of the underlying cause, use of antacids and avoidance of foods and substances which can cause limitation. In severe cases, surgery may be undertaken.</p>
<p>General Care of the Adult with Oesophageal Diseases</p>
<p>One of the most common disorders is gastro-oesophageal reflux disease. The measures necessary to prevent reflux are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Eating small frequent meals that are high in protein and low in fat</li>
<li>The patient should not lie down immediately after eating and should elevate the head of the bed</li>
<li>Avoidance of alcohol, smoking and beverages that contain caffeine. These beverages can weaken the lower sphincter and hence contribute to reflux</li>
</ul>
<p>The conservative management includes the above measures in addition to antacids, cholinergic and other drugs that act on the lower oesophageal sphincter to make it firmer. Surgery is always used as a last resort.</p>
<p>Hiatus Hernia</p>
<p>Some individuals have the stomach herniating through the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity. This is referred to as hiatus hernia. The hiatus hernia results in reflux of gastric contents and symptoms like those of oesophagitis will ensue. Congenitally weak muscles, obesity, pregnancy, tight fitting clothes and other conditions that raise the intra abdominal pressure contribute to it. Hiatus hernia leads to gastro-oesophageal reflux disease and the management will entail the same measures. The patient should also avoid constricting clothes and heavy lifting.</p>
<p>Carcinoma of the Oesophagus</p>
<p>Carcinoma of the oesophagus is usually squamous cell carcinoma. It can occur at any level of the oesophageal tract but are most common at the gastro esophageal junction. The pathogenesis of oesophageal carcinoma is facilitated by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Alterations of oesophageal structure and function that permit food and drink to remain in the oesophagus for prolonged periods.</li>
<li>Ulceration and metaplasia caused by oesophageal reflux.</li>
<li>Chronic exposure to irritants such as alcohol and tobacco.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 165 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Risk Factors</p>
<ul>
<li>Tobacco use</li>
<li>Alcoholism</li>
<li>Dietary deficiencies of trace elements and malnutrition associated with poor economic conditions</li>
<li>Reflux oesophagitis</li>
<li>Sliding hiatal hernia</li>
</ul>
<p>Clinical Manifestations</p>
<ul>
<li>Chest pain</li>
<li>Dysphagia - This usually progresses rapidly and swallowing is mostly painless during early stages of oesophageal carcinoma. Initially, dysphagia starts with solid food and eventually with the fluids. This is then followed by a feeling of a lump in the throat, painful swallowing substernal pain or fullness and later regurgitation of undigested food with foul breath and hiccoughs.</li>
</ul>
<p>Diagnosis
This is done by oesophagoscopy with biopsy.</p>
<p>Management
Treatment includes surgery, radiation and chemotherapy.</p>
<p>The patient may be treated by surgical excision of the lesion, radiation or both. Surgery is preferred for lower esophageal tumours whereas irradiation is favoured for upper esophageal lesions.</p>
<p>General Care of the Adult with Oesophageal Diseases
Cancer of the oesophagus (Ca oesophagus) is one of the disorders that you are likely to meet in your practice. Depending on the stage at which it is discovered, the management modalities include: radiation, gastrostomy and simple palliative measures such as dilatation. Gastrostomy is the creation of a stoma into the stomach to assist in delivery of nutrients to the patient. In patients undergoing surgery of the oesophagus, there are several nursing actions that are necessary. They include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maintenance of a patent airway</li>
<li>Monitoring vital functions</li>
<li>Providing oral care</li>
<li>Maintaining nutritional status by providing total parental nutrition, tube feedings, and vitamin and mineral supplements</li>
<li>Those with severe oesophageal disease may also require these actions, even if they have not undergone surgery</li>
</ul>
<p>Prognosis
Mortality among patients with cancer of the esophagus is high owing to three factors:</p>
<ol>
<li>The patient is an older person usually with other disorders e.g. cardiovascular and pulmonary disorders.</li>
<li>Symptoms are more evident when the tumour has invaded surrounding structures.</li>
<li>The unique relation of the oesophagus to the heart and lungs makes the organs easily accessible to extension of the tumor.</li>
</ol>
<p>Diverticuli
These are pouches on the wall of the GIT, which occur as a result of weakness of the muscles. The diverticuli make the patient feel as if the food is sticking in the Oesophagus. They may also contribute to the development of cancer of the oesophagus.</p>
<p>Patients with diverticular disease need to be given blended foods. Surgery may also be indicated and these patients would require pre and post-operative management. Generally pre and post-operative care is the same in most cases.</p>
<p>Gastritis
Gastritis is an inflammatory disorder of the gastric mucosa. This is the mucosa that protects the stomach from the actions of the hydrochloric acid.</p>
<p>Acute gastritis is the irritation of the gastric mucosa by alcohol, bacterial toxins, or acids. The surface epithelium is eroded in a diffuse or localised pattern and erosions are usually superficial. These acids may be hydrochloric acid or from drugs such as aspirin. Antinflammatory drugs cause gastritis perhaps because they inhibit prostaglandins which normally stimulate the secretion of mucous. The onset is insidious and patients begin vomiting with haematemesis and bleeding, if the disease is severe. Normally, the disease is self limiting.</p>
<p>Chronic gastritis on the other hand involves the atrophy of the epithelium in the stomach. This results in less hydrochloric acid being</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>produced. The atrophy may be caused by chronic alcoholism or autoantibodies. This disorder produces pernicious anaemia. This is because the production of intrinsic factor is affected. Hence the absorption of vitamin B12 is affected. The condition also predisposes to gastric ulceration and cancer of the stomach. Clinical manifestations of chronic gastritis include vague abdominal discomfort, epigastric tenderness and bleeding. The management involves removal of the predisposing factors by educating patients on foods and drinks that they should avoid. If severe, surgery may be performed to bypass the diseased area, and deliver nutrients directly into the small intestines.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="peptic-ulcers">Peptic Ulcers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peptic-ulcers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A peptic ulcer is a break/ulceration in the protective mucosal lining of the lower oesophagus, stomach or duodenum. This term encompasses both gastric and duodenal ulcers. Peptic ulcers occur in those areas of the GI tract exposed to HCL acid and the proteolytic enzyme (pepsin).</p>
<p>These can occur in any area of the gastrointestinal tract. They are associated with acid pepsin secretions. The ulcers can occur in the oesophagus, stomach or any part of the intestines particularly the duodenum. May be you have heard of such terms as gastric ulcers, duodenal ulcers and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="risk-factors-for-peptic-ulcer">Risk factors for peptic ulcer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#risk-factors-for-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Smoking</li>
<li>Habitual use of non steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs</li>
<li>Alcohol</li>
<li>Chronic diseases</li>
<li>Infections of the gastric and duodenal mucosa and helicobacter pylori</li>
</ul>
<p>The predisposing factors to peptic ulceration are related to imbalance between acid and pepsin production, and the mucosal barrier. Destruction of the mucosal barrier leads to ulceration. Increased acid-pepsin production is associated with increased numbers of acid producing cells and increased sensitivity of parietal cells to stimuli like alcohol, caffeine and so on.</p>
<p>Lack of gastric secretion inhibition and excessive stimulation of the vagus nerve are also associated with increased stimulation. A gastrin secreting tumour of the pancreas causes the Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Once the gastric juice is produced, it affects the gastric mucosal barrier. The bacteria Helicobacter Pylori has also been associated with peptic ulceration in the stomach. It is thought that once ulceration occurs, the bacteria colonise the ulcer and make the healing process difficult.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="zollinger-ellison-syndrome">Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#zollinger-ellison-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a rare condition caused by a gastric secreting tumour. Gastric acid secretion reaches such levels that ulceration becomes inevitable. The increased gastric secretions cause symptoms related to peptic ulcer. Diarrhoea may result from hypersecretion or from inactivation of intestinal lipase and impaired fat digestion. Diagnosis is based on elevated serum gastric levels.</p>
<p>Proton pump inhibitors are used to control gastric acid secretions.</p>
<p>Uncomplicated peptic ulcer manifests with discomfort and pain, which occurs when the stomach is empty. The pain is at the epigastrium and radiates to the back. Patients can also pass loose tarry stools. The ulcer can complicate with haemorrhage, intestinal obstruction and perforation. You will now learn how to manage this disorder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-peptic-ulcer">Types of Peptic Ulcer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-peptic-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="oesophageal-peptic-ulcers">Oesophageal Peptic Ulcers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oesophageal-peptic-ulcers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These are erosions or ulcerations of oesophageal mucosa which can occur in patients with reflux oesophagitis. Presence of an incompetent lower oesophageal sphincter or hiatal hernia predispose to reflux of acidic gastric contents into the lower portion of the oesophagus, which then causes the erosion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="clinical-manifestations">Clinical Manifestations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-manifestations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Heart burn</li>
<li>Epigastric distress that may radiate to the back or lower abdomen</li>
<li>Oesophageal structure (due to recurrent oesophagitis and replacement of mucosa with scar tissue)</li>
</ul>
