</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-1-respiratory-system">SECTION 1: RESPIRATORY SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-1-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Respiration is a very important body function. It ensures that the oxygen required for the breakdown of materials is delivered to the body tissues and waste gas (carbon dioxide) is excreted.</p>
<p>This process will be covered in detail in this section.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-efa8573d.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>By the end of this section you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the structures and functions of the respiratory system.</li>
<li>Describe respiratory disorders and diseases.</li>
<li>Utilise the nursing process in the management of adults with conditions affecting the respiratory system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-structures-and-functions-of-the-respiratory-system">The Structures and Functions of the Respiratory System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-structures-and-functions-of-the-respiratory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The most important function of the respiratory system is to facilitate intake of air in the body, enabling the gaseous exchange and excretion of waste gases.</p>
<p>The structures of the respiratory system will be divided into upper and lower airways. You will start with the upper airway.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-upper-airway">The Upper Airway<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-upper-airway" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>The job of the upper airway is to filter, moisten and warm air entering the body during respiration. This is done through the mucociliary action of cilia in the upper airway.</p>
<p>The upper part of the respiratory tract consists of the nose and pharynx.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-6c6da989.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-nose">The Nose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-nose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nose has both the functions of respiration and olfaction (to smell). The respiratory function of the nose is the conditioning of the air through warming, filtering, clearing and humidification.</p>
<p>The nasal cavity is divided into two by a septum. The cavity has a roof, a floor, lateral walls and a posterior wall followed by a posterior pharynx. Mucous secreting cells line it. There are openings into the nasal cavity. The anterior nostrils open into the nasal cavity, while posterior naris open from the nasal cavity into the pharynx.</p>
<p>Adjacent to the nasal cavity are air filled cavities located within the bony structure. These are called sinuses. The main sinuses include the maxillary sinuses in the maxillary bone, frontal, sphenoidal and ethmoidal sinuses in the respective bones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-pharynx">The Pharynx<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-pharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pharynx is the tube that extends from the nose at the base of the skull to the 6th cervical vertebra and is 12-14cm long. It is divided into the nasopharynx, the oropharynx and the laryngeopharynx. The eustachian tube from the ear empties into the nasopharynx and, therefore, infection from the ear can also involve the</p>
<p>pharynx and vice versa. There is a mass of lymphoid tissue within the pharynx called the tonsils. The three groups of tonsils are the palatine tonsils, the bilingual tonsils and the pharyngeal tonsils, also referred to as adenoids. The functions of the pharynx include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Passage of air and food. It allows passage of air and food</li>
<li>Taste</li>
<li>Hearing</li>
<li>Protection through presence of lymphatic tissue</li>
<li>Warming and humidification of air</li>
<li>Speech</li>
</ul>
<p>The tonsils filter bacteria from circulating lymph fluid and trap any particles as the inhaled air passes through. Inflammation of the tonsils is referred to as tonsillitis.</p>
<p>The other part of the upper airway is the larynx also known as the voice box. The larynx is a tube made up of cartilage, fibrous membranes and muscles. Its function is to produce sound and also to protect the lower airway from foreign objects.</p>
<p>Finally in the upper airway, there is a triangular space between the vocal cords and the opening of the larynx called the glottis. To have a clear picture of the structure and function of the respiratory tract, please study the diagram on the left.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-lower-air-way">The Lower Air Way<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-lower-air-way" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The lower air way enables gaseous exchange to take place. It consists of the trachea, bronchi, and lungs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trachea">Trachea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trachea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is referred to as the wind pipe and extends from the larynx to the level of the fifth thoracic vertebrate where it bifidates into the left and right bronchus. It is made of the C-shaped cartilages which prevents it from collapsing thus effecting its function of air passage. Its functions, include conditioning of the air, are filtering, warming, and humidifying, removing of particles and mucus through its ciliary function and cough reflex.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bronchi-and-bronchioles">Bronchi and Bronchioles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchi-and-bronchioles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The bronchus sub divides into smaller branches thus forming different lobes of the lung. They further sub-divide to form the bronchioles and respiratory bronchioles. Their main function is to provide air passage and control the amount of</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>air passing through into the alveoli, conditioning of air is maintained as it enters into the alveoli.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-alveoli">The Alveoli<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-alveoli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>At the distal end, the respiratory tract terminates with the blind end of alveolar ducts and alveoli which is a sac like structure where air interchange takes place. Alveoli are well supplied with blood supply to allow for diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide. Surfactant factor is produced here, which is important in maintaining the air sac open.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lungs">Lungs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lungs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The lungs are elastic organs, made up of conducting airways. There are millions of gas exchange units called acini. An acinus is composed of respiratory bronchioles, alveolar ducts and alveoli. This is where the gas exchange takes place.</p>
<p>The lungs are contained within the bony thoracic cage. This comprises the ribs, the sternum and clavicles, spinal column and scapulae. In part one of this unit the topics of support and locomotion were covered. Below the lungs is the diaphragm, which also takes part in the process of respiration. The lungs are enclosed within an elastic membrane called the pleura. The pleura has two parts; the one adjacent to the lungs is called the visceral pleura and the other, adjacent to the thoracic cavity, is called the parietal pleura. In between the two is a space, the pleura space, which has a thin film of serous fluid.</p>
<p>The respiratory tract is generally supplied by blood from the pulmonary and bronchial arteries. Oxygen diffuses into blood in the capillaries from where it is carried to the heart to be pumped to other tissues. The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs for oxygenation while the four pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart for onward delivery to the rest of the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-respiration">Mechanism of Respiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The respiratory centre in the brainstem controls breathing. This is stimulated by an increase in the acidity (pH) of the blood.</p>
<p>Movement of air into and out of the lungs comprises the respiratory cycle. This cycle occurs about 15 times in a minute, and consists of inspiration, expiration and a pause. Pressure differences are created by changes in the</p>
<p>thoracic cavity, which make movement of air into and out of the lungs easier.</p>
<p>Some of the structures, which participate in the movement of the thoracic cavity to create the pressure differences, include the inter-costal muscles and the diaphragm.</p>
<p>During respiration the lungs and passages are never empty. Since exchange of gases takes place only across alveolar ducts, the rest of the passage is called anatomical dead space.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tidal-volume">Tidal Volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tidal-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tidal volume is the amount of air that comes into and out of the lungs with each cycle of respiration. This is normally about 500mls.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="expiratory-reserve-volume">Expiratory Reserve Volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#expiratory-reserve-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) is the largest additional volume of air that can be forcibly expired after a normal inspiration and expiration. ERV is about 1000-1200mls.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inspiratory-reserve-volume">Inspiratory Reserve Volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inspiratory-reserve-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) is the largest additional volume of air that can be forcibly inspired after a normal inspiration. Normal IRV is 3000-3300mls.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="residual-volume">Residual Volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#residual-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Residual volume is that air that cannot be forcibly expired from the lungs. It is normally about 1200mls.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="forced-expiratory-volume">Forced Expiratory Volume<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#forced-expiratory-volume" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Forced expiratory volume is the volume of air that can be forcibly exhaled within a specific time normally 1-3 seconds.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inspiratory-capacity">Inspiratory Capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inspiratory-capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the amount of air that can be inspired with the maximum effort. It consists of tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functional-residual-capacity">Functional Residual Capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functional-residual-capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Functional residual capacity is the amount of air that remains in the air passages and alveoli at the end of a quiet inspiration. This prevents collapse of the alveoli during expiration. It comprises of expiratory reserve volume and the residual volume.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vital-capacity">Vital Capacity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vital-capacity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Vital capacity is the amount of air that can be forcibly expired after forcible inspiration. This varies with the size of the thoracic capacity. It is made up of the tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-e57ac1ae.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg">
Lung Volumes and Capacities</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="general-clinical-features-of-patients-suffering-from-respiratory-conditions">General Clinical Features of Patients Suffering From Respiratory Conditions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#general-clinical-features-of-patients-suffering-from-respiratory-conditions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Patients suffering from conditions that affect the respiratory system will present with various clinical features.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cough">Cough<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cough" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The cough is very common from irritation of respiratory mucosa. The cough reflex protects the patient from accumulation of secretions and irritant substances. Therefore, a cough may arise from inflammation and exudation of secretion or irritation by foreign materials or irritants. A cough may be described as dry, brassy, high pitched, wheezy, hackling, loose or severe.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sputum">Sputum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sputum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This results from over production of secretion which may result from the inflammatory process. Sputum is examined for consistency and colour</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chest-pain">Chest Pain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chest-pain" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This can be associated with pathological process on the affected area. However, note that the lung and viscera have no sensory nerve ending and are unlikely to produce much pain except when parietal plural is affected. It produces sharp pain called pleuric pain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wheeze">Wheeze<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wheeze" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is associated with bronchospasms and constriction of the airway. It is usually heard without the help of a stethoscope and is usually on expiration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hemoptysis">Hemoptysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemoptysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Here, blood may be expectorated with sputum. This ranges from blood stained to hemorrhage. It is usually associated with bronchitis, pulmonary tuberculosis, bronchial asthma, carcinoma of the lung, pulmonary embolism and infarction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clubbing-of-fingers">Clubbing of Fingers<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clubbing-of-fingers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It results from hypoxic lung disease like malignancies or bronchiectasis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cyanosis">Cyanosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cyanosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It appears when circulating haemoglobin carries less oxygen than 2/3 of the expected amount. It can be either central or peripheral.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dyspnoea">Dyspnoea<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dyspnoea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is laboured or breathing in increased lung rigidity and airway resistance. Dyspnoea may lead to tachypnoea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-breathing">Mechanism of Breathing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-breathing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are chemoreceptors in the walls of the aorta and carotid arteries which sense changes in partial pressures of oxygen and carbon dioxide. These will determine the rate of breathing. For example, now while you are seated reading, you breathe quietly. However, if you stop reading and start doing some exercise, the breathing will become faster and deeper in response to the need for more oxygen and to get rid of carbon dioxide.</p>
<p>Now, take a deep breath and make a mental note of how your ribs and diaphragm move.</p>
<p>While you are breathing quietly, you are using your inter-costal muscles and diaphragm. In difficult breathing accessory muscles, such as the abdominal muscles, may be used.</p>
<p>Following phrenic nerve stimulation, the diaphragm and respiratory muscles will start to contract. The thoracic cavity increases; the lungs follow the move and begin to expand. Air rushes from positive pressure outside to negative pressure in the lungs. The inspiration is completed and expiration starts with the reverse process.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="control-of-respiration">Control of Respiration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#control-of-respiration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Alveolar stretch receptors on the walls of the lungs send messages to the brain to prevent over distension of the lungs. Blood pH stimulates the respiratory centre directly. Blood pCO2 and pO2 stimulate receptors to control the rate of breathing.</p>
<p>In the body tissues, gas exchange occurs by diffusion from high concentration to low concentration. Oxygen binds to haemoglobin to be transported to tissues for use in producing energy.</p>
<p>You will now look at the disorders affecting the respiratory function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-disorders">Respiratory Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="disorders-of-the-upper-respiratory-tract">Disorders of the Upper Respiratory Tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-upper-respiratory-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Many of the patients you have been nursing may have been suffering from upper respiratory tract infections. Others may also have had inflammation, trauma or tumours.</p>
<p>Another common disorder, especially among young people, is epistaxis. This is nose bleeding. The most common causes of epistaxis are trauma, infection, tumours and high blood pressure.</p>
<p>Foreign objects inserted accidentally can cause airway obstruction, which you should treat as an emergency.</p>
<p>You will start by learning about respiratory tract infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="upper-respiratory-tract-infections">Upper Respiratory Tract Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#upper-respiratory-tract-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The upper respiratory tract often falls victim to viral infections. The most common viral infections are pharyngitis, tracheitis, tonsilitis, laryngotracheobronchitis and influenza. These infections are common in children in whom they cause serious illnesses. Even the common cold is a viral infection. Viral infections cause inflammation resulting in congestion and watery exudate formation. In adults these conditions do not cause very serious illnesses unless the individual's immunity is compromised.</p>
<p>The management of infections involves use of antibiotics, control of fever, and relief of discomfort</p>
<p>The nose is part of the respiratory system. Nasal polyps can affect it. These are small masses that protrude into the cavity. Their cause is not clear but chronic inflammation is thought to be a risk factor.</p>
<p>Allergic rhinitis is commonly associated with allergens such as pollen, animal fur and dust. Patients have frequent sneezing, running nose and nasal blockage.</p>
<p>Acute sinusitis is an inflammation of the sinuses. Microorganisms that spread from the adjacent nose and pharynx commonly bring about the inflammation. There follows congestion, blocking the drainage from the structures. This results in dull pain over the affected sinus, fever and sometimes purulent discharge, if there is communication with the nasal passages. Sinusitis can become chronic if not well managed.</p>
<p>Acute pharyngitis accompanies common colds. The infection causes inflammation resulting in congestion. The infection can spread to the nose and sinuses. Laryngitis and tracheitis are the other infections that affect the upper respiratory tract mostly due to trauma, foreign bodies or infection. The trachea may be accessed via an endo-tracheal tube. This is inserted to open an airway for emergency resuscitation or to deliver anaesthetic gases.</p>
<p>Tonsillitis is another common inflammation. It affects the tonsils. It can be acute or chronic. Streptococcus pyogenes and some viruses commonly cause the inflammation of the tonsils. Other micro-organisms that can affect the tonsils are Staphylococci and Haemophilus influenza. Tumours are rare in the upper respiratory tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-adults-with-upper-respiratory-tract-disorders">Care of Adults with Upper Respiratory Tract Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-adults-with-upper-respiratory-tract-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="epistaxis">Epistaxis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epistaxis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is nose bleeding. The most common causes of nose bleeding include trauma especially picking of nose, infection, tumours and high blood pressure. Bleeding is caused by the rupture of tiny blood vessels in the mucus membrane. It may also occur as a sign of rheumatic fever.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>For a patient with epistaxis, which manifests quite often in our communities, simple first aid means may be effective in stopping the bleeding. It is important to keep the patient quiet. Place them in a sitting position, leaning forwards or reclining with head and shoulders elevated. You can apply pressure by pinching the lower portion of the nose for 10-15 minutes. Apply ice, if it is available, to try and stop the bleeding. Partially insert small gauze and call for more help. If first aid is not effective, management involves application of vaso-constrictive agents</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>or cauterisation. If after packing the patients require oxygen, then it should be given. Mouth care and antibiotics will decrease the possibility of toxic shock syndrome.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rhinitis">Rhinitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rhinitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Rhinitis is the inflammation of the mucus membrane of the nose. It could be as a result of infection or allergic reaction. When the cause is allergy, it is referred to as allergic rhinitis. Rhinitis can be caused by infections that could be bacterial or viral, the most common being viral. Rhinitis causes inflammation of the nasal mucosa, leading it to become congested, swollen and oedematous. This leads to an increase in nasal discharge and in cases of bacterial infection this could be a thick nasal discharge. This is then referred to as acute rhinitis. Recovery may follow after a few days.</p>
<p>Repeated attacks lead to deposition of abnormally large connective tissue in the nasal mucus membrane leading to thickening and hypertrophy. This causes formation of spurs and polyps on the nasal septum. There could be excessive exudation leading to atrophic rhinitis. Patients present with frequent sneezing, running nose, pulurent discharge and nasal blockage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pharyngitis">Pharyngitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pharyngitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the inflammation of the pharynx which commonly accompanies the common cold. It is caused by several viruses and bacteria. The throat becomes inflamed leading to the mucus membrane becoming fiery red. The lymphoid tissue including the tonsils become swollen with exudation.</p>
<p>Uncomplicated pharyngitis resolves in 3-5 days, while complicated pharyngitis may cause otitis media, sinusitis, mastoiditis, rheumatic fever, nephritis and adenitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>For uncomplicated pharyngitis, a lot of fluids are recommended with saline, antimicrobial, antifungal gargles. Intravenous fluids are recommended if one is not able to take them orally. Liquid diet is given due to discomfort in swallowing. Bacterial infections are treated with antibiotics. Staphylococcal and streptococcal infections are treated with penicillins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laryngitis">Laryngitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laryngitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the inflammation of the larynx. It may be caused by use of irritants, abuse in use of voice</p>
<p>or infection. Bacteria infections are usually secondary to viral infection.</p>
<p>Causes include exposure to low temperatures, malnutrition, low immunity and dietary deficiencies.</p>
<p>Laryngitis presents with hoarseness or complete loss of voice (aphonia), severe cough and general malaise.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-laryngitis">Management of Laryngitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-laryngitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Irritants like tobacco smoking must be avoided.</li>
<li>Steam inhalation or aerosol therapy is important to sooth the mucus membrane and facilitate drainage of mucus secretions.</li>
<li>Anti bacterial therapy is done where bacterial infections have been suspected.</li>
<li>Rest of the voice promotes healing. This is done in a well humidified environment.</li>
<li>Plenty of fluids must be given to replace lost fluids and to thin the secretions.</li>
<li>Steroids could be beneficial in reducing inflammation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sinusitis">Sinusitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sinusitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This refers to the blockage of the nasal sinus by either inflammation or hypertrophy of the mucosa. It may affect one or more of the four sinuses.</p>
<p>The main causes include obstruction by nasal polyps, deflected nasal septum, spurs or hypertrophid turbinates due to inflammation. The blocked nasal ostia (exit) results in the accumulation of secretions which provide media for growth of micro-organisms. This results in a secondary infection.</p>
<p>Acute sinusitis results from upper respiratory infections, allergic rhinitis, swimming or dental manipulation which cause inflammation resulting in increased secretions and blockage of their drainage. Chronic sinusitis is usually associated with chronic infection of sinuses and nasal polyps</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>There is usually pain over the affected sinuses due to inflammatory process and accumulation of pus and absorption of air.</li>
<li>Purulent nasal drainage due to hyper secretion.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Nasal obstruction due to inflammation or altered anatomy.</li>
<li>The turbinate will be oedematous, enlarged with tenderness over the affected area.</li>
<li>Recurrent headache which changes with position.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="investigations-include">Investigations include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#investigations-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>A CT scan will show sinus filled with fluid or hypertrophied mucosa.</li>
<li>A nasal endoscopy to examine or drain the sinus to get the secretions for culture and sensitivity.</li>
<li>An X-ray of sinus will show fluid in the sinus.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If the patient has pain related to decreased sinus drainage, inflammation or infection:</p>
<ul>
<li>Encourage patient to take the prescribed medication. Requires antibiotics for example amoxil to decrease risk of recurrent infection.</li>
<li>Expectorants may be used to drain secretions. A steroid like the hydrocortisone to relieve inflammation especially in allergic sinusitis.</li>
<li>Use analgesics and decongestants to relieve pain.</li>
<li>Instruct the patient to use plenty of fluids to dilute the secretion hence allow good drainage.</li>
<li>Nurse patient elevated to facilitate drainage and encourage frequent nose blowing.</li>
<li>Nasal irrigation, nasal drops may be used to relieve obstruction or decongest the nostrils.</li>
<li>Teach patient to avoid situations which aggravate sinusitis like swimming and diving.</li>
<li>Take vital signs and report any increased temperature.</li>
<li>If allergies, follow instructions of environmental control by identifying the allergen and avoiding stimulation of allergy.</li>
<li>Assess patient for features of infection and give appropriate medication.</li>
</ul>
<p>Peritonsillar Abscess</p>
<p>Peritonsillar abscess develops above the tonsil following tonsillar infection or pharyngitis.</p>
<p>The tonsils grossly enlarge to sometimes threaten the patency of the airway. The patient will have difficulty in swallowing (dysphagia) and pain (odinophagia). The patient presents with thickened voice, chills, fever and swelling of the soft palate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Peritonsilar abscess occurs as a complication of tonsilitis and acute pharyngitis. The tonsils may enlarge to threaten airway passage. High fever, leukocytosis and chills will occur and the patient needs IV antibiotics, incision and drainage for the abscess. Tonsillectomy may be performed after the infection has subsided. When a patient has a mass in the upper airway, patency may be lost. In such a patient, endotracheal intubation may have to be done</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="airway-obstruction">Airway Obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#airway-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the blockage of the air passage through the airways, that is, the nose, pharynx, larynx into the trachea and the lungs. It may be either partial or complete obstruction.</p>
<p>The causes include: Laryngeal oedema, aspirated food or foreign body, laryngeal tracheal stenosis, neurological depression, tumour.</p>
<p>Clinical features include: Stridor, uses of accessory muscle in breathing, substernal and intercostal muscles retraction, wheeze, restlessness, tachycardia, cyanosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an emergency and interventions are aimed at establishing and maintaining a patent airway, the Heimlich manoeuvre, cricothyroidectomy, endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy are commonly used</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intubation">Intubation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intubation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Make sure the patient is well oxygenated, explain the procedure and assemble and check the equipment. Then remove any dentures, and administer pre-medication. After intubation, the responsibilities include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Assessing for correct tube placement</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Inflating the cuff</li>
<li>Assessing oxygenation and acid-base balance</li>
<li>Suctioning to remove secretions and preventing accidental disconnection from ventilator or blockage</li>
<li>Prevention of the over-inflation of the cuff</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tracheotomy">Tracheotomy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tracheotomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Tracheotomy is an incision into the trachea for the purpose of establishing an airway. Tracheostomy is the surgical creation of an opening into the trachea through the neck. It is used:</p>
<ul>
<li>To bypass airway obstruction</li>
<li>To facilitate removal of secretions</li>
<li>To facilitate weaning from a ventilator</li>
<li>To permit long-term mechanical ventilation and improve patient comfort</li>
</ul>
<p>Care of the patient with tracheostomy involves avoiding dislodgment, assessing the respiratory function and evaluating the risk of swallowing, and speech problems. The patient on long-term tracheostomy should be taught about its care. The suctioning of the airway for a patient with endotracheal tube or tracheostomy should be done in such a way as to avoid cuff deflation while maintaining good respiratory function. Principles of asepsis must be strictly adhered to.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cancer-of-the-head-and-neck">Cancer of the Head and Neck<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cancer-of-the-head-and-neck" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cancer of the head and neck can greatly affect respiration. The choice of treatment in cancer of the head and neck is dependent on such factors as extent of the disease, cosmetics, and urgency of treatment. However, surgery and radiation are commonly used. Whatever the mode of management, the patient requires health education on radiation, duration of treatment, change of voice, speech and emotional adjustments.</p>
<p>Nutritional management and improvement of respiratory function are the most important aspects to concentrate on, in addition to the teaching just mentioned. The post-operative care is done by undertaking the following actions:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Putting the patient in semi-fowlers position</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clearance of the secretions</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Care of pressure areas and dressings, checking on drainage tubes and use of a humidifier</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Wound management should always be part of the post-operative care. Later, stoma care, voice rehabilitation and home care are taught to the patient for long-term home management.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-lower-respiratory-tract">Disorders of the Lower Respiratory Tract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-lower-respiratory-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="acute-and-chronic-bronchitis">Acute and Chronic Bronchitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-and-chronic-bronchitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Acute and chronic bronchitis are common conditions of the respiratory tract. This is an inflammation of the bronchi. Acute bronchitis is caused by bacteria and may follow a common cold. Streptococcus, staphylococcus aureus and H. influenza are commonly associated with acute bronchitis. Chronic heavy smoking and air pollution contribute to chronic bronchitis. The inflammation of the bronchi brings about thickening and an increase in mucous secretions, oedema, decrease in ciliated cells and narrowing of the bronchi.</p>
<p>Acute bronchitis is commonly a bacterial infection, which responds well to broad-spectrum antibiotics. Patient education goes hand in hand with the antibiotics, especially on the importance of completing the dose and recognition of symptoms of complications such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="bronchial-asthma">Bronchial Asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchial-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>It is an intermittent, reversible, obstructive airway disease that is characterised by increased responsiveness of the trachea and bronchi to stimuli resulting in the narrowing of the airway.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="types">Types<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Extrinsic asthma - Patients usually have a history of earlier allergic conditions like eczema or allergic rhinitis. They usually have known allergies like pollens, animals and food. Children with this type of asthma recover with age especially in adolescence.</li>
<li>Intrinsic - This is not related to any allergen. The attacks become more severe and frequent with time and can progress into chronic bronchitis or emphysema. Factors associated with intrinsic asthma include environmental pollutants, cold weather, exercise, respiratory tract infection or drugs especially the non steroidal like aspirin.</li>
</ol>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Mixed - This is the most common and has both the characteristics of the intrinsic and extrinsic type.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Exposure of the person to a stimulant causes the initiation of an immunological response which leads to production of antibodies against the allergen and antigen.</p>
<p>Re-exposure results into the antigen binding into the antibodies resulting into the production of cell mediators which include histamine, and prostaglandins. These mediators cause the muscles of the airway to go into spasms, mucus membrane swelling and hyper production of mucus secretion. This leads to broncho constriction with increased secretion causing further obstruction of the airway.</p>
<p>Breathing in becomes easier with more effort required in expiration due to narrowing of the bronchus and increased secretion. The secretion produces a sound as air squeezes out of the constricted bronchus. This sound is called a wheeze.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cough is present due to production of excessive mucus secretion</li>
<li>Slow laboured breathing with excessive use of accessory muscles</li>
<li>Obstructed airway creates dyspnoea</li>
<li>Profuse sweating, weak pulse and cold extremities is experienced due to fluid loss and dehydration</li>
<li>Occasionally nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea</li>
<li>Air hunger and chest tightness</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-asthma">Management of Asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the patient has ineffective breathing due to bronchospasms, mucosal oedema and increased secretions:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Provide a comfortable sitting up position to facilitate breathing and use of accessory muscles.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Give low humidified oxygen to increase oxygen saturation and correct hypoxia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Monitor the vital signs and respiratory activity of the patient to identify any change of condition and acute dyspnoea.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Monitor blood gases with pulse oximetry or blood gases analysis to monitor oxygen saturation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Auscultate patient's chest, premedicate with broncho dilator, advise deep breathing, coughing and chest physiotherapy to open airway and to allow good sputum removal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Teach patient deep breathing to increase PaO2 and reduce the respiratory rate.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Administer broncho dilator to reduce bronchospasms.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-asthma">Management of Asthma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the patient has ineffective airway clearance related to broncho spasms, ineffective cough and increased mucus production:</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure absence of possible allergen to reduce the severity of attack.</li>
<li>Assess patient's ability to expectorate secretions noting the character, quantity and odour of the secretions to rule out any infection.</li>
<li>Carry out culture and sensitivity tests and treat with appropriate antibiotics.</li>
</ul>
<p>When the patient becomes anxious due to difficulty in breathing:</p>
<ul>
<li>Give simple, concise explanations to situations and procedures to alleviate anxiety.</li>
<li>Provide reassurance by staying with the patient and allowing full participation.</li>
</ul>
<p>When there is risk of infection due to impaired airway clearance:</p>
<ul>
<li>Assess for infection, do culture and sensitivity tests and give the appropriate antibiotics</li>
</ul>
<p>When the patient has a knowledge deficit on the management of asthma:</p>
<ul>
<li>Teach patient and relatives about the important aspects of management.</li>
<li>Enlighten patient on what asthma is, good asthma control management and medication and their safe use.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>History of hypersensitivity to known allergen or stimulant</li>
<li>Clinical manifestation</li>
<li>Pulmonary function test, BGAs</li>
<li>Chest x-ray</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 188 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="status-asthmaticus">Status Asthmaticus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#status-asthmaticus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Status asthmaticus is severe bronchial asthma that is unresponsive to conventional therapy and lasts for more than 24 hours.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-include">Causes include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Infection that is not resolved</li>
<li>Anxiety</li>
<li>Dehydration</li>
<li>Increased beta block</li>
<li>Non specific irritant</li>
<li>Use of aspirin</li>
<li>Pathophysiology</li>
</ul>
<p>There is narrowing of bronchus, with bronchospasms and swelling. Increased mucus production limits air movement and patient ends up with hypoxaemia. Patient presents with respiratory alkalosis initially and as condition persists progresses to acidosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Severe form of the acute asthmatic. However, with severe asthma, wheeze may be minimised.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Patient is admitted, preferably in a pulmonary ICU.</li>
<li>Intravenous fluids are given to replace lost fluids.</li>
<li>Nebulisation can be attempted if not initially used to cause broncho dilation.</li>
<li>Low humidified oxygen is used where dyspnoea is marked. With poor ventilation, treat with endotrachial intubation and mechanical ventilation.</li>
<li>Intravenous drip of aminophylline is commenced with corticosteroid used to restore bronchial reactivity.</li>
<li>Mucolytis may also be used to help in the removal of secretions.</li>
<li>Antibiotics are used for treatment of underlying respiratory infection or prophylactically.</li>
<li>Carry out constant monitoring of the vital signs to identify deviations from normal and also to evaluate the effectiveness of the therapy.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bronchiectasis">Bronchiectasis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bronchiectasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When small bronchi are permanently dilated it is called this bronchiectasis. This is associated with bacterial infection. There is persistent cough to remove mucous retained in the dilated areas, which increases the pressure, worsening the dilation. Pus may form or bleeding may occur. This condition can lead to hypoxia and it can also contribute to right sided heart failure.</p>
<p>Bronchiectasis is normally treated with bronchodilators, mucolytic agents, expectorants and antibiotics. Good hydration, to liquefy secretions, must be maintained. Postural drainage and avoidance of air irritants are also important.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lung-cancer">Lung Cancer<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Lung cancer is mainly treated by surgery and radiation therapy. Make sure that the patient has effective breathing patterns, adequate airway clearance, adequate oxygenation, minimal pain (or none at all), and adherence to treatment regimen. If one has undergone surgery, postural drainage, airway clearance and an effective breathing pattern are the goals of care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="emphysema">Emphysema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emphysema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pulmonary emphysema is an irreversible distention of the bronchioles, alveolar ducts and alveoli. This results in increased capacity of the lungs. In this condition, the alveoli may merge, hence decreasing the surface area. The factors thought to predispose to emphysema are smoking, acute inflammation, chronic cough and congenital defects that result in deficiency of proteolytic enzyme in the lungs.</p>
<p>Emphysema may also result from rupture of the lung through stab wounds and accidents. Emphysema can be divided into alveolar or interstitial emphysema.</p>
<p>Emphysema is managed by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Treatment of respiratory tract infection if present</li>
<li>Bronchodilators such as anticholinergics, beta-2-adrenergic blockers and corticosteroids</li>
<li>Chest physiotherapy to improve the removal of secretions</li>
<li>Positive end expiratory respiration if the patient is on assisted ventilation, this prevents alveolar collapse</li>
<li>Breathing exercises and retraining</li>
<li>Hydration with at least three litres of fluid per day</li>
<li>Advice on cessation of smoking</li>
<li>Rest as appropriate</li>
<li>Progressive plan of exercises and pulmonary rehabilitation</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 189 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="empyema">Empyema<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#empyema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is the collection of pus in the pleural cavity. It is usually associated with underlying pulmonary infection.</p>
