<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-include">Causes include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ruptured lung abscess</li>
<li>Thoracic surgery</li>
<li>Penetrating wounds of the chest</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The goal of management is to drain the pus and allow and full expansion of the chest cavity.</p>
<ul>
<li>Antibiotics are used to check infection and prevent further pus formation</li>
<li>Analgesics and antipyretics to reduce temperature and pain caused by inflammatory process</li>
<li>The patient will be put on humidified oxygen to improve oxygen saturation. This is accompanied with positioning and breathing exercises</li>
<li>Needle aspiration can be done in thin exudates under good monitoring of the vital signs</li>
<li>Open drainage by decortication or pus removal may be done</li>
<li>Heimlich valves can also be used</li>
<li>Under water seal drainage may be done to allow for proper drainage of the pus and prevent atelectasis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-patient-on-underwater-seal-drainage">Care of Patient on Underwater Seal Drainage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-patient-on-underwater-seal-drainage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Insertion of chest tube through a thoracotomy incision with the aim of draining fluid or air from the chest cavity and passing it into or through a water bath to prevent back flow of air or fluids into chest cavity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indications">Indications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pnemothorax</li>
<li>Haemothorax</li>
<li>Hydrothorax</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The procedure of setting an underwater seal drainage is done in the ward or at the emergency room. The thoracotomy tube is passed through a system of bottles with fluids to prevent back flow or entry of air into the chest and to provide for suction pressure. The fluid contained must be sterile to prevent ascending infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patient-care">Patient care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>X-ray of the chest is done to confirm the position of the tube.</li>
<li>Keep patient in a comfortable position where patient is able to breath effectively to improve oxygenation and prevent hypoxia.</li>
<li>Keep tubings straight to avoid coiling which might end up with obstruction to flow.</li>
<li>Ensure tight tubings to prevent leakage and back flow and air entry in pleural space.</li>
<li>Check vital signs to evaluate patients condition.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patient-care">Patient Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>X-Observe the bubbles/dripping of fluids into the underwater seal fluid to ascertain patency</li>
<li>Change the fluid in the sterile bottle using aseptic technique to limit infection</li>
<li>Mark the amount of fluid in the seal bottle to have an accurately drained amount</li>
<li>Remember never to put the drainage bottle above the patient level</li>
<li>Milking the tubings increases the amount of negative pressure and can therefore be done periodically</li>
<li>While changing the patient's position, tube cramping is done to prevent back flow</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chest-tube-removal">Chest Tube Removal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chest-tube-removal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Give the patient pain medication before removal of the tube</li>
<li>Ensure chest x-rays are done to check lung expansion</li>
<li>Drainage should have stopped</li>
<li>Removal is done by cutting the suture and sealing the area with petroleum jelly dressing gauze. It is removed during deep expiration</li>
<li>Observe patient for any respiratory distress and signs of infection</li>
<li>The dressing should be completely removed when healing is complete</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atelectasis">Atelectasis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atelectasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Atelectasis refers to the collapse of an alveoli, lobule or lung unit. This could be due to defective expansion of the lungs at birth as a result of obstruction, poorly developed lungs and poor stimulation in the respiratory centre. It may also be acquired as a result of severe lung infection, particularly where there is poor clearance of secretions. Bronchial carcinoma and bronchiectasis are also common causes. The patient may present with dyspnoea, cyanosis, prostration and chest pain. There is cyanosis and anxiety with dyspnoea.</p>
<p>The affected side or part of chest has little movement with the opposite side experiencing excessive chest movement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Endoscopic procedures may be performed.</li>
<li>Carry out a radiograph e.g chest x-ray.</li>
<li>Angiograph - study of pulmonary vessels. The goal of management is to increase ventilation and remove the obstruction.</li>
<li>Encourage the patient to cough and do suction where indicated. Chest physiotherapy will also assist in facilitating secretion drainage.</li>
<li>Oxygen therapy will be done to increase oxygen concentration during inhalation.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pneumonia">Pneumonia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pneumonia is an acute respiratory illness, which is either segmental or affecting more than one lobe. It can be community acquired, hospital acquired or occurring due to immunosuppression. It can also occur as a result of aspiration of contents. The factors that contribute to this process include damage to the epithelia lining by chronic disease, chronic bronchitis and aspiration of contents from the stomach when drunk or unconscious. In our setup, the common infectious agents include: streptococcus pneumoniae, klebsiella pneumoniae, haemophilus influenzae and staphylococcus aureus. In patients with an impaired immune system, the agent pneumocystis carinii commonly causes pneumonia in the immunocompromised.</p>
<p>Patients with pneumonia clinically present with breathlessness, cough, fever, chest pain, tachypnoea and reduced chest movements. Subjectively, the patient with pneumonia may complain of dyspnoea, and fatigue. On x-ray the film may show pulmonary infiltration. The cough accompanying pneumonia may have several characteristics. It could be purulent, or yellow and blood stained, or red and gelatinous.</p>
<p>The goals of nursing care for a patient with pneumonia are: the patient to have clear breath sounds, normal breathing pattern, normal chest x-ray and no complications related to pneumonia. Although many patients in our set up are treated on an outpatient basis, some may be admitted into hospital and will require interventions ranging from measures to ensure comfort, good nutrition, fluids and electrolytes and patient education on infection prevention and control.</p>
<p>Before the actual management, it is recommended that vital signs and breathing patterns are assessed. It is recommended that sputum is collected for culture and sensitivity testing. Determine the colour, consistency and amount of sputum the patient is producing.</p>
<p>When the patient has ineffective breathing due to pneumonia and pain:</p>
<ul>
<li>Monitor respiratory function of a new patient's respiratory response to treatment, this should include blood gas analysis, pulse oximetry, respiratory rate and rhythm.</li>
<li>Position patient in an upright position to ease breathing and facilitate use of accessory respiratory muscles.</li>
<li>Give oxygen by mask or nasal cannular depending on the patients need.</li>
</ul>
<p>When the patient has splenic pain:</p>
<ul>
<li>Administer analgesia and provide information that can relieve pain</li>
<li>Observe the pharmacological effects of the drugs</li>
<li>Patient is at risk of infection complications</li>
<li>Administer antibiotics and observe their effects to therapy</li>
<li>Monitor for any signs of hypoxemia</li>
</ul>
<p>Where there is an ineffective airway clearance due to thick secretions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Administer broncho dilators, mucolytics and exercises to facilitate secretions removal</li>
<li>Maintain input of IV fluids to replace lost fluids and dilute the secretions (reduce the viscosity)</li>
</ul>
<p>When the patient is at the risk of altered health maintenance:</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Educate the patient on health, self care, and safe use of drugs to prevent recurrent infection</li>
<li>Educate the patient on safe health practices and discourage unsafe practices like smoking</li>
<li>Teach the patient about food and nutrition that will help maintain a healthy body</li>
</ul>
<p>To maintain body temperature:</p>
<ul>
<li>To relieve fever to promote comfort you can use antipyretics</li>
<li>Provide fluid replacement for fever and dehydration</li>
</ul>
<p>If an activity intolerance exists due to dyspnoea on exertion:</p>
<ul>
<li>Administer oxygen and increase oxygen intake dependent on patients needs</li>
<li>Plan for patient to prevent any unnecessary interruptions in order to decrease lung activity and promote ventilation</li>
<li>Note signs to evaluate the condition and identify deviation from the normal</li>
<li>Rehabilitation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Lung Collapse</li>
<li>Emphysema</li>
<li>Empyema</li>
<li>Hypoxemia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="manifestations-of-tuberculosis">Manifestations of Tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#manifestations-of-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacteria cause tuberculosis. This is the mycobacterium tuberculosis, also referred to as acid-fast bacilli. These bacteria are spread either by droplet infection or dust contaminated by sputum. Tuberculosis is divided into primary TB and secondary TB.</p>
<p>Primary TB is infection to the lungs as a result of mycobacterium tuberculosis. When microbes colonise the lung, macrophages surround the microbes, triggering the body's defence mechanisms. These macrophages spread to other areas and primary complexes are formed at the Hillary lymph nodes. Caseous material forms in several areas including the lungs. Caseous material is basically necrotic (dead) tissue. The disease may then be referred to as pulmonary tuberculosis.</p>
<p>The clinical features of pulmonary TB are persistent cough for more than four weeks, unexplained weight loss, chest pain, night sweats, poor appetite and haemoptysis.</p>
<p>It is called extra pulmonary tuberculosis if it affects areas outside the respiratory system. When the disease is extra pulmonary, the manifestations may include enlarged lymph nodes, pain and swelling in the joints, meningitis and paralysis if the spine is involved. This is a condition that is very common in Kenya.</p>
<p>Secondary TB is infection that is due to the caseous material in other organs such as the spinal cord, bone and brain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-tuberculosis">Management of Tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>TB is treated with standard pharmacologic agents. While nursing a patient with tuberculosis, the overall nursing goals are that the patient will:</p>
<ul>
<li>Comply with the therapeutic regimen</li>
<li>Have no recurrence of the disease</li>
<li>Have normal pulmonary function</li>
<li>Take appropriate measures to prevent the spread of the disease</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pleural-disease">Pleural Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleural-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pleura can be inflamed after injury or as a result of introduction of microbes from other processes. Accumulation of air within the pleural cavity results in pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is due to stab injury that allows air to enter, but not leave, the pleural space. Pleural pain, dyspnoea, chest asymmetry and hypoxia are common manifestations of pleural involvement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pleural-effusion">Pleural Effusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleural-effusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pleural effusion refers to accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity. The fluid may be blood, serous exudates or pus. It can be a complication of diseases such as pulmonary tuberculosis or lung cancer. It can also follow increased pressure due to heart failure, and increased permeability due to inflammation and impaired drainage. The manifestations are almost the same as pneumothorax. However, the percussion note on examination is different (dull).</p>
<p>The note elicited when percuting air filled cavities sounds like a drum.</p>
<p>Generally, a detailed history and physical assessment must be undertaken to come up with nursing diagnoses. Other than the medication, teaching on how to avoid spreading the disease, continued follow-up and compliance with the drug regimen and good nutrition must be given. The management of tuberculosis will</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>be mentioned again under communicable diseases.</p>
<p>The involvement of the chest and pleura can be very distressing. It is important to institute measures to ensure that respiratory function is not compromised.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-pleural-disease-and-chest-trauma">Management of Pleural Disease and Chest Trauma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-pleural-disease-and-chest-trauma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The emergency management of chest injuries involves:</p>
<ul>
<li>Establishing and maintaining an airway</li>
<li>Administering high flow oxygen</li>
<li>Establishing IV access</li>
<li>Monitoring vital signs, level of consciousness and urinary output</li>
<li>Assessing for tension pneumothorax</li>
<li>Dressing a sucking chest wound with nonporous material</li>
<li>Putting the patient in semi-Fowler's position or laying them on the injured side if breathing is easier</li>
<li>A pneumothorax can be aspirated if there is minimal air or fluid in the pleural space</li>
<li>Chest tubes and under water seal drainage are the most definitive treatment modalities</li>
</ul>
<p>The nursing care for a patient on underwater seal drainage includes the following actions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Avoid kinks in the tubing</li>
<li>Keep all connections tight</li>
<li>Keep the water seal and suction chambers at appropriate levels by adding sterile water as needed</li>
<li>Mark the drainage levels appropriately</li>
<li>Follow principles of asepsis when emptying the fluid and when changing the bottle</li>
<li>Observe for air bubbles in the water seal chamber and fluctuations in the chest tubes</li>
<li>Air should be bubbling from the chest tube. Check for intermittent bubbling in the water seal</li>
<li>Monitor the patient's status and avoid elevating the drainage system to the level of the patient's chest or above</li>
<li>Encourage the patient to cough</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-embolism">Pulmonary Embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pulmonary embolism develops when venous thrombus or embolus from peripheral circulation lodge in the pulmonary artery or one of its branches. The commonest causes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Venous stasis as a result of immobility</li>
<li>A flushed blood clot from an IV line</li>
</ul>
<p>The clinical findings are: dyspnoea, restlessness, anxiety, sharp pleuritic pain, and increased pulse, respirations and temperature. The management involves anti-coagulants and thrombolytic drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-embolism">Pulmonary Embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The patient should be placed in a good comfortable position preferably High Fowler's position. Monitor them closely and administer oxygen. Keep the patient calm and monitor for the development of hypoxia. The patient with pulmonary embolism should be given IV fluids with caution if pulmonary oedema has developed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-2-circulatory-system">SECTION 2: CIRCULATORY SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-2-circulatory-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In this section, you will study the circulatory system. It comprises of the blood, cardio vascular and the lymphatic systems. All the three systems are involved in transporting substances from one point to the other, thus they are also classified under systems dealing with communication in the body.</p>
<p>It is advised that you read and understand anatomy and physiology of these systems before you continue further.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="refer-to-rose-and-wilson-9th-edition-pages-59-129">Refer to Rose and Wilson 9th Edition pages 59-129.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#refer-to-rose-and-wilson-9th-edition-pages-59-129" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By the end of this section you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the composition and function of blood</li>
<li>Describe the structures and functions of the cardio-vascular system</li>
<li>Describe the structure and functions of lymph vessels and lymphatic tissue</li>
<li>Describe the disorders of the circulatory system.</li>
</ul>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-and-function-of-blood">Composition and Function of Blood<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-and-function-of-blood" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In section one of this unit you learned that blood is one type of connective tissue. Blood carries oxygen and carbon dioxide, nutrients and wastes, hormones, protective substances such as antibodies and blood clotting factors.</p>
<p>Blood consists of plasma and different blood cells. Plasma is a fluid that is almost 90% water. It contains plasma proteins, salts, nutrients, organic wastes, enzymes and antibodies dissolved in it. Three groups of cells are found in the blood.</p>
<p>These are:</p>
<ul>
<li>White blood cells (Leucocytes)</li>
<li>Red blood cells (Erythrocytes)</li>
<li>Platelets (Thrombocytes)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="white-blood-cells">White Blood Cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#white-blood-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>White blood cells are the largest of all the blood cells. They contain nuclei, and some have granules in their cytoplasm. There are three main types, each have different functions. These are granulocytes, monocytes and lymphocytes. The granulocytes are involved in the phagocytosis of bacteria and foreign particles. Phagocytosis is the process of engulfing an unwanted organism and digesting it. The granulocytes include neutrophils, eosinophils and basophils. They are also referred to as polymorphonuclear leucocytes.</p>
<p>Lymphocytes are of two types and they form the basis of the immune response.</p>
<ol>
<li>Thymus dependent (T) lymphocytes</li>
<li>Non-thymus dependent (B) lymphocytes</li>
</ol>
<p>The lymphocytes are involved in keeping memory of the various antigens encountered over time.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="red-blood-cells">Red Blood Cells<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#red-blood-cells" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Red blood cells (erythrocytes) are produced through a process called erythropoiesis. This process is regulated by oxygen requirements and is controlled by a hormone called erythropoietin, which is produced by the kidneys. When patients have chronic renal failure, they suffer from anaemia due to decreased erythropoiesis.</p>
<p>The function of the red blood cells is to transport gases and regulate the acid base balance. The major component of the red blood cell is haemoglobin. This is the red pigment that gives blood its colour. This has the characteristic of combining with oxygen to transport it to various points in the body.</p>
<p>When a red blood cell has lived for about 120 days it is destroyed by spleen macrophages through a process known as haemolysis. This destruction produces bilirubin, which is mixed with bile. You will learn more about the process of bilirubin formation when you look at the liver and gall bladder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="platelets">Platelets<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#platelets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These have the major function of initiating blood clotting. They also act as plugs in capillaries to close any opening.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-clotting">Blood Clotting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-clotting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Normal blood clotting relies upon the complex interaction between the vessel wall, the platelets and various coagulation factors.</p>
<p>The process of blood clotting takes place after the activation of prothrombin to thrombin in the presence of other clotting factors. The thrombin acts on the protein fibrinogen to form fibrin that is part of the clot.</p>
<p>The activation of prothrombin occurs after a long chain of events that involve the activation of various clotting factors in the blood. There are twelve blood-clotting factors involved in this process. When any of these factors are missing, clotting is affected and individuals may bleed to death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-groups">Blood Groups<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-groups" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are associated with genetically determined antigens on the red blood cell membrane and naturally occurring antibodies in serum. Two systems are commonly used in blood grouping. One is the ABO system and the other is the Rhesus system. By the ABO system, people are of blood group AB, A, B, or O depending on whether they have A and B, A, B, or no antigens on their red blood cells.</p>
<p>Blood group A has 'A' antigens and has natural antibodies against the other types, that is B and AB. The person with blood group B has "B" antigens and has natural antibodies against A and AB.</p>
<p>The Rhesus system depends on whether an individual has the Rhesus antigen, in which case they are Rhesus positive, or not. If they don't</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>have it, then they are Rhesus negative and will form antibodies against the Rhesus antigen and lyse (destroy) the Rhesus positive blood.</p>
<p>The person with Blood group O Rhesus negative has no antigens and has antibodies against A, B, and AB. This person can therefore donate blood to anybody but can only receive blood from group O negative.</p>
<p>The person who is type AB Rhesus negative can receive blood from any donor both Rhesus positive and negative. However, AB Rhesus negative can only give blood to itself.</p>
<p>The internal circulation consists of the blood system (the heart, vessels and blood) and the lymph system, which is made up of lymph nodes, lymph vessels and lymph.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-cda3a2da.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg">
Structure and Function of the Heart</p>
<p>The heart is a cone shaped hollow muscular organ about the size of a person's fist. It is located within the thoracic cavity between the lungs. Its apex is pointed down and towards the left at the fifth inter-costal space.</p>
<p>The walls of the heart consist of three layers. The first is the endocardium, which is a single layer of epithelium and underlying connective tissue. This is the innermost layer and it is continuous with the inner lining of arteries and veins. The middle layer is the myocardium, which comprises specialised cardiac muscle</p>
<p>fibres. The third and outer layer of the heart is the pericardium which is made up of two sacs: an outer fibrous sac and an inner sac, a serous membrane, whose parietal layer lines the fibrous sac and the visceral layer or epicardium which is adherent to the heart muscle. The space between the parietal and visceral layers is only a potential space.</p>
<p>The heart is divided into a right and left side by a wall called the atrioventricular septum. This wall is composed of myocardium lined by endocardium.</p>
<p>Each side is further divided by a valve into an upper chamber (the atrium) and a lower chamber (the ventricle). The right atrioventricular valve has three flaps and is called the tricuspid valve. The left has two flaps and is called the mitral valve. These valves open and close according to pressure changes and allow blood to pass from one chamber to another.</p>
<p>The heart acts as a pump and because of its two sides, it can be considered as two pumps in one.</p>
<p>Blood flows into the heart from the superior and inferior vena cavae. The blood is emptied into the right atrium, passes through the right valves into the right ventricle where it is pumped into the pulmonary artery.</p>
<p>The pulmonary artery has the pulmonary valve to ensure blood does not flow backwards. This pulmonary valve has three flaps that make the semilunar valve(s). After leaving the heart, the artery divides into two to supply the right and left lungs. This ensures that the blood becomes oxygenated before it returns to the heart via the pulmonary veins into the left atrium.</p>
<p>The blood then passes through the left atrioventricular valve, the mitral valve, into the left ventricle to be pumped into the aorta and into the rest of the body. The aorta has a valve as well to ensure blood does not flow back to the left ventricle when it relaxes.</p>
<p>The heart itself is supplied with blood by the coronary arteries, which branch off from the aorta. They form a network of capillaries traversing the heart. Venous blood is collected into small veins that join to form the coronary sinus which empty into the right atrium.</p>
<p>The blood supply to the heart is called the coronary circulation. When this is disrupted, the heart may lack oxygen and nutrients. The most common factor that leads to interrupted blood flow to the heart is narrowing of vessels due to the deposition of cholesterol (atherosclerosis).</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>This can lead to such conditions as myocardial infarction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-conducting-system-of-the-heart">The Conducting System of the Heart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-conducting-system-of-the-heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart muscle is intrinsically excitable and, therefore, can contract on its own. There are specialised cells in the myocardium, which start an impulse. These specialised areas include the sinoatrial node (SA node) in the wall of the right atrium. This is the 'pace maker' of the heart. The other one is the atrioventricular node (the AV node) located on the wall of the septum near the right atrioventricular valves. This is stimulated by impulses from the SA node. It can also initiate its own impulses but at a slower rate than the SA node.</p>
<p>The last one is the Bundle of His, located in the wall of the septum. It passes downwards into the ventricular septum, and at the apex of the heart divides into the right and left Purkinje fibres. The Purkinje fibres pass impulses to the apex of the heart where the wave of contraction begins.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-9e7af155.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg"></p>
<p>The heart functions as a pump and consists of a series of events, comprising contraction and relaxation.</p>
<p>The contraction and relaxation is called the cardiac cycle. When the heart contracts and relaxes, blood passes through the valves into the</p>
<p>various chambers.</p>
<p>The opening and closing of the valves produces heart sounds that are audible on auscultation.</p>
<p>Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by</p>
<p>each ventricle in one minute. Cardiac output is equal to the heart rate multiplied by the stroke</p>
<p>volume, the amount of blood pumped by a ventricle with each beat. Sounds that are audible on auscultation are described as the 'lub' and 'dub'.</p>
<p>Lub is usually loud and more audible. This is caused by the closure of atrio-ventricular values caused by increased ventricular pressure during systole. Dub is due to the closure of semilunar valves which is caused by relaxation of ventricles during the ventricular diastole.</p>
<p>The blood is then circulated around the body at a certain pressure maintained by peripheral resistance, elasticity of artery walls and the force of contraction</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulse">Pulse<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pulse refers to the palpable wave of distension and relaxation in arterial walls following left ventricular contraction. The pulse or the wave of distention is due to blood pressure. The pulse rate is the number of heartbeats per unit time. The pulse rhythm is the regularity with which the heart beats.</p>
<p>The pulse is measured at various points on the human body. During measurement, the rate, rhythm and force/strength of contraction must be determined. The various points of palpation include antecubital, popliteal, femoral, carotid, and radial arteries.</p>
<p>The average pulse rate in an adult is 60-100 per minute. This is determined by the state of the arteries supplying the periphery and the ability of the heart to generate enough force to circulate blood to the periphery.</p>
<p>When measuring the pulse rate of a patient, remember to note the rhythm and strength as well!</p>
<p>The heart pumps blood to all parts of the body and is carried through blood vessels. These vessels vary in structure, size and function. They comprise of the arteries and veins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arteries">Arteries<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arteries" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are blood vessels that carry blood away from the heart. Large arteries have more elastic tissue allowing them to possess the elasticity property.</p>
<p>They sub-divide into small blood vessels called the arterioles. Anastomoses may also be formed linking one artery with another.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 196 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="veins">Veins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#veins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These carry blood back into the heart. Their walls are thinner and are continuous with the arteries thus forming a closed circuit through where blood circulates. Between the arteries and the veins are capillaries which facilitate the interchange of substances between the tissue and the circulatory system. Some veins in the lower extremities have valves which prevent back flow of blood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="blood-pressure">Blood Pressure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-pressure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The blood pressure refers to the transmitted force of contraction that moves blood through the various vessels. The pressure is measured during contraction (systole) and during relaxation (diastole) of the ventricles. The pressure that you have been measuring is the arterial blood pressure. It measures the force of transmission in the arteries. There is also venous pressure that can be measured centrally through a catheter. This is called central venous pressure (CVP). The central venous pressure measures the pressure in the heart chambers.</p>
<p>The arterial blood pressure can be affected by factors such as total peripheral resistance and cardiac output. The renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system produces angiotensin that can act directly on peripheral vessels to increase the resistance and, therefore, affect blood pressure. Many diseases of the kidneys, liver and heart can lead to an increase in blood pressure. Endocrine diseases such as hyperthyroidism, Cushing's syndrome and Addison's diseases can affect blood pressure.</p>
<p>There may be variations in the blood pressure in the same individual depending on the emotional status, position during blood pressure measurement and the point of measurement. This means that the patient must be calm and in one position before taking arterial blood pressure. For instance, the arterial pressure while sitting may vary from that taken while one is lying on the left side.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="structure-and-function-of-the-blood-circulation">Structure and Function of the Blood Circulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-and-function-of-the-blood-circulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Blood pumped from the heart (the left ventricle) is carried by the aorta, which has three distinct parts:</p>
<ul>
<li>The ascending aorta</li>
<li>The arch of the aorta</li>
<li>The descending aorta</li>
</ul>
<p>Various arteries branch off from these three parts of the aorta to supply all parts of the body. These arteries subdivide further until the capillary network is formed. The capillaries start re-grouping until they form veins that return blood to the right atrium through the superior and inferior vena cava.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-fb879312.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg"></p>
<p>The pulmonary circulation refers to that part of circulation taking blood from the heart to and from the lungs.</p>
<p>Branches of aorta supply the neck and the head. The major arteries supplying the head and the neck are common carotid arteries and the vertebral arteries. The common carotid arteries subdivide into the internal and external carotid arteries.</p>
<p>The external carotid arteries supply the superficial structure of the head and neck while the internal carotid artery supplies the internal structures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-circle-of-willis">The Circle of Willis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-circle-of-willis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This refers to the network of arteries that supply the brain. It comprises of:</p>
<ul>
<li>two anterior cerebral arteries</li>
<li>two internal carotid arteries</li>
<li>one anterior communicating artery</li>
<li>two posterior communicating arteries</li>
<li>two posterior cerebral arteries</li>
<li>one basilar artery</li>
</ul>
<p>Two vertebral arteries arise from subclavian and pass through the foramen magnum into the skull. They join shortly after forming one basilar artery.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-011500c5.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<p>The basilar artery branches into the right and left posterior cerebral arteries. These two arteries are joined to internal carotid arteries which enter the cranial cavity from the mid part of cranial wall by the left and right posterior communicating arteries.</p>
<p>Within the anterior, two anterior cerebral arteries arise from internal carotid arteries and are joined by the anterior communicating artery.</p>
<p>This arrangement completes a circle in the cranium commonly called the circulus arteriosus of arteries or the Circle of Willis.</p>
<p>The blood circulation from the abdominal organs forms the portal circulation. The portal circulation is involved in taking blood from the intestines where nutrients have been absorbed to the liver where the nutrients will be stored or broken down.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphatic-system">Lymphatic System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphatic-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The lymphatic system consists of lymphatic capillaries and ducts, which carry fluid from the interstitial spaces to the blood and the lymph nodes, which trap particles. Lymph is important because it transports proteins and fat from the gastrointestinal tract. It also transports certain hormones back to the blood. Excess interstitial fluid returns to the blood through the same process to avoid development of oedema.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphatic-fluid">Lymphatic Fluid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphatic-fluid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lymph fluid is pale yellow and diffuses through lymphatic capillary walls. It circulates through its own vessels.</p>
<p>When the fluid is too much, and there is blockage of the vessels, lymphoedema can develop.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymph-nodes">Lymph Nodes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymph-nodes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lymph nodes are part of the lymphatic system. They are small and round or bean shaped and vary in size.</p>
<p>Their function is filtration of bacteria and foreign particles.</p>
<p>They are situated at strategic places in the body for this purpose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spleen">Spleen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spleen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The spleen is formed by reticular and lymphatic tissue and lies in the left hypochondriac region of the abdominal cavity. It is enclosed in a fibro-elastic tissue that forms trabeculae.</p>
<p>It has the splenic pulp made of lymphocytes and microphages.</p>
<p>The function of the spleen includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maintenance of body immunity</li>
<li>Phagocytosis</li>
<li>Storage of blood</li>
<li>Erythropoiesis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thymus">Thymus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thymus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thymus is situated in the mediastinum and it</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>participates in the defence mechanisms of the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-heart">Disorders of the Heart<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-heart" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The heart is a very complex and important organ in our body.</p>
<p>You will now look at various disorders that may affect the normal functioning of the heart.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-pericardium">Disorders of the Pericardium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-pericardium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The pericardium is the outer covering of the heart and many processes can affect it. Infectious agents like bacteria, fungi and viruses can bring about inflammation of the pericardium. Inflammation can also result from immune disorders, metabolic disorders such as myxoidema, tissue injury, physical and chemical agents, for example drug reactions and radiation. All these factors bring about pericarditis, which can be chronic or acute.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pericarditis">Pericarditis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pericarditis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the inflammation of the pericardium of the heart. This is the pericardial sac that is made up of the parietal and the visceral plueral. Possible causes of pericarditis include viruses, bacteria, tuberculosis, fungi, syphilis, parasites, injury, auto immune disorders, rheumatic fever, radiation or neoplasm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pericardial tissue damage triggers inflammatory response causing vasodilation, hyperaemia and oedema. Capillary permeability increases allowing proteins to escape into pericardial space.</p>
<p>Exudates which contains blood cells may form and if due to infection may be pulurent. This may increase the pericardial fluid substantially causing pericardial effusion. Pericarditis may heal with fibrosis or scarring which may restrict heart function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Patients with pericarditis present with chest pain, a friction rub and various symptoms that are related to the chest pain. These include anxiety, restlessness and palpitations.</p>
<p>This is the inflammation of the pericardium of the heart. This is the pericardial sac that is made up of the parietal and the visceral plueral. Possible causes of pericarditis include viruses, bacteria, tuberculosis, fungi, syphilis, parasites, injury, auto immune disorders, rheumatic fever, radiation or neoplasm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pericardial tissue damage triggers inflammatory response causing vasodilation, hyperaemia and oedema. Capillary permeability increases allowing proteins to escape into pericardial space.</p>
<p>Exudates which contains blood cells may form and if due to infection may be pulurent. This may increase the pericardial fluid substantially causing pericardial effusion. Pericarditis may heal with fibrosis or scarring which may restrict heart function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Patients with pericarditis present with chest pain, a friction rub and various symptoms that are related to the chest pain. These include anxiety, restlessness and palpitations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Assessment on quality and nature of pain and anxiety is important to rule out myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Careful nursing observation including vital signs must be done to identify any deviation from normal</li>
<li>Pain relief measures - allow bed rest, anti-inflammatory medication</li>
<li>Antibiotics must be given for infections</li>
<li>Anxiety reducing measures</li>
<li>Pericardicentesis can be done under strict observation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pericardial effusion</li>
<li>Tamponade and shock</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pericardial-effusion">Pericardial Effusion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pericardial-effusion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pericardial effusion is the presence of fluid in the pericardial cavity. The fluid can accumulate slowly or fast, and the amount can be small or large. This is what will determine the symptoms that patients will present with. Pericarditis on its own can result in effusion. The symptoms of pericardial effusion may therefore mimic those of pericarditis, in addition to high blood pressure and impaired cardiac return.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiac-tamponade">Cardiac Tamponade<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-tamponade" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Cardiac tamponade, which refers to compression, is one of the consequences following pericardial effusion. Pericardial effusion can lead to increased pressure in the heart and interfere with venous return. Cardiac tamponade is a very serious and life threatening disorder that needs urgent action.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cause">Cause<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cause" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pericardial effusion, trauma, cardiac rapture or haemorrhage can cause cardiac tamponade.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There is increase in intra cardinal pressures that decreases the ventricular filling time and cardiac output.</p>
<p>During inspiration, the right ventricle receives more venous return thus causing the ventricular septum to bulge towards the left ventricle. This reduces the left ventricular pressure - and leads to low pulse pressure during inspiration. This is called pulsus paradoxicus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include pulses paradoxicus, reduced cardiac output, dyspnoea, tachypnea, tachycardia, distended neck veins, mumbled heart sounds and dilated atrium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="studies">Studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Electrocardiography</li>
<li>Echocardiography</li>
<li>X-ray shows cardiac enlargement</li>
<li>CT scan identify the pericardial effusion</li>
<li>Haemodynamic monitoring - elevated pulmonary pressures</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Pericardiocentesis may be done to remove fluid from the pericardial sac</li>
<li>Drug treatment includes anti-inflammatory drugs to reduce inflammation and promote comfort</li>
<li>Surgery can be done in restrictive pericarditis</li>
<li>Antibiotics may be used if associated with infection</li>
<li>Maintain a calm environment and position of comfort</li>
<li>Monitor patient vital signs</li>
<li>Assess for pain and relieve as necessary</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management-of-inflammatory-heart-disease">Management of Inflammatory Heart Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management-of-inflammatory-heart-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Adults with such conditions as endocarditis, infective endocarditis, myocarditis and pericarditis are likely to come under your care at sometime</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endocarditis">Endocarditis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocarditis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Endocarditis is the inflammation of the innermost layer of the heart. It may be infective or non-infective. Infective endocarditis is due to bacteria, viruses, yeast and fungal infection, while non-infective endocarditis may be due to rheumatic fever. Rheumatic fever might be caused by autoimmunity. Endocarditis presents with fever, heart murmurs, anorexia, malaise and lethargy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infective-endocarditis">Infective Endocarditis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infective-endocarditis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infective endocarditis will be managed by giving appropriate antibiotic therapy, antipyretics, rest and surgical valve repair if the valves are damaged. Rest periods can give the heart opportunity to use the little oxygen available well. Antipyretic medication is intended to control the fever.</p>
<p>For the patient with infective endocarditis, blood culture, X-ray and other specialised investigations may identify the problem. Then appropriate antibiotics can be given for the infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myocarditis">Myocarditis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocarditis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Most patients with myocarditis recover spontaneously. However, they may be treated in the same manner as those with pericarditis.</p>
<p>Generally, the patient with inflammatory heart disease must be assessed well through clinical, radiological and laboratory techniques. Chest x-ray, blood culture and cardiac catheterisation may be used.</p>
<p>People, especially young children, undergoing dental surgery should be given prophylactic treatment to avoid the possibility of development of infective heart disease</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pericarditis">Pericarditis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pericarditis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pericarditis is treated after identification of the underlying cause with aspirin, bed rest, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and corticosteroids. Steroids are intended to decrease the inflammation, while aspirin has thrombolytic activity. If blood clotting occurs in the coronary circulation, there may be a decrease in the</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>supply of oxygen to the heart muscle, leading to myocardial infarction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="coronary-heart-disease">Coronary Heart Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coronary-heart-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This results from impaired blood flow to the heart muscles. Impairment of coronary heart flow may lead to myocardial infarction, angina and conduction disorders. It can also result in heart failure and death. Myocardial ischaemia occurs due to deficient blood flow to the myocardium. Ischaemia is deficient oxygen supply to a particular tissue. In the heart, this can manifest with a condition referred to as angina pectoris, which is chest pain or pressure sensation that the patient will describe as constricting and suffocating. Sometimes there can be ischaemia without angina. With continued lack of oxygen and nutrients, myocardial infarction can occur. An infarction is dead tissue.</p>
