<p>The manifestations of myocardial ischaemia are: pain, weakness, dysrhythmias and signs of inflammation. Nausea, vomiting and epigastric discomfort are common. Tachycardia, restlessness and anxiety occur with the patient's skin becoming cold and moist. Myocardial infarction can cause shock, pericarditis, heart failure and ultimately, death.</p>
<p>The adult patient with coronary heart disease should be involved in identifying modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors and then managing those that are modifiable. These will decrease the risk of myocardial infarction. The modifiable factors include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Hypertension - The patient should have regular check ups and take prescribed medications. They should reduce salt intake, stop smoking and reduce their weight.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Smoking - Patients should stop smoking.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Obesity - Patients should change feeding patterns and habits, reduce caloric intake, exercise regularly, avoid fad and crash diets and avoid large, heavy meals. Fad diets are the fast foods that seem to be very fashionable but are not balanced.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Diabetes mellitus - Patients with diabetes mellitus should control their diet, reduce their weight and monitor their blood glucose closely.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Elevated serum lipids - Individuals should reduce animal (saturated) fat, engage in regular exercise and increase complex carbohydrates.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Physical inactivity - Advise patients to develop and maintain a routine for physical activity.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stressful lifestyle - Increase patient awareness of behaviour that is detrimental to health such as long hours in stressful situations without breaks or leave.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>In addition, the specific management of the disease includes drugs and supportive therapy. Patients can receive drugs, which increase lipoprotein removal, for example. cholesterol, and drugs that restrict lipoprotein production, for example, nicotinic acid.</p>
<p>Coronary artery disease can manifest as angina pectoris. This is treated with nitroglycerin if the patient has acute attacks. The tablets will be given sublingual when the patient is working hard and is likely to experience exertion. They are taken in three doses repeated one after every five minutes. Chronic angina prophylaxis involves antithrombotic therapy, nitroglycerin treatment, long acting nitrates, adrenergic blocking drugs and calcium channel blockers. Nitrates increase oxygen supply to the heart muscle. The overall goals of nursing care in coronary heart disease involve pain relief, reduced anxiety and modification of risk factors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="myocardial-infarction">Myocardial Infarction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myocardial-infarction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This refers to destruction of myocardial tissue on the regions where blood supply has been deprived because of reduced coronary blood flow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes">Causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The causes may include reduced coronary flow due to shock, haemorrhage or coronary occlusion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Coronary artery may be occluded by an atheroma or emboli, resulting in reduced blood supply to the distal areas of heart. This result into an imbalance between oxygen supply and oxygen demand by the myocardial cells.</p>
<p>This results into ischemia, injury and lastly complete death of the myocardium cells called infarction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Characteristic chest pain, usually described as sudden, sternal or may be</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>abdominal, radiates to shoulders or down arms. The pain is persistent and may be relieved by either rest or nitroglycerine. Referred to as anginal pain.</p>
<ul>
<li>The pulse may become rapid, irregular and feeble.</li>
<li>Sweating may be present.</li>
<li>Patient becomes very anxious due to release of catecholamine.</li>
<li>Nausea and vomiting may result from reflex stimulation of the vomiting centre.</li>
<li>Fever may be present which may be a manifestation of the inflammatory process of the dying cells.</li>
<li>Blood pressure may be reduced with reduced urinary output as a result of reduced cardiac output.</li>
<li>Ventricular aneurysm may be revealed under further examination.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Investigations include:</p>
<ul>
<li>12 lead ECG will reveal areas of infarction.</li>
<li>Cardiac enzymes - there are enzymes released by dead cells. Some are specific to the cardiac cells and forms basis of diagnosis of cardiac infarction.</li>
<li>Echocardiogram to assess the function of the valves.</li>
</ul>
<p>Myocardial infarction requires IV fluid therapy, continued electrocardiogram (ECG) monitoring, narcotic analgesics and oxygen. Vital signs should be monitored every one to two hours while the patient is put on strict bed rest. Thrombolytic therapy, anticoagulants and nitroglycerin are given while at the same time recording intake and output. An infusion of lidocaine may be given to prevent ventricular fibrillation.</p>
<p>When nursing the patient with myocardial infarction always make sure that:</p>
<ul>
<li>The patient experiences pain relief</li>
<li>The patient has no progression of myocardial infarction</li>
<li>The patient receives immediate treatment and modifies high-risk behaviours.</li>
</ul>
<p>Many of the patients that you will meet will be emergencies and, will therefore, need quick action to prevent death. The oxygen and nitroglycerin will come in handy. Patient teaching is important during rehabilitation. They must</p>
<p>know how to adjust their lifestyles to cope with their problem.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications">Complications<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cardiac arrhythmias - this may range from simple tachycardia to complex ventricular rhythms especially when the conducting system has been involved. ECG changes will be involved.</li>
<li>Congestive heart failure occurs when pumping powers of the heart diminishes.</li>
<li>Cardiogenic shock will follow in adequate oxygen transport to the tissues.</li>
<li>Papillary muscle dysfunction - where infarcted area affects the areas controlling the valves.</li>
<li>Ventricular aneurysms appear in the destroyed muscle tissue.</li>
<li>Pericarditis may occur.</li>
<li>Dresslers syndrome caused by antigen-antibody reactions to the necrotic myocardium.</li>
<li>Pulmonary embolism may occur where a thrombus is involved.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiac-arrhythmias">Cardiac Arrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-arrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cardiac arrhythmias are the result of a disordered contraction of the heart muscle. Fibrillation is the contraction of heart muscle in a disordered sequence</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atrial-fibrillation">Atrial Fibrillation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrial-fibrillation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The atria has uncoordinated and disorganised atrial stimulation due to presence of numerous ectopic foci stimulating the atria at a very fast rate. Atrial contraction is limited to quivers with no effective atrial contraction.</p>
<p>Ventricular rhythm will depend on the response of the atrio-ventricular node. Most impulses may be blocked allowing ventricles to have a slower rate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ventricular-fibrillation">Ventricular Fibrillation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ventricular-fibrillation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The ventricle has rapid, uncoordinated and disorganised impulse stimulation due to presence of many ectopic foci pacing the heart resulting into ineffective ventricular contraction. Blood flow to various organs is impaired because there is no stroke volume and death results if no emergency measures are taken.</p>
<p>Emergency cardio-pulmonary resuscitation is the only option with ventricular defibrillation being the management of choice.</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 202 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="atrio-ventricular-block">Atrio Ventricular Block<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atrio-ventricular-block" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Heart block occurs when there is delay of an impulse between the atria and ventricles. This is due to a delay of stimulation of the AV node. This results in bradycardia or heart rate of less than 35 beats per minute. Improper use of certain drugs, myocardial ischaemia and myocardial infarction cause heart block.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="care-of-the-patient-with-dysrythmia">Care of the Patient with Dysrythmia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-patient-with-dysrythmia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The patient with dysrythmia needs to be investigated and the underlying cause treated. They may receive drugs, bed rest and surgical corrections. The various drugs indicated for cardiomyopathy include digitalis, diuretics and angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. The digitalis increases the force of contraction of the heart muscle. The diuretics will decrease the venous return, hence decrease the cardiac output. This lessens the work that the heart has to perform.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="emergency-management-of-dysrhythmias">Emergency Management of Dysrhythmias<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#emergency-management-of-dysrhythmias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Establishing and maintaining a patient's airway</li>
<li>Administration of oxygen via nasal canular</li>
<li>Establishing an IV line with a large gauge needle</li>
<li>ECG monitoring</li>
<li>Being prepared to initiate cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation should the need arise</li>
<li>Monitoring vital signs</li>
<li>Reassuring the patient</li>
</ul>
<p>Some of the drugs that are used in the treatment of dysrhythmias are atropine, digoxin, quinidine, procainamide, verapamil and beta-blockers. Some of the drugs increase the force of heart contraction, while others open up the peripheral circulation to relieve the heart of too much work. It is important that you get acquainted with the use of cardiac electrodes and the technique for CPR and defibrillation. You can learn this from your more experienced colleagues at work.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypertension">Hypertension<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypertension" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Hypertension is another common condition in your practice.</p>
<p>Hypertension can lead to rupture of small blood vessels, hence eye, renal and heart complications, ascitis, liver failure and so on. It can also lead to coronary heart disease, heart failure, kidney failure, and stroke.</p>
<p>The causes of hypertension are not very clear, but there are some predisposing factors. These include heart disease, liver and kidney disease and eclampsia in pregnancy. In many individuals, hypertension has a genetic predisposition.</p>
<p>A stressful lifestyle can also contribute to hypertension.</p>
<p>Hypertension is confirmed when there is an increase of over <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20\mathrm{mmHg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mmHg</span></span></span></span></span></span> diastolic pressure on more than two occasions. That means that the individual is measured on different days and the increase is persistent.</p>
<p>The management involves the use of drugs and modification of one's lifestyle. The drugs commonly used are diuretics, blood vessel dilators, centrally acting drugs, and beta-blockers. The more familiar names are aldomet (methyldopa), inderal (propranolol), lasix (frusemide), and captopril.</p>
<p>The objective is to decrease the intravascular volume, decrease the force of contraction and decrease peripheral resistance. This is intended to decrease the amount of work being performed by the heart.</p>
<p>The preventive message given to the patient with hypertension is:</p>
<ul>
<li>Regular checkups</li>
<li>Compliance with drugs</li>
<li>Modification of lifestyle</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="rheumatic-heart-disease">Rheumatic Heart Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rheumatic-heart-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Rheumatic heart disease is one of the heart disorders that have serious consequences. It is caused by rheumatic fever which is an autoimmune disease following a throat infection by streptococcus pyogenes, that is, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi></mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;"></span></span></span></span></span>-haemolytic group A-streptococci.</p>
<p>The disease may cause heart valve damage leading to heart failure and death. The antibodies that result from rheumatic heart fever can also affect the myocardium, the endocardium or/and the pericardium.</p>
<p>The manifestations of rheumatic fever are fever, abdominal pain, sore throat, headache, polyarthritis, nausea and vomiting. Patients who have a sore throat should be vigorously treated.</p>
<p>Adults with rheumatic fever need bed rest. The rest is intended to avoid overworking the heart.</p>
<p>Benzathine penicillin is used prophylactically, while aspirin decreases the likelihood of clotting and corticosteroids are used to decrease inflammation.</p>
<p>The important aspects are to ensure there is no residual heart disease. Patients with vulvular heart disease can be treated either non-surgically or surgically. They receive prophylactic antibiotics, digitalis, diuretics, sodium restriction and anticoagulants. They may also benefit from anti-dysrhythmic drugs and -adrenergic agents.</p>
<p>These drugs and the purposes for which they are given have been mentioned previously. Surgery may be undertaken at specialised institutions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heart-failure">Heart Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Heart failure is the inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the metabolic requirements of the body. Some of the causes of heart failure are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Damage of heart muscles</li>
<li>Rupture of heart valves</li>
<li>Pulmonary embolism</li>
<li>Cardiac arrhythmias</li>
<li>Severe hypertension</li>
</ul>
<p>Heart failure can either be right-sided or left-sided failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="right-sided-heart-failure">Right-sided Heart Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#right-sided-heart-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Right-sided heart failure occurs when the right ventricle is unable to pump blood adequately. This results into congestion in the right side of the heart, the viscera and peripheral tissues.</p>
<p>Increased blood flow in the periphery, leads to congestion in the blood vessels resulting into pitting oedema. Congestion in the hepatic circulation also leads to venous engorgement resulting into hepatomegally, ascitis and respiratory distress due to pressure on diaphragm.</p>
<p>Cardiac output improves at night due to improved rest and venous return. This increases diuresis usually referred to as nocturnal diuresis. The patient with right-sided heart failure will manifest with fatigue, oedema, distension of jugular veins, ascitis, cyanosis, anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="left-sided-heart-failure">Left-sided Heart Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#left-sided-heart-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This results from left ventricular failure. The left ventricle is not able to adequately pump blood out of the heart resulting in congestion in the pulmonary circulation.</p>
<p>Fluid accumulates in the lungs resulting into pulmonary oedema which manifests in dyspnoea at rest. Dyspnoea may be at night due to increased congestion in pulmonary circulation. This is caused by increased venous return which results into much more alveolar congestion.</p>
<p>Low cardiac output results into fatigability with decreased removal of catabolic waste.</p>
<p>Left-sided heart failure manifests with pulmonary oedema, hence shortness of breath, cyanosis and dyspnoea. It is important that you remember this well, so that you understand the rationale for management of patients with heart failure.</p>
<p>Congestive heart failure refers to accumulation of fluids in the body (especially the lungs) due to impaired cardiac function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-adult-with-congestive-heart-failure">Care of the Adult with Congestive Heart Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-with-congestive-heart-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It was mentioned earlier that congestive heart failure might be right-sided or left-sided. Therapy is directed towards improving left ventricular function by decreasing the after-load. There is also the need to increase cardiac output, improve gas exchange and reduce anxiety.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatments-for-congestive-heart-failure-underlying-cause">Treatments for Congestive Heart Failure Underlying Cause<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatments-for-congestive-heart-failure-underlying-cause" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Investigations have to be done extensively to determine the cause of the failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="history-and-physical-examination">History and Physical Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#history-and-physical-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A history should be taken and a physical examination done. Cardiac monitoring, 12 lead ECG, echocardiogram nuclear imaging studies, and cardiac catheterisation may be done for specific diagnosis and management.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="improve-oxygenation">Improve Oxygenation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#improve-oxygenation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This may be achieved by administration of oxygen to increase the percentage of oxygen inspired per breath. If patient has severe heart failure with pulmonary oedema, endotracheal intubation might be necessary. Administration of morphine may also reduce oxygen demand by reducing anxiety. It also improves blood circulation by reducing venous return.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="promotion-of-rest">Promotion of Rest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#promotion-of-rest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Rest improves heart function by reducing venous return due to reduced work load. It reduces blood pressure and increases blood reserve in the veins. It also rests the respiratory system thus resulting into improved respiration and oxygen exchange.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="position-the-patient">Position the Patient<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#position-the-patient" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Position the patient in a sitting up position to reduce pulmonary congestion. This reduces venous return thus improving cardiac contraction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="digitalis-therapy">Digitalis Therapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digitalis-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Digitalis increases the force of contraction of the myocardium. It is helpful in patients suffering from atrial flutter, atrial fibrillation or fast ventricular rates. Digitalis therapy promotes diuresis thus reducing venous return. It also causes mild venous dilation which helps to increase venous pooling and reduce ventricular congestion.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vasodilators">Vasodilators<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vasodilators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Vasodilators are used to reduce arterial congestion hence lower central venous pressure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dopamine">Dopamine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dopamine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dopamine may be used. When in low doses of below 10 micrograms/min improves renal circulation thus reducing incidence of renal failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anti-arrhythmic-drugs">Anti-arrhythmic Drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anti-arrhythmic-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anti-arrhythmic drugs may be used to improve cardiac function.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cardiac-arrest">Cardiac Arrest<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-arrest" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In case of cardiac arrest, cardio-pulmonary resuscitation must be initiated within the next four minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="treatments-for-congestive-heart-failure">Treatments for Congestive Heart Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatments-for-congestive-heart-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In addition the patient should have their:</p>
<ul>
<li>Weighed checked daily</li>
<li>Sodium diet restricted</li>
<li>Oedema monitored</li>
<li>Urea and electrolyte levels tested to ensure balance and prevent weight gain</li>
<li>Input and output chart strictly maintained to evaluate renal function</li>
<li>Vital signs monitored to evaluate their condition and response to therapy</li>
<li>Right-sided heart monitored for failure</li>
</ul>
<p>Also give the patient general information on the disease and help them to attain self care status.</p>
<p>In the acute phase the patient should be:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maintained in the High-Fowlers position</li>
<li>Given oxygen, morphine, diuretics, nitroglycerine, and ionotropic drugs (These are drugs that increase the rate of contraction of the heart muscle)</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="heart-surgery">Heart Surgery<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heart-surgery" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Heart surgery is increasingly becoming common in our centres. These operations involve open-heart surgery for the reconstruction and repair of the heart valves. In developed countries innovations are making it possible for patients to undergo surgery without the chest being opened. This is done by passing fibre-optic instruments and catheters.</p>
<p>For cardiac surgery, the patient is usually placed under cardio pulmonary bypass. This is a form of extra corporeal circulation of blood to outside environment. This provides means of circulating and oxygenating blood without passing through the heart or the lung.</p>
<p>Heamodilution, hypothermia and heparinisation are done to prevent complications that may result from extra corporeal circulation.</p>
<p>Types of operations requiring open-heart surgery:</p>
<ul>
<li>Mitral valve commissurotomy - opening of fussed parts of the valve leaflet</li>
<li>Valve replacement, for example, aortic, mitral</li>
<li>Removal of cardiac tumours</li>
<li>Pericardectomy</li>
<li>Left ventricular aneurism</li>
<li>Surgical intervention in coronary artery disease</li>
<li>Heart transplant</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pre-operative-care">Pre-operative Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pre-operative-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Aimed at ensuring optimum heart function before surgery. Investigations are done to confirm the diagnosis and the operation to be done.</li>
<li>Patients and relatives have the fear of the unknown outcome. They are allowed enough time to express their fears. Reassurance is given to calm the patient and reduce their anxiety.</li>
<li>Patient and relatives are shown the expected pre-operative and post-</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>operative care. In Kenya visits are made to ICU to familiarise the family with the environment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-operative-care">Post-operative Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-operative-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Ensure proper rest to promote calm and healing</li>
<li>Monitor for any haemodynamic changes due to compromised myocardial function as a result of surgery</li>
<li>Monitor central venous pressure, maintain at 5-12cm of water</li>
<li>Assess peripheral pulses and warmth to ensure good peripheral perfusion</li>
<li>Ascultate for breath sound and heart sound to identify impaired gases exchange</li>
<li>Monitor blood pressure to identify hypotension early and ensure cerebral perfusion to prevent infarction</li>
<li>Monitor electrolytes at normal levels (K+ 3.5-5.0) (Na+ 135-145) milliEquivalents/litre (mEq/lt)</li>
<li>Monitor ECG, echocardiogram</li>
<li>Observe for blood loss, cardiac tamponade and hypotension</li>
<li>Ensure adequate gaseous exchange by giving oxygen, monitoring blood gases to prevent hypoxia.</li>
<li>Give strong analgesics, sedatives and anxiolytics to calm the patient and promote comfort.</li>
<li>Maintain adequate renal perfusion by monitoring urine output at -1ml/hr/body kg wt.</li>
<li>Monitor the patient for infection. Give antibiotics to prevent infection and maintain principles of asepsis during invasive procedures.</li>
<li>Teach the patient self-care. Give health education on post-surgery care and drugs to be used. Identify patient's worries and give psychological care.</li>
<li>Assist the patient in the rehabilitation process.</li>
<li>Dress the surgical wound, any signs of infection need to be identified and culture and sensitivity treatment done.</li>
<li>Tubes and gadgets of monitoring on the patient must be cared for well to prevent dislodgement and wrong reading.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-include">Complications include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cardiac tamponade</li>
<li>Heart failure</li>
<li>Myocardial infarction</li>
<li>Dysrhythmias</li>
<li>Cardiac arrest</li>
<li>Infection</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="shock">Shock<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#shock" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Shock occurs when there is inadequate blood flow to vital organs and/or inability to utilise oxygen by the tissues. It is characterised by hypotension.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification">Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Hypovolaemic Shock - this results from volume loss of blood. This may happen in diarrhoea and vomiting, bleeding and plasma loss in burns.</li>
<li>Cardiogenic Shock - this results from the inability of the heart to contract and supply the tissues with oxygenated blood, for example, infarctions, cardiac tamponade, pulmonary embolism, general anaesthesia or advanced hypovolaemia.</li>
<li>Neurogenic Shock - this results from dilated blood vessels as a result of drugs, for example, anaesthesia.</li>
<li>Distributive Shock - this is when blood does not reach the tissues.</li>
<li>Septic Shock - this is when blood arteries become dilated as a result of endotoxins from gram-negative micro-organisms.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Low arterial pressures stimulate the release of catecholamines which causes vasoconstriction and increase heart activity. Renin-angiotensin mechanism is also stimulated. This is where the kidney cells produce renin which acts on angiotensinogen to give angiotensin I. Angiotensin I passes through the lungs and it is activated by angiotensin converting enzyme into angiotensin II which cause generalised vasoconstriction. It also stimulates release of aldosterone compensatory mechanisms triggered by shock. Patients will manifest with a cold clammy skin, thready pulse, and low blood pressure among others.</p>
<p>Shock is managed by concentrating on the cause. The vital organs must receive adequate perfusion by positioning the patient on the left</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>lateral position, keeping them warm and giving IV fluids. The patient may require transfusion and haemostasis to stop bleeding. After the initial resuscitation, investigations can then start to focus on the real cause of the shock.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vascular-disorders">Vascular Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vascular-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="vascular-disorders">Vascular Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vascular-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Most disorders of the blood vessels commonly affect men after middle age and women after menopause, atheroma being one of those.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="atheroma">Atheroma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atheroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Atheroma is the accumulation of cholesterol compounds in the inner wall of the blood vessels. Predisposing factors are genetic, sex (males are commonly affected), environmental, smoking, obesity, certain lifestyles, alcohol and certain diets. The atheroma can lead to thrombosis or blood clots and the formation of aneurysms. Aneurysms are formed due to a weakened wall of an artery. The arteries affected can be narrowed or occluded. This may lead to tissue ischaemia and infarction. Diets that are high in saturated fats and also high in cholesterol can cause atheromas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="arteriosclerosis">Arteriosclerosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arteriosclerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Degeneration of arteries is associated with loss of elasticity and hardening of the vessel. When it affects the intima of the blood vessel, it is called arteriosclerosis.</p>
<p>Vessels lose their elasticity and their lumen becomes smaller.</p>
<p>A smaller lumen does not deliver blood to the target tissues efficiently. Arteriosclerosis can lead to stroke, myocardial infarction and cardiac arrest.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="embolism">Embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Embolism is an obstruction of the blood flow by an embolus in the blood. The emboli may be fragments of blood clots, tumours, pus, fat or air bubbles. Emboli can affect the heart, lung, liver or brain and result in ischaemia and infarction. Thrombi and emboli are common causes of cerebro-vascular accidents. You studied the pulmonary embolism earlier in the unit and you learnt how it comes about. The consequences of embolism are the same as those of atheromas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arterial-embolism">Arterial Embolism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arterial-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an emboli that is found in the arteries. It may develop from the chambers of the heart due to atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction, endocarditis, cardiac failure or as a result of transport from the venous circulation into the heart. It can also develop from arteriosclerosis.</p>
<p>When the thrombus is carried into the peripheral circulation, it results in blockage of blood circulation to the vessel. It tends to lodge in arterial diffusion and athelosclerotic narrowing.</p>
<p>Clinical features include severe pain aggravated by movement, gradual loss of sensory and motor function and reduced or lost pulse which is usually accompanied by sharp line of colour and temperature demarcation.</p>
<p>Embolectomy is the management of choice. This must be done early in 6-10 hrs to prevent permanent necrosis.</p>
<p>Intravenous anticoagulants like heparin may also be given to prevent propagation of the clot and reduce muscle neclosis. Thrombolytic therapy with streptokinase or urokinase is effective in dissoving of the clot.</p>
<p>In the post-operative period the patient is encouraged to perform simple exercises to promote blood flow. Pain is managed with strong analgesics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="varicose-veins-and-haemorrhoids">Varicose Veins and Haemorrhoids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#varicose-veins-and-haemorrhoids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Predisposing factors of varicosities are heredity, advanced age, obesity and high blood pressure. As one grows older, the veins lose their elasticity. The affected veins protrude and become tortuous. High blood pressure impedes venous return. Haemorrhoids, on the other hand, are due to increased pressure and structural weaknesses in the veins of the anus and rectum. Protrusion and difficulty in defecation are the initial manifestations, followed by bleeding and infection</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="raynauds-disease">Raynauds Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#raynauds-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is severe vasoconstriction resulting from vasospasms caused by environment stimuli. It involves small arteries and affects one or two digits unilaterally.</p>
<p>The main stimulant includes cold climate, pain and ulceration of finger tips. Patients presents with terrible pain which is associated with removal of ischemic materials when the vasoconstriction reduces.</p>
<p>Management involves avoidance of stimulant, though sympathectomy may improve the patient's condition</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aneurysms">Aneurysms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aneurysms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>These are out pouching or dilation of the arterial wall of a blood vessel. This condition commonly affects the aorta. They are associated with hypertension, atherosclerosis and smoking.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification">Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>True aneurysm: is when walls of the artery form aneurisms with at least one layer intact. A true aneurysm may be fusiform which is of circumferential and uniform shape or a saccular aneurysm which is pouch-like with a narrow neck bulging to one side.</li>
<li>False aneurysm: is also called pseudoaneurysm and has disruption of all the layers of the vessel resulting into bleeding. This may result from trauma, infection, disruption of arterial suture line, removal of canulas and catheters.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The walls of the blood vessels weaken and dilate with tabulate blood flow. Thrombi are deposited in the aortic wall resulting into danger of embolising.</p>
<p>In atherosclerosis, plaque deposited on the intima causes degenerative changes on the middle layer, thus leading to loss of elasticity, weakening and dilation of the vessel. The vessel may rupture.</p>
<p>A Ruptured aneurysm causes massive bleeding because of its turbulence. It also causes cerebral vascular accident when the rupture is in the brain. However the most common site for an aneurysm is the aorta.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features-of-aortic-aneurysm">Clinical features of Aortic Aneurysm<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features-of-aortic-aneurysm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Deep diffuse chest pain for ascending aorta</li>
<li>Hoarseness due to laryngeal nerve pressure for arch of aorta aneurysms</li>
<li>Dysphagia due to pressure an oesophagus</li>
<li>In case they press on the vena cava, they cause decreased venous-return resulting into oedema</li>
<li>Abdominal pain</li>
<li>Blue toe syndrome due to formation of emboli</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="management">Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Investigations:</p>
<ul>
<li>Physical examination</li>
<li>Chest X-ray</li>
<li>CT Scan</li>
<li>Autography</li>
<li>Echocardiogram</li>
</ul>
<p>The goal of management is to prevent rupture of the aneurysm. Detailed evaluation is done also to identify any existing problem or obstruction to blood flow that may be co-existing. The management of choice is surgical interventions. Surgical technique depends on location, size and pathophysiological effects.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-operative-care">Post-operative Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-operative-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The post-operative care is aimed at maintaining adequate tissue perfusion, intact motor neurological function and prevent complications related to surgery.</p>
<p>Where the patient may have altered peripheral tissue perfusion:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maintain adequate systemic blood pressure to prevent hypotension thrombosis and to maintain adequate blood flow to the graft. This helps to prevent rupture of the sutureline</li>
<li>Ensure normal central venous pressure to maintain hydration</li>
<li>Maintain patient on intravenous fluids</li>
<li>Assess the peripheral for warmth to identify impaired flow resulting from the graft</li>
</ul>
<p>Monitor the patient for any signs of hypovolemia related to bleeding, diuresis or fluid redistribution:</p>
<ul>
<li>Monitor the input and output and do adequate replacement</li>
<li>Check hematocrite and hemaglobin levels and transfuse as needed</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs and intervene when abnormal</li>
</ul>
<p>Where there is risk of infection due to presence of vascular graft or invasive lines:</p>
<ul>
<li>Ensure aseptic technique in invasive procedures</li>
<li>Check temperature to identify signs of infection</li>
<li>Give adequate nutrition to promote healing</li>
<li>Give broad spectrum antibiotics</li>
<li>Do white blood cells count regularly to rule out infection</li>
<li>Ensure that the changing of the catheter changing and dressing is done aseptically</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Where the patient may have altered renal perfusion related to operation procedure:</p>
<ul>
<li>Monitor urine output and maintain at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo></mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>ml/kg/min</mtext></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1}{2} - 1 \text{ml/kg/min}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s"></span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">ml/kg/min</span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Check urea and electrolyte levels</li>
</ul>
<p>Monitor neurological status related to poor cerebral perfusion due to surgical procedure during and after surgery.</p>
<p>If the patient has anxiety and requires the nurse's intervention:</p>
<ul>
<li>Explain the whole procedure to the patient and allow them to verbalise their worries</li>
</ul>
<p>When caring for the surgical incisions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Check for bleeding post-operation</li>
<li>Check for signs of infection</li>
<li>Change dressing as necessary</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="complications-include">Complications include:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#complications-include" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Cardiac tamponade</li>
<li>Renal failure</li>
<li>Cerebral insufficiency</li>
<li>Bleeding</li>
<li>Ruptured graft</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-the-adult-with-vascular-diseases">Care of the Adult with Vascular Diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-the-adult-with-vascular-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Occlusive disease can be treated with non-surgical and surgical means. The non-surgical treatment involves use of mild analgesics, walking daily as tolerated, foot care, avoidance of trauma and avoidance of tobacco. First, the individuals must avoid foods that can predispose to arterial depositions.</p>
<p>Nutritional care involves adjusting caloric intake to achieve optimum weight, decreasing dietary cholesterol, reducing saturated dietary fat and restricting sodium to 2g/day.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="care-of-patients-with-deep-vein-thrombosis-dvt">Care of Patients with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#care-of-patients-with-deep-vein-thrombosis-dvt" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Deep vein thrombosis is treated with both conservative and surgical measures. The conservative measures are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Continuous IV heparin</li>
<li>Bed rest</li>
<li>Elevation of the legs above the heart</li>
<li>Oral anticoagulants</li>
<li>Elastic stockings</li>
<li>Measurement and charting of the size of both thighs</li>
</ul>
<p>Any time you are caring for a patient with deep vein thrombosis, ensure that there is relief of pain, decreased oedema, no skin ulceration or any evidence of pulmonary embolism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-blood-and-the-lymphatic-tissue">Disorders of the Blood and the Lymphatic Tissue<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-blood-and-the-lymphatic-tissue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Any of the cellular components of the blood can be affected by disease. The cellular components were mentioned before, they are erythrocytes, platelets and leukocytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leucopoenia">Leucopoenia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leucopoenia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Leucopoenia is a decrease in the number of white blood cells. It may affect any of the specific types of white blood cells. Granulocytopenia is a decrease in circulating granulocytes.</p>
<p>In many cases, it is a result of drugs, irradiation, bone marrow disease or severe infections. Patients become susceptible to infections when the number of circulating white blood cells is low.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphoproliferative-diseases">Lymphoproliferative Diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphoproliferative-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lymphoproliferative disorders are those that affect the white blood cells and lymphoid tissue. They include leukaemia, lymphomas and multiple myeloma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leukaemia">Leukaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leukaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Leukaemia is a malignant neoplasm of the white blood cells. The types of leukaemia according to the predominant cell type are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Myelocytic leukaemia</li>
<li>Lymphocytic leukaemia</li>
</ul>
<p>They can also be classified according to whether they are acute or chronic. There is Acute Lymphocytic Leukaemia (ALL) and Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL) among others.</p>
<p>Acute Lymphocytic Leukaemia is common in children, while Acute Myelocytic Leukaemia is common in patients aged between 13 and 39 years.</p>
<p>Chronic Myelocytic Leukaemia (CML) and Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL) are common in the elder generation. The causes of leukaemia are not known. However, associated factors are irradiation, genetic predisposition, exposure to certain chemicals and viral infections.</p>
<p>The clinical manifestations include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bone marrow suppression</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Bone pain and tenderness</li>
<li>Headache</li>
<li>Nausea</li>
<li>Vomiting</li>
<li>Abdominal discomfort</li>
<li>Anaemia</li>
<li>Frequent infections</li>
</ul>
<p>Once a diagnosis of leukaemia has been made, therapeutic management includes chemotherapeutic drugs and sometimes radiation. The patient should be evaluated and support given to avoid complications such as haemorrhage and infection.</p>
<p>In more advanced treatment centres, bone marrow transplant is undertaken. Nurses should know the various drug combinations used for treatment of leukaemia and the cycles of treatment, the doses and side effects.</p>
<p>The specific nursing actions necessary are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Discussing the importance of follow up with the client and family</li>
<li>Providing emotional support</li>
<li>Providing specific care related to chemotherapy, transfusion, and diagnostic tests</li>
<li>Providing a safe, injury free environment</li>
<li>Using appropriate infection control techniques</li>
<li>Ensuring the patient does not develop fatigue</li>
<li>Providing nutritional support</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphoma">Lymphoma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A lymphoma is a malignancy of lymphatic tissue. They are divided into Hodgkin's disease and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hodgkin-s-disease">Hodgkin's disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hodgkin-s-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is characterised by abnormal proliferation of multinucleated cells in the lymph node known as Reed-Sternberg cells. It's of two types, Hodgkins paragramutoma which is milder and Hodgkins Sarcoma which is more severe.</p>
<p>Hodgkin's disease is characterised by enlargement of lymph nodes, which is not painful. Lymph nodes become enlarged and the spleen increases in size. Patients also suffer high-grade swinging fever, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue and anaemia.</p>
<p>The liver, lungs, digestive tract and central nervous system also get involved. Due to the proliferation of abnormal cells, the immunologic response is defective. Hodgkin's disease is staged according to lymphoid involvement. In the assessment, the objective data that may be obtained is:</p>
<ul>
<li>Enlarged lymph nodes</li>
<li>Progressive anaemia</li>
<li>Elevated temperature</li>
<li>Enlarged liver and spleen</li>
<li>Pressure symptoms due to enlarged nodes</li>
</ul>
<p>Hodgkin's disease is managed depending on the stage of the disease. Radiation, a combination of radiation and chemotherapy, or chemotherapy are the choice methods. The drug combination for Hodgkin's disease is:</p>
<ul>
<li>MOPP - Nitrogen Mustard and vincristine (Oncovin) on day 1 and day 8, Procarbazine and prednisone on day 1 and day 14</li>
<li>ABVD - Doxorubicin (Adriamycin) and Bleomycin on day 1 and day 15, Vinblastine and Darcabazine on day 1 and day 15</li>
</ul>
<p>Skin therapy, psychological and social aspects are included in each case. The nursing actions are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Providing emotional support</li>
<li>Protecting the patient from infection</li>
<li>Monitoring the patient's temperature</li>
<li>Observing for symptoms of anaemia and managing accordingly</li>
<li>Encouraging good nutrition</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-hodgkin-s-lymphomas">Non-Hodgkin's Lymphomas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-hodgkin-s-lymphomas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>One type of Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma is Burkitt's lymphoma, which is common in Kenya. It may affect the jaw or abdomen. Patients present with fever, frequent infections, enlarged asymmetrical jaw, abdominal mass and anaemia. Medical and nursing management is similar to that of Hodgkin's disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="multiple-myeloma">Multiple Myeloma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiple-myeloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Multiple Myeloma is a disorder of the plasma cell (B lymphocytes). There is abnormal proliferation of plasma cells. The first symptoms to appear are bone pain, weight loss, pathological fractures and weakness. This may progress to heart failure, neurological problems and renal failure.</p>
