<p>Multiple myeloma can be easily treated if diagnosed early, by addressing both the disease and its symptoms.</p>
<p>Ambulation and hydration are used to treat hypercalcemia accompanying multiple myeloma,</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>hyperuricemia and dehydration. Weight bearing helps the bones reabsorb some calcium. Pain control and chemotherapy are all part of the management. Some drugs such as allopurinol may be used to counteract the hyperuricaemia (that may cause gout) due to chemotherapy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-red-blood-cells-and-coagulation">Disorders of the Red Blood Cells and Coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-red-blood-cells-and-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The red blood cells are involved in oxygen transport and fine pH adjustment. After about 120 days, the red blood cells become old and are destroyed, resulting in the formation of bilirubin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anaemia">Anaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Anaemia is a condition in which there is a low number of circulating red blood cells and, therefore, abnormally low haemoglobin, which is defined according to age, sex and geographical location. Anaemia can result from:</p>
<ul>
<li>Excessive loss through bleeding</li>
<li>Deficient cell production because of nutritional deficiencies and bone marrow failure</li>
<li>Premature or excessive haemolysis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="sickle-cell-anaemia">Sickle Cell Anaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#sickle-cell-anaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a disorder that affects the red blood cells which contain a special protein called haemoglobin (Hb for short). The function of haemoglobin is to carry oxygen from the lungs to all parts of the body.</p>
<p>People with Sickle Cell Anaemia have Sickle haemoglobin (HbS) which is different from the normal haemoglobin (HbA). When sickle haemoglobin gives up its oxygen to the tissues, it sticks together to form long rods inside the red blood cells making these cells rigid and sickle-shaped. Normal red blood cells can bend and flex easily.</p>
<p>Because of their shape, sickled red blood cells can't squeeze through small blood vessels as easily as the almost disc-shaped normal cells. This can lead to these small blood vessels getting blocked which then stops the oxygen from getting through to where it is needed. This in turn can lead to severe pain and damage to organs. The most affected parts are joints, however the abdomen and chest can also be affected. Sometimes infarction can occur in tissues lacking oxygen.</p>
<p>It is important for you to be able to differentiate between sickle cell trait, sickle cell disease and sickle cell crisis.</p>
<p>A person with sickle cell trait does not have the disease but carries the gene that causes the disease. Persons with sickle cell trait usually have both HbS and HbA, but the HbA is more thus preventing the person from having symptoms of sickle cell disease. If two people with sickle cell trait get married there is a 25% chances of bearing children with sickle cell disease. They therefore require genetic counselling before marriage.</p>
<p>A sickle cell crisis occurs when sickled red blood cells block small blood vessels that carry blood. This causes pain that can begin suddenly and last several hours to several days. The patient might have pain in their back, knees, legs, arms, chest or stomach. The pain can be throbbing, sharp, dull or stabbing. A sickle cell crisis can also cause a severe attack of anaemia.</p>
<p>The mode of management of a patient who has sickle cell disease involves pain control, treatment for anaemia and patient education. These patients must be given genetic counselling.</p>
<p>The therapeutic management of sickle cell disease is mainly supportive with alleviation of symptoms such as chronic leg ulcers, which are treated with bed rest, antibiotics and dressings.</p>
<p>Since nutritional anaemia's are more common in our population, it will be necessary to learn more about them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nutritional-deficiency-anaemia">Nutritional Deficiency Anaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutritional-deficiency-anaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Iron deficiency anaemia is usually caused by dietary lack of iron. Hookworm infestation and deficiencies of other foods can also cause iron deficiency.</p>
<p>Megaloblastic anaemia, on the other hand, is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, pernicious anaemia and folic acid deficiency. Pernicious anaemia is anaemia caused by a lack of intrinsic factor leading to a lack of absorption of vitamin B12. Fish tapeworm infestation can also cause megaloblastic anaemia.</p>
<p>The causes of anaemia generally are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Deficiency of materials for synthesis of haemoglobin, through deficient diets, malabsorption, high demands through pregnancy and lactation, drugs that lead to non-absorption, bowel disease that causes poor absorption, and pernicious anaemia</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<ul>
<li>Blood loss</li>
<li>Destruction of red blood cells</li>
<li>Failure to produce red blood cells</li>
<li>Blood cell cancers</li>
</ul>
<p>There are several manifestations of anaemia. When assessing a patient, look for:</p>
<ul>
<li>Brittle hair</li>
<li>Signs of fatigue</li>
<li>Dyspnoea</li>
<li>Palpitations</li>
<li>A smooth tongue</li>
<li>Dysphasia</li>
</ul>
<p>Other manifestations include decreased sensation, pallor, rapid pulse, faintness and dizziness, high output heart failure and spoon shaped nails (koilonychia). High output failure is congestive failure because of overload, which affects the left side of the heart. In some of the vitamin deficiencies, loss of sensation may be a clinical sign.</p>
<p>When managing anaemic patients, you should try to ensure that they can participate in activities of daily living (ADL's), experience no fatigue and replace essential nutrients. The different causes of anaemia will determine the different nursing interventions. Dietary changes, blood transfusion and pharmacologic agents can be tried.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="aplastic-anaemia">Aplastic Anaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aplastic-anaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bone marrow suppression results in aplastic anaemia. Aplastic anaemia is due to irradiation, infections, drugs such as chloraphenical, and toxic chemicals. Cytotoxic therapy can result in aplastic anaemia. Aplasia results in failure to produce blood cells, leading to a reduction in leucocytes, erythrocytes and thrombocytes. The red bone marrow gets replaced with fatty tissue. Due to involvement of different cells in the bone marrow, patient may present with abnormal cellular levels. There could be marked bleeding due to thrombocytopenia, pallor, weakness, breathlessness on exertion, dyspnoea and fever.</p>
<p>Management involves a bone marrow transplant to provide the patient with intact hemopoietic tissue. Antilympholytic globulin and high dose of methypredinison therapy is given. Careful assessment and supportive therapy is important for these patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="polycythaemia">Polycythaemia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#polycythaemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When the red blood cell mass is abnormally high, the condition is called polycythaemia vera. The haemoglobin level is abnormally high. It may occur with living at high altitude. The blood becomes thick and this can result in hypertension.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="coagulation-disorders">Coagulation Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#coagulation-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The process of coagulation involves vessel spasm, platelet aggregation, and formation of fibrin clot, clot retraction and fibrinolysis afterwards. This was mentioned when you covered the process of blood clotting. The conditions associated with hypercoagulation are atherosclerosis, diabetes mellitus, smoking, high cholesterol, pregnancy and puerperium. Immobility and malignancies accelerate the activity of the clotting system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disseminated-intravascular-coagulation">Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disseminated-intravascular-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Coagulation defects, on the other hand, result in easy bleeding. This is initiated by situations where there is massive consumption of coagulation factors leading to easy bleeding. Endothelial damage resulting from many causes, for example, obstetric conditions such as placental abruption, malignancies, severe burns, severe infection and severe malaria, shock, surgery and blood transfusion reaction can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).</p>
<p>This is a life threatening condition that you may have heard about. The therapeutic management of DIC involves relief of the underlying cause, for example, IV antibiotic for suspected septicaemia. Exacerbating factors such as acidosis, dehydration, renal failure and hypoxia should be corrected. Blood transfusion to correct identified deficiencies such as platelets, fibrinogen, and so on, should be given. Here you must remember that observing for any bleeding, minimising skin punctures and providing emotional support are important nursing actions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="haemophilia">Haemophilia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#haemophilia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Haemophilia A is a sex linked disorder which is characterised by reduced or absent factor VIII activity, while haemophilia B is a similar disease but is due to the absence of or reduced factor IX. The main characteristic of haemophilia is persistent bleeding into joints and muscles, hence crippling arthritis. Easy bleeding is the hallmark of the disease. The female is the</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>carrier; but it is her male offspring that may suffer</p>
<p>Management of haemophilia includes emergency measures to prevent bleeding and administration of the missing clotting factors after proper investigation. Use of blood products and transfusion are necessary measures while investigations are undertaken. The main role of the nurse in this situation is health education on healthy living and avoidance of injury by the patient.</p>
<p>When you are caring for patients with haemophilia you must ensure measures are taken to stop the bleeding as soon as possible, administer specific coagulation factor, give rest and manage any life threatening complications.</p>
<p>Most of the long-term measures are related to education. All activities of daily living should be done with utmost care to avoid trauma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-transfusion-reaction">Blood Transfusion Reaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-transfusion-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The reactions that are likely to occur during a blood transfusion include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Acute haemolytic reactions</li>
<li>Febrile reactions</li>
<li>Mild allergic reaction</li>
<li>Circulatory overload</li>
<li>Sepsis</li>
<li>Massive transfusion reactions</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-transfusion-reaction">Blood Transfusion Reaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-transfusion-reaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If a patient on blood transfusion gets a transfusion reaction, you should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Stop the transfusion</li>
<li>Maintain a patent IV line with saline solution</li>
<li>Notify the blood bank and a physician immediately</li>
<li>Re-check identifying tags</li>
<li>Monitor vital signs and urine output strictly</li>
<li>Save the blood bag for cross checking with appropriate patient details</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="section-3-genitourinary-system-and-the-integuments">SECTION 3: GENITOURINARY SYSTEM AND THE INTEGUMENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#section-3-genitourinary-system-and-the-integuments" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>In section four, part one of this unit you covered the digestive system where you looked at the digestion, absorption, assimilation, metabolism and storage of proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins and minerals. The last stage of this cycle is excretion.</p>
<p>In this section you will focus on the genitourinary system and the integuments.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-e7b42504.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>By the end of this section you will be able to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Describe the structure and function of the urinary system</li>
<li>List common genitourinary disorders and conditions</li>
<li>Describe the structure and function of the integuments</li>
<li>List common skin disorders</li>
<li>Describe the nursing process in the management of diseases and conditions outlined in this section</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-kidneys">The Kidneys<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-kidneys" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The kidney is an important organ of excretion. If kidneys fail completely, then there is a threat to survival.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="structure">Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The kidneys are bean shaped organs located behind the peritoneum on either side of the vertebral column, from the 12th thoracic</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>vertebral to the third lumbar vertebra.</p>
<p>Each kidney is about 11cm long, 7cm wide and 3cm thick and weighs 120-170g. The right kidney is slightly lower than the left probably due to the space occupied by the liver.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-e40db4a8.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gross-structure-of-the-kidney">Gross Structure of the Kidney<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gross-structure-of-the-kidney" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A thin, smooth layer of fibrous membrane, called the capsule, covers the surface of each kidney. The lateral surface of the kidney is convex and the medial surface is concave and forms a vertical cleft called the hilum where the renal blood and lymph vessels and nerves enter and renal vein and ureters exit.</p>
<p>On cutting the kidney longitudinally, various internal structures can be seen. The outer layer is the cortex while the inner part is the medulla. The medulla is made up of many pyramids. The apices of these pyramids are called papillae. It is through these papillae that urine passes to enter minor calyces, which merge to form major calyces. The calyces form the funnel shaped renal pelvis. The lumen of the pelvis decreases to form the ureter.</p>
<p>The major calyces form the funnel shaped renal pelvis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopic-structure-of-the-kidney">Microscopic Structure of the Kidney<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopic-structure-of-the-kidney" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The functional unit of the kidney is the nephron. Each kidney has more than one million nephrons. A nephron consists of a glomerulus, Bowman's capsule and a tubular system. The</p>
<p>tubular system has a proximal convoluted tubule, loop of Henle, and the distal convoluted tubule.</p>
<p>Many distal convoluted tubules drain into a collecting duct. The glomerulus, Bowman's capsule, the proximal and distal tubules are in the cortex while the loop of Henle and the collecting ducts are in the medulla.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-adfe214f.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blood-vessels">Blood Vessels<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blood-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>After entering the kidney at the hilum, the renal artery divides into smaller arteries and arterioles. In the cortex an arteriole, the afferent arteriole enters each glomerular capsule then subdivides into a cluster of capillaries forming the glomerulus.</p>
<p>The blood vessel leading away from the glomerulus is the efferent arteriole. It breaks up into a second capillary network to supply oxygen and nutritional materials to the remainder of the nephron.</p>
<p>Venous blood drained from the capillary bed leaves the kidney in the renal vein which empties into the inferior vena cava.</p>
<p>The blood pressure in the glomerulus is higher than in other capillaries because the diameter of the afferent arteriole is greater than that of the efferent arteriole.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-the-glomerulus-glomerular-capsule-and-tubule-walls">Structure of the Glomerulus Glomerular Capsule and Tubule walls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-the-glomerulus-glomerular-capsule-and-tubule-walls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The walls of the glomerulus and the glomerular capsule consists of a single layer of flattened</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers</p>
<p>epithelial cells. The glomerular walls are more permeable than those of other capillaries. The remainder of the nephrone and the collecting tube are formed by a single layer of highly specialised cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="functions-of-the-kidney">Functions of the Kidney<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-the-kidney" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The primary function of the kidneys is to regulate the volume and composition of the Extracellular Fluid (ECF). The excretory function of the kidneys is secondary to this regulatory function. Other major functions include renin secretion and blood pressure control, erythropoietin production, vitamin D activation and acid base balance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-physiology-of-urine-formation">The Physiology of Urine Formation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-physiology-of-urine-formation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The kidneys form urine which passes through the ureters to the bladder for excretion. There are three phases in the formation of urine:</p>
<ul>
<li>Simple filtration</li>
<li>Selective reabsorption</li>
<li>Secretion</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="simple-filtration">Simple Filtration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#simple-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Filtration takes place through the semipermeable walls of the glomerulus and glomerular capsule. The hydrostatic pressure of blood within the glomerular capillaries causes a portion of blood to be filtered across the semi-permeable membrane into Bowman's capsule, where the filtered portion of the blood called the glomerular filtrate begins to pass down to the tubule. The filtrate is similar in composition to blood except that it lacks blood cells, platelets and large plasma proteins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="simple-filtration">Simple Filtration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#simple-filtration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The amount of blood filtered by the glomeruli in a given time is termed as the Glomerular Filtrate Rate (GFR) and the normal glomerular filtrate rate is about 125ml per minute. On the average only 1ml per minute is excreted as urine because most glomerular filtrate is reabsorbed by the peritubular capillary before it reaches the end of the collecting duct.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="selective-reabsorption">Selective Reabsorption<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selective-reabsorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Selective reabsorption is the process by which the composition and volume of the glomerular filtrate are altered during its passage through the convoluted tubules, the medullary loop and the collecting tubule. The general purpose of this is</p>
<p>to reabsorb those filtrate constituents needed by the body to maintain fluid and electrolyte balance and blood alkalinity.</p>
<p>The tubules and collecting ducts carry out the functions by means of reabsorption and secretion.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-af41c608.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg"></p>
<p>Reabsorption is the passage of a substance from the lumen of the tubules into the capillaries while tubular secretion is the passage of a substance from the capillaries into the lumen of the tubule. The process involves both active and passive transport.</p>
<p>At the proximal convoluted tubule, about 80% of the electrolytes are reabsorbed, that is all the glucose, amino acids and protein, and hydrogen ions and creatinine are secreted.</p>
<ul>
<li>In the loop of Henle, the descending loop reabsorbs water moderately, sodium, urea and other solutes while the ascending loop reabsorbs chloride ions and sodium.</li>
<li>In the distal tubules, there is reabsorption of water and sodium through the action of antidiuretic hormone and secretion of potassium.</li>
<li>Acid base balance regulation involves the reabsorption of the bicarbonate (HCO3-) and secretion of excess hydrogen ions (H+).</li>
<li>The parathyroid hormone, parathormone increases the reabsorption of calcium ions and decreases the reabsorption of phosphate ions.</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 215 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="secretion">Secretion<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secretion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This involves secretion of substances not required and foreign materials for example drugs that may not be cleared from the blood by filtration due to the short time it remains in the glomerulus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-composition-of-normal-urine">The Composition of Normal Urine<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-composition-of-normal-urine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Water = 96%
Urea = 2%
Uric acid
Creatinine
Ammonia
Sodium
Potassium
Chlorides
Phosphates
Sulphates
Oxalates</p>
<p>Urine is termed as transparent yellow or amber or straw-coloured, with a specific gravity of 1.001-1.035 and is acidic in reaction (PH 4.6 - 8.0). A healthy adult passes 1000 to 1500ml per day which varies with fluid intake.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-ureters">The Ureters<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-ureters" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-structure">The Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The ureters are two tubes which originate from the renal pelvis. They pass behind the peritoneum into the pelvic cavity. They pass through the posterior (rear) part into the urinary bladder. They are, therefore, compressed and their opening closed when bladder pressure rises during micturition. This prevents urinary reflux.</p>
<p>They are made up of an outer fibrous tissue, a middle muscular layer and an inner epithelium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The ureters propel the urine from the kidneys into the bladder by peristaltic contraction of the muscular wall.</p>
<p>The waves of contraction originate in a pace maker in the minor calyces and send urine in little spurts into the bladder.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-8f78f570.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-urinary-bladder">The Urinary Bladder<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-urinary-bladder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="the-structure">The Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The bladder is roughly pear shaped but becomes more oval as it fills with urine. It has anterior, superior and posterior surfaces. The posterior surface is the base. The bladder opens into the urethra and its lowest point which is the neck.</p>
<p>The peritoneum covers only the superior surface. It is adjacent to the uterus and the rectum. Its wall is made up of three layers of tissue with blood vessels. The middle is a smooth muscle (dartos muscle) and the inner layer is composed of epithelial cells. The three openings in the bladder, that is, from the two ureters and the urethra, form a triangle. At the opening of the urethra, there is a sphincter called the internal sphincter made of a thickening of smooth muscle. The external sphincter is composed of voluntary muscle.</p>
<p>On average 200-250ml of urine in the bladder causes moderate distension and the urge to urinate. When the quantity of urine in the bladder reaches 400-600ml the individual feels uncomfortable. The bladder capacity varies with individuals and usually ranges from 600-1000ml.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="functions">Functions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>To serve as a reservoir for urine</li>
<li>To help the body eliminate waste products</li>
</ul>
<p>Bishops Computers
Page 216 of 425
Bishops Computers</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-urethra">The Urethra<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-urethra" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-structure">The Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The urethra is a small muscular tube or canal that loads from the bladder neck to the external meatus. In the male, it is a common pathway for semen and urine and consists of a prostatic urethra, a membranous urethra and a spongy urethra.</p>
<p>There are two sphincters for the urethra: the internal one, just mentioned in conjunction with the bladder and the external sphincter at the root of the penis. In the female the urethra is approximately 4cm long and opens at the external urethral orifice just in front of the vagina.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="function">Function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It serves as a pathway for urine from the bladder to the outside of the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="micturition">Micturition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#micturition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Micturition is also termed as urination or voiding. In the average bladder, 250ml of urine causes a moderately distended sensation and the desire to void.</p>
<ul>
<li>When the nervous system is fully developed the micturition reflex is stimulated but sensory impulses pass upwards to the brain and there is an awareness of the desire to micturate. By conscious effort, reflex contraction of the bladder wall and relaxation of the internal sphincter can be inhibited for a limited period of time.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanism-of-micturition">Mechanism of Micturition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-micturition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>This begins when the detrusor muscle contracts and there is reflex relaxation of the internal sphincter and voluntary relaxation of the external sphincter. This forces the urine out of the bladder and through the urethra.</li>
<li>It can be assisted by increasing the pressure within the pelvic cavity by lowering the diaphragm and contracting the abdominal muscles.</li>
<li>In over distension of the bladder, there is a tendency for involuntary relaxation of the external sphincter muscle to occur.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="associated-structures-of-the-urinary-system">Associated Structures of the Urinary System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#associated-structures-of-the-urinary-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The associated structures in the female include the uterus and the vagina. You will cover these</p>
<p>in module two as part of reproductive health.</p>
<p>In the male, the associated structures are the testes, scrotum, spermatic cords, seminal vesicles, ejaculatory ducts and the prostate gland. The testes are the reproductive organs and are equivalent to the ovaries. The spermatic cords suspend the testes in the scrotum. The seminal vesicles are near the bladder and they are connected by the ejaculatory duct to the urethra. They secrete a fluid that nourishes the spermatozoa.</p>
<p>The prostate gland lies in the pelvic cavity. It has glandular tissue and secretes lubricating fluid through the urethra.</p>
<p>You need to keep this information in mind because it will be mentioned in the module on reproductive health.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="disorders-of-the-kidney-bladder-and-associated-organs">Disorders of the Kidney, Bladder and Associated Organs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-kidney-bladder-and-associated-organs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-tract-obstruction">Urinary Tract Obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-tract-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Obstructive symptoms of urine flow depend on whether the flow is obstructed unilaterally or bilaterally, partially or completely. When there is obstruction, urine flows back and stays longer in the renal pelvis. The stasis predisposes to bacterial multiplication, hence inflammation of the renal pelvis and the cortex. Prolonged blockage can lead to damage of the kidneys.</p>
<p>The factors that can lead to urinary obstruction include renal stones (calculi), abnormal pregnancy, hypertrophy of the prostate, tumours, neurological disorders such as spinal injury and scars resulting from inflammation. Obstruction can occur at the level of the renal pelvis, the ureter, bladder or urethra.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-tract-obstruction">Urinary Tract Obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-tract-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Hydronephrosis is the dilation of the renal pelvis due to obstruction to urine flow. Hydroureter is dilation of the ureter due to obstruction.</p>
<p>The manifestations of urinary obstruction are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Pain</li>
<li>Hypertension</li>
<li>Impaired ability to concentrate urine</li>
<li>Signs and symptoms of urinary tract infection</li>
</ul>
<p>These will be covered later.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-calculi">Renal Calculi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-calculi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Renal calculi (renal stones) are formed by substances normally excreted in the urine. The stones can be made of calcium, magnesium,</p>
<p>ammonium phosphate, uric acid or cystein compounds. Contributing factors to formation of stones are hypercalcaemia, immobilisation, hyperthyroidism, urinary tract infections, gout, cytotoxic therapy, and a diet that is rich in purines. Pain is the major symptom of the stones. They can also cause other symptoms related to obstruction. People who get severe dehydration are at risk of stone formation if they are predisposed.</p>
<p>Kidney stones are managed by focusing on two approaches. The first approach is directed towards management of acute attacks. This involves treatment of pain, infection and obstruction to urine flow. Large amounts of fluid intake are recommended. The second approach is directed towards evaluation of the aetiology of stone formation. In this case emphasis is laid on hydration, dietary modifications and drugs. The diet restriction is to decrease foods rich in purines (such as sardines, liver, chicken).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260110-551955c7.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-tract-infections">Urinary Tract Infections<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-tract-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The infections that are included under urinary tract are cystitis, pyelonephritis, urethritis, ureteritis and bacturia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacteriuria">Bacteriuria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriuria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Is the presence of bacteria in urine. Most upper urinary tract infections ascend from the bladder and urethra. Factors predisposing to urinary tract infection are urinary tract obstruction, urine stasis and pregnancy induced changes. Foreign bodies like catheters and other instruments predispose to urinary tract infection. Pregnancy and old age are risk factors to urinary tract infections. This is because pregnant women and old people have decreased immunity. Lower abdominal pain, dysuria, fever and general malaise are commonly associated with urinary tract infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cystitis">Cystitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cystitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Is inflammation of the urinary bladder, is common in females because of their short urethra. It manifests with frequency of urination, urgency of micturition, supra-pubic pain, dysuria, and foul smelling urine. Urgency refers to a feeling of wanting to urinate quickly without delay, while frequency is the increased number of times one has to urinate. When a patient presents with cystitis they receive antimicrobial agents and must be encouraged to have high fluid intake. The purpose of this management is to have relief of dysuria, reduce upper urinary tract complications and avoid recurrence of Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs). Urinary catheterisation in the hospital should always be aseptic to decrease the risk of nosocomial UTI's.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urethritis">Urethritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urethritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Can be specific or non-specific. Gonococci or other organisms cause specific urethritis. If it is non-specific, then no particular micro-organisms are implicated. Non-specific urethritis manifests with discharge, itching, urgency, frequency and dysuria. Nocturia, red swollen urinary meatus and pelvic inflammatory disease may also be present. Urethritis is treated on the basis of the cause and symptoms of the disease. Antibiotics and antimicrobial agents such as tinidazole, doxycycline, benzathine penicillin, and norfloxacin are drugs that can benefit the patient depending on the sensitivity of the involved micro-organisms. Analgesics are also</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>given. Urethral sounding, analgesics, antibiotic cover can also be tried and when these measures are unsuccessful, surgery is indicated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pyelonephritis">Pyelonephritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pyelonephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Is the inflammation of the renal pelvis, tubules and interstitial cells of one or both kidneys. Its causes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Reflux of urine due to obstruction or congenital structural abnormalities</li>
<li>Renal infections</li>
<li>Trauma</li>
<li>Metabolic disease, which causes destruction of adjacent renal tissue. The commonest metabolic disease implicated is diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>There is swelling of the renal parenchyma, scarring, kidney atrophy, and if not checked, failure</li>
</ul>
<p>The clinical picture of the patient with pyelonephritis includes: frequency, dysuria, chills, fever, malaise and dull back pain. If it gets chronic, headache, anorexia, weight loss and the uremic syndrome may occur. Adults who present with pyelonephritis will be treated with antibiotics; antiseptics and high fluid intake as recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ureteritis">Ureteritis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ureteritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Is an inflammation of the ureters and is commonly associated with pyelonephritis. Once the kidney infection is cured, ureteral inflammation usually subsides. Unfortunately, chronic pyelonephritis causes the ureters to become fibrotic and narrowed by strictures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-the-glomerular-function">Disorders of the Glomerular Function<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-the-glomerular-function" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Disorders of the glomeruli disrupt filtration and affect the capillary membrane, making it easily permeable. This results in proteinuria, haematuria, oliguria, hypertension and azotemia. Azotemia is an increase of the products of protein metabolism such as urea and ammonia.</p>
<p>Nephrotic syndrome is a clinical disorder resulting from increased permeability to protein.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-do-patients-with-nephrotic-syndrome-present">How do patients with nephrotic syndrome present?<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-do-patients-with-nephrotic-syndrome-present" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Patients with nephrotic syndrome present with generalised oedema and proteinuria, which are the most common manifestations. Idiopathic</p>
<p>thickening of the basement membrane that occurs in diabetes mellitus can cause it.</p>
<p>Give bed rest to the patient with nephrotic syndrome and dietary care to include high protein, low sodium and high calorie. Diuretics and other drugs may be used and the patient should be protected from infection.</p>
<p>On the other hand, nephritis manifests with decreased filtration rate, haematuria, oliguria, azotemia and hypertension. There is little proteinuria and oedema. It is a result of inflammation arising from an autoimmune disease or infection.</p>
<p>Among the disorders that can be grouped together as nephritic syndromes is acute glomerulonephritis, which may be due to bacteria and viruses. Streptococci are sometimes involved in acute glomerulonephritis.</p>
<p>Chronic glomerulonephritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis are the other disorders included among the nephritic syndromes.</p>
<p>Acute glomerulonephritis presents with oliguria, proteinuria, haematuria, oedema, and hypertension. The patient with acute glomerulonephritis will be treated with two main objectives in mind.</p>
<p>The first one is to protect poorly functioning kidneys.</p>
<ul>
<li>Bed rest</li>
<li>Restriction of activities until Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) and BP are normal</li>
<li>Restriction of dietary protein if BUN is high and if there is oliguria</li>
<li>Liberal use of carbohydrates</li>
<li>Monitoring of vital functions, intake and output</li>
<li>Daily weighing</li>
<li>Giving fluids liberally</li>
</ul>
<p>The second objective is to recognise and treat complications promptly. This is done by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Explaining the complications to the patient</li>
<li>Treating the infection</li>
<li>Observing closely for symptoms of renal failure</li>
<li>Evaluating for any other complications</li>
</ul>
<p>When there is oedema, fluids are given with caution and sodium is restricted.</p>
<p>Chronic glomerulonephritis presents with oliguria, proteinuria, haematuria, oedema,</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>and hypertension. This disease represents the last stage and may signal the onset of renal failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="renal-failure">Renal Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Renal failure describes the inability of the kidneys to remove metabolic waste products and regulate fluids, electrolytes and the pH. It may be acute or chronic. Renal failure is caused by many factors, which can be divided into pre-renal, intra-renal and post-renal causes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-renal-failure">Acute Renal Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Is a clinical syndrome characterised by a rapid decline in renal function with progressive azotemia (an accumulation of nitrogenous waste products such as Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) and increasing levels of creatinine). Acute renal failure is associated with a decrease in urinary output to less than 400ml per day.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="causes-of-acute-renal-failure-pre-renal">Causes of Acute Renal Failure Pre-renal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#causes-of-acute-renal-failure-pre-renal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These consist of factors outside the kidneys that reduce renal blood flow. They are the most common causes of renal failure and accounts for 70% of all the cases, examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Hypovolaemia which may be from diarrhoea, haemorrhage, vomiting, excessive use of diuretics, burns and glycosuria.</li>
<li>Drugs that may start or complicate pre-renal azotemia, for example Nonsteroidal Anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID).</li>
<li>States of decreased cardiac output such as congestive heart failure, acute pulmonary embolus.</li>
<li>Decreased vascular resistance as in anaesthesia.</li>
<li>Vasodilatation and sepsis.</li>
<li>Vascular obstruction, for example aneurysm and bilateral renal artery occlusion.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intra-renal-or-renal">Intra-renal or Renal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intra-renal-or-renal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are conditions that cause direct renal damage to the renal tissue (parenchyma) or changes that result in the malfunction of the nephrons. Intra-renal causes account for approximately 25% of all the cases. Examples include:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Nephrotoxic substances, for example aminoglycosides, antibiotics, heavy metals</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acute tubular necrosis (most common renal cause)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Glomerulonephritis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Acute pyelonephritis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Trauma</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Metabolic disorders</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Renal vascular lesions</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="post-renal">Post-renal<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#post-renal" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These involve mechanical obstruction of urinary outflow in the urinary tract from the renal tubules to the urethral meatus. As the flow of urine is blocked, urine backs up into the renal pelvis resulting in renal failure. Post renal causes account for less than 5% of the cases. The most common causes are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Benign prostatic hyperplasia</li>
<li>Renal calculi</li>
<li>Prostrate cancer</li>
<li>Tumours</li>
<li>Urethral or bladder cancer</li>
<li>Cervical cancer</li>
<li>Trauma</li>
<li>Post-surgical or traumatic interruption or retroperitoneal fibrosis</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology-of-acute-renal-failure">Pathophysiology of Acute Renal Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology-of-acute-renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Renal vasoconstriction:</p>
<ul>
<li>Hypovolaemia and decreased renal blood flow stimulate renin release which activates the angiotensin-aldosterone system.</li>
<li>This results in constriction of the peripheral arteries and the renal afferent arterioles.</li>
<li>With decreased renal blood flow, there is decreased glomerular capillary pressure and glomerular filtrate rate, tubular dysfunction and oliguria.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology-of-acute-renal-failure">Pathophysiology of Acute Renal Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology-of-acute-renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cellular Oedema:</p>
<ul>
<li>Ischaemia causes anoxia which leads to endothelial cell oedema.</li>
<li>Cellular oedema raises tissue pressure above capillary flow pressure. Inadequate renal blood flow which results further depresses the GFR.</li>
</ul>
<p>Decreased glomerular capillary permeability: Ischaemia alters glomerular epithelial cells and decreases glomerular capillary permeability. This in turn reduces GFR, which significantly</p>
<p>Bishops Computers
Bishops Computers</p>
<p>reduces blood flow and this finally leads to tubular dysfunction.</p>
<p>Intratubular obstruction: When the renal tubules are damaged, the necrotic epithelial cells accumulate in the tubules. The accumulated debris also lowers the GFR.</p>
<p>Leakage of glomerular filtrate: The glomerular filtrate leaks back into plasma through the holes in the damaged tubuless and this decreases intratubular fluid flow.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="clinical-features">Clinical Features<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Has a rapid onset which results from retention of fluids, metabolic wastes and the inability to regulate electrolytes.</li>
<li>The patient is acutely ill and may suffer from acidosis, anaemia, fluid and electrolytes imbalances, fluid overload or deficit and gastrointestinal distress.</li>
<li>Oliguria (urine output of less than 400ml per day) or anuria (urine output of less than 100ml/day).</li>
<li>Oedema and hypertension when the fluid intake exceeds the urinary output and insensible losses (skin and lungs).</li>
<li>Signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure and pulmonary oedema in excessive fluid overload.</li>
<li>Symptoms of uremia - nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, fatigue, shortness of breath, confusion, convulsions, coma or gastrointestinal bleeding.</li>
<li>Fever, pleuric pain from pericarditis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-phases-of-acute-renal-failure">The Phases of Acute Renal Failure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-phases-of-acute-renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are three phases:</p>
<ul>
<li>Onset</li>
<li>Oliguric Phase</li>
<li>Diuretic Phase</li>
<li>Recovery Phase</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="onset">Onset<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#onset" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is the initial phase of injury to the kidney and reversal or prevention of kidney dysfunction is possible.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oliguric-phase">Oliguric Phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oliguric-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Urine is less than 400ml/day.</li>
<li>Is accompanied by a rise in serum concentration of the elements usually secreted by the kidneys (urea, creatinine, uric acid and intracellular cations potassium and magnesium).</li>
<li>The patient is acutely ill and the phase lasts approximately 10 - 14 days.</li>
<li>The longer this phase, the worse the prognosis.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diuretic-phase">Diuretic Phase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diuretic-phase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Patient experiences a gradual increase in daily urinary output which may be greater than 2000ml/day, but about one to three litres per day.</li>
<li>Despite the urinary output rising, the nephrons are still not fully functional.</li>
<li>The kidneys have also recovered their ability to excrete wastes but not to concentrate urine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-recovery-period">The Recovery Period<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-recovery-period" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The phase begins when the glomerular filtrate rate rises and the blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine levels start to stabilise and then decrease. The phase lasts 3 - 12 months.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="diagnosis">Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>History taking and physical examination are done to determine the causes.</li>
<li>Urinalysis will show casts or proteins in intrarenal disorders.</li>
<li>Decreased or absent urinary output.</li>
<li>Increase levels of Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN), serum creatinine, sodium, potassium and chloride.</li>
<li>Decreased serum calcium, carbon dioxide (bicarbonate) and haemoglobin.</li>
<li>If the diagnosis cannot be made by history and physical examination, then the following tests may be done.</li>
<li>Renal ultrasound, renal scan, retrograde pyelogram, Computed Tomography (CT) scan or Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).</li>
</ul>
